emissions in the U.K ( Dadhich et al., 2015 ) and around 40% of the
total waste material in China ( Huang et al., 2018 ). Globally, 65% of
total aggregates and 20% of metal material are consumed in the
construction sector ( Ajayabi et al., 2019 ) and construction is
responsible for the consumption of 60% of raw materials ( Zabalza
Bribi /C19an et al., 2011 ). When looking beyond construction, the built
environment in the European Union accounts for half of the ma-
terials extracted, 35% of CO 2emissions, and generating up to 30% of
the waste of numerous materials ( “Roadmap to a Resource Ef ﬁcient
Europe COM (2011) 571, ”2011 ) including concrete, and various
metal materials ( Fregonara et al., 2017 ).
Due to its massive impact, CBE is considered to have great po-
tential in generating value and taking advantage of the practices
within CE ( Ajayabi et al., 2019 ). The built environment, with its
direct impact on the environment from the large use of energy,
material, and minerals ( Ghisellini et al., 2018b ), is a resource-
intensive sector ( Casas-Arredondo et al., 2018 ). CE thinking places
importance on the design and construction stages of buildings to
minimize resource usage and waste generation as early as possible
(Honic et al., 2019 ). One of the aims of construction in CE is to
eliminate or at least minimize waste ( Ghisellini et al., 2018b )a t
both the construction and deconstruction stages ( Akanbi et al.,
2019 ). This provides an economically attractive model in response
to the shortages of raw resources ( Ekin Eray et al., 2019 ). According
to CE principles, the best re-use alternative in the construction
industry is reusing the building ( G/C19alvez-Martos et al., 2018 ) since
the building and construction activities are responsible for natural
resource consumption and CO 2emissions ( Ajayi et al., 2019 ).
Nevertheless, the selection of materials that are low on environ-
mental impact can reduce the emission of CO 2in the construction
industry ( Licciardello et al., 2017 ). Just as it is important to note the
negative impact on the environment, it is also important to note the
positive effects of construction such as contribution to Gross Do-
mestic Product, creating job opportunities, and providing infra-
structure that satis ﬁes human needs ( Zuo et al., 2012 ).
Similar to most of the project types in general, construction
processes can be broken down into stages of preparation, pro-
curement, design, construction, and take-over ( Sutt, 2011 ). For
traditional procurement of construction projects, the main stages
are considered to be design, tender, construction, and operation
(Cooke and Williams, 1998 ). However, at a very early phase, a
construction project needs to verify its ﬁnancial viability before
moving forward from an investor ’s perspective ( Jackson, 2020 ).
Complying with the reviewed CBECE literature, the construction
stage is combined with preconstruction and postconstruction
stages resulting in the complete stages of “Feasibility and Plan-
ning ”,“Design ”,“Manufacturing ”,“Construction ”,“Operation ”and
“End of Life ”(see Fig. 1 ). The feasibility and planning stage contains
early-stage decisions including, investment decisions, technical or
ﬁnancial feasibilities, and planning activities. Following a positive
decision in the feasibility and planning stage, the design stage
starts, and the project begins taking shape as a design document.
The manufacturing phase can be both a project-speci ﬁc phase or an
independent material production in which the production of the
construction material is the main purpose. The construction stage is
where all the site-related activities take place bringing resourcesand knowledge together to physically form the project. Following
the construction stage, the project becomes a product anddelivered to the end-user starting the operation stage. Finally, the
end-of-life stage starts when the operation lifetime is over.
The built environment, on the other hand, is more like a scale
nature topic introduced at meso, micro, and macro scales
(Anastasiades et al., 2020 ).

Following
the construction stage, the project becomes a product anddelivered to the end-user starting the operation stage. Finally, the
end-of-life stage starts when the operation lifetime is over.
The built environment, on the other hand, is more like a scale
nature topic introduced at meso, micro, and macro scales
(Anastasiades et al., 2020 ). The built environment starts as a ma-
terial or component form and grows into buildings, areas, cities,
andﬁnally a man-made environment of earth. From a broader view,
the built environment is categorized into seven scales: products,
interiors, structures, landscapes, cities, regions, and earth
(Bartuska, 2007 ). In line with the reviewed literature of CBECE, the
built environment scales in this study are grouped into “Material ”,
“Building ”,“Area ”, and
“City ”.“Material ”comprises all types of
material and components while “Building ”includes all types of
structures, residential, non-residential, and infrastructure. “Area ”
represents the industrial parks and non-industrial areas that are
smaller than cities but larger than facilities, and, ﬁnally “City ”in-
cludes both cities and large regions (see Fig. 2 ).
Considering the massive impact of construction on both the
economy and the environment, as well as its high potential to
contribute to CE principles ( Smol et al., 2015 ), this review assumes
it is highly important to assess the academic progress in the ﬁeld of
CBECE. Although research-based studies and frameworks exist,
construction is in the very early stages of transforming to CE
(Hossain and Ng, 2018 ) and needs to embrace practices for a sus-
tainable built environment ( Kleme /C20s and Huisingh, 2005 ). Under the
prevailing LE model, construction of a building is considered a
project ( Institute, 2017 ) with an established starting and end date
which is realized upon the completion of a commissioning period.Though there is more than one de ﬁnition of commissioning
(Turner, 1982 ), it generally represents the point where the con-
struction process meets the building product for the ﬁrst time to
verify the alignment of the planned product with the actual
outcome ( Kubba, 2010 ). This is also where the production stage
ﬁnishes and the product usage stage starts. Due to one of the
fundamental principles of CE, which constitutes maintaining a
closed loop of material ( Sanchez and Haas, 2018a ), the end of the
construction stage now interphases within the broader lifecycle in
combination with production and use. This newly integrated life-
cycle acts in a cyclical manner similar to emerging lifecycle ap-
proaches, i.e. cradle to cradle. Consequently, this new overarching
stage selected in this study is de ﬁned as construction and built
environment (CBE). When considering the limited time and

resources used for research within CBE, we need to understand
what ﬁelds and topics are already investigated contributing to the
closed-loop of material. Are there ﬁelds requiring additional aca-
demic attention but remain understudied which promise greater
impact and importance in expediting CE in CBE? Do we know
which ﬁelds or subjects in CBE need to be prioritized to expedite
circularity within CBECE? CE requires us to consider the resources
in a continuously cyclical way. In the case of construction and built
environment, resources are being processed in the construction
stage and become a product in different scales of the built envi-
ronment. However, current literature lacks a comprehensive review
of CBECE, which would enable a mapping of the present progress,
gaps, and prospective ideas in an integrated manner. In this context,
a comprehensive literature review can help synthesize the existing
studies with their main CBECE contributions which establish the
main scope of this study.
Although environmental sustainability in construction is a long-
standing research topic, academic studies and literature reviews of
construction in CE are very limited ( Pomponi and Moncaster, 2017 ).
Existing literature reviews are based on a small number of studies
and mainly provide detailed but fragmented and narrow topics.Upon investigating the existing literature reviews of CBECE, it is
found that studies are spread across four major areas including
construction and demolition waste (CDW), municipal and indus-
trial waste, built environment and construction industry, and sus-
tainability of construction material. One of the earliest literature
reviews focused on exploring CDW management strategies
implemented in China to demonstrate the transition of CDW to-
wards cleaner products ( Ghisellini et al., 2018a ). Additionally,
Ghisellini et al. (2018b) reviewed the CE literature to investigate its
primary principles to be applied in CDW. To provide a broader re-
view of CDW, studies conducted between 2009 and 2018 are
reviewed to provide a guide linking existing practices and theories
to future trends ( Jin et al., 2019 ). In a comparative nature literature
review, CDW management practices in China and the USA are
reviewed to investigate the present policies and regulations of CDW
management in both countries ( Aslam et al., 2020 ). Finally, in a
recent study, the literature is reviewed for factors affecting the CE
adoption by the CDW industry ( L/C19opez Ruiz et al., 2020 ).
Literature reviews with a particular focus on waste include a
study with the recycling of bottom ash obtained by municipal solid
waste from the points of present chemical barriers, engineering
applications, and varying treatment technologies for different use
cases ( Verbinnen et al., 2016 ). In a more speci ﬁc study, Tallini and
Cedola (2018) examined the literature for investigating the
changes in thermal characteristics of construction material when
mixed with residual waste obtained from the combustion of
municipal solid waste. In addition to the municipal waste, studies
conducted in Russia with a focus on inorganic industrial waste are
reviewed to improve the material properties of construction ce-
ramics ( Boltakova et al., 2017 ).
The built environment and the construction industry also
caught the attention of literature reviews. Pomponi and Moncaster
(2017) reviewed the de ﬁning dimensions of CE that can be used
within the built environment. By utilizing CE principles, resource
efﬁciency within the built environment is evaluated ( Ness and
Xing, 2017 ) and followed by reviewing the factors facilitating CE
in the built environment and studying gaps that are needed to be
ﬁlled ( Munaro et al., 2020 ).Tallini and Cedola (2018) , on the other
hand, studied the implication of the life cycle assessment ap-
proaches on buildings via investigating case studies and surveys
and concluded that resource recovery and ef
ﬁciency in building
construction have not been investigated adequately. In a relatively
narrow review, based on 45 articles, Benachio et al. (2020) studied
literature to ﬁnd recent CE developments that can be potentiallyutilized in the construction industry. For a more speci ﬁc study, CE
applications in the construction industry are reviewed in the
context of bridge construction ( Anastasiades et al., 2020 ).

In a relatively
narrow review, based on 45 articles, Benachio et al. (2020) studied
literature to ﬁnd recent CE developments that can be potentiallyutilized in the construction industry. For a more speci ﬁc study, CE
applications in the construction industry are reviewed in the
context of bridge construction ( Anastasiades et al., 2020 ).
Other reviews in CBECE literature included research on recycled
aggregate as sustainable construction material ( Chen et al., 2019 ),
low-carbon production of building materials ( Orsini and Marrone,
2019 ), recycled ﬁbers used as concrete reinforcement ( Merli et al.,
2020 ), factors affecting the reuse of building components
(Rakhshan et al., 2020 ) and residues found in the agro-industry that
can be valorized in building construction via the use of additive
material or water treatment ( Ricciardi et al., 2020 ).
As described brie ﬂy in the above summary of existing literature,
the available reviews focus on either narrow topics (CDW, munic-
ipal and industrial waste, CE in the built environment, CE in the
construction industry, and sustainability in construction materials)
or single studies in a fragmented nature from the rest of the CBE
domain. In this regard, this study provides a comprehensive liter-
ature review of CBECE based on a systematic literature review of
238 papers and debuts a matrix shape review framework that
brings built environment scales and construction stages together
while combining CE subjects in order to quickly evaluate thematurity and understudied ﬁelds of CBECE. The study also con-
tributes to the current literature by providing a comprehensive
state of the literature with the subject maturity and diversity,
understudied ﬁelds, gaps, challenges, providing extensive discus-
sions, critical review, and future research ideas with sound pro-
posals in CBECE. It is also possible to use the three-tier framework
developed in this study for different studies and purposes. Other
contributions of the study are to propose the additional CE prin-
ciple of “Replace ”to the literature in section 3.1.4.3 , and proposals
and future research ideas in section 4.
Focusing on CBECE, this study aims (i) to demonstrate its
development trend and diversity based on a descriptive analysis in
section 3.1, (ii) to spot its maturity, gaps, and understudied areas
based on a novel framework given in section 3.2, (iii) to provide
critical reviews of ﬁndings, proposals and future suggestions based
on a synthesis of the literature in section 3.3. The method observed
in this study, including systematic literature review, research tools,
structure, and steps of the screening process, is described in detail
in section 2. Based on a full review of 238 papers, the study pro-
vides descriptive analysis, text analysis, literature mapping on a
three-tier framework, and literature synthesis, each serving a
purpose as described in section 2.
2. Method
To map out the existing state of the literature in a comprehen-
sive way, a systematic literature review is conducted with explicit,
reproducible nature while identifying, evaluating, and synthesizing
the existing knowledge of literature ( Fink, 2014 ). Systematic liter-
ature reviews help understand a large body of literature by map-
ping out the existing state of the literature ( Petticrew and Roberts,
n.d.) and establish a framework for future studies in a structured
form ( Okoli and Schabram, 2010 ). The study is conducted based on
a clear set of steps and protocols to reduce prospective researcher
bias ( Carver et al., 2013 ) and provide a transparent picture of the
literature to establish a basis for this study. During the literature
review, the eight steps of the systematic literature review are
employed including the purpose of literature review, protocol,
searching, screening, quality appraisal, data extraction, synthesis,
and writing ( Okoli and Schabram, 2010 ). Moreover, similar to
protocols by Briner and Denyer (2012) , the following Fig. 3 illus-
trates the ﬂow and protocols incorporated into this research by
linking the aim of the study to the speci ﬁc sections of the paper.€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180

2.1. Tools and sources
As main study tools used for this study; Zotero ( “Zotero | About, ”
n.d.) is used as the reference management tool, Atlas.ti ( “What is
ATLAS.ti, ”n.d.) for synthesizing the literature, Voyant-Tool
(“About - Voyant Tools Help, ”n.d.) for text analysis, and Microsoft
Ofﬁce ( “Ofﬁce - Microsoft Download Center, ”n.d.) for data analysis,
presentation and writing the manuscript.
As for the searching database, Ebscohost ( “EBSCO Information
Services, ”n.d.) is selected as the primary source, due to its access
to a large number of databases containing nearly 400 academicdatabases including Scopus, ScienceDirect, and Web of Science
(“Content in EBSCOhost Databases is Diligently Selected by Subject
Matter Experts, ”n.d.).
2.2. Screening and review process
Due to the relatively new concept of CE and the highly lagging
nature of CBE, it is aimed to reach as many studies as possible that
are particularly related to CE while maintaining the quality of pa-
pers. Therefore, peer-reviewed academic journal papers in the
English language are chosen as the main type of papers. Studies

containing one of the terms of “construction ”,“built ”,o r “build ”in
either one of the title, keyword, or abstract ﬁelds are considered
eligible as long as they contained the term “circular economy ”in
any of those ﬁelds.
The review process is completed in ﬁve main steps starting with
one large initial search and progressively applying further quali-tative criteria to sustain paper quality and relevance. After each
phase of the screening is completed, the number of the remaining
papers is stated (See Fig. 4 ).
In the following, each phase is explained and a complete review
process is demonstrated in Fig. 5 .
In the 1stPhase, a set of keywords seen below is applied in three
separate searches.
/C15Search Criteria for “Title Only ”¼construction OR built OR build
AND circular economy
/C15Search Criteria for “Keyword Only ”¼construction OR built OR
build AND circular economy
/C15Search Criteria for “Abstract Only ”¼construction OR built OR
build AND circular economy
In the 2ndphase , the basic qualitative criteria seen below are
applied to the results obtained from the ﬁrst phase.
/C15Only peer-reviewed
/C15Only English language
/C15Removal of identical duplicate papersIn the 3rd phase, titles and keywords are checked for relevancy
as per the “Eligibility ”conditions mentioned. It is noticed that
searches returned some irrelevant studies to the scope of this paper
when they contained the term “construction ”or “building ”as a
verb for an irrelevant subject e.g. “construction of circular economy
industrial system ( Man and Wenhu, 2007 )”.
In the 4thphase , the remaining duplicate papers are manually
selected and removed.
In the 5thphase , abstracts of papers are manually reviewed for
subject relevancy. Any abstract that did not provide any words,
meanings, or sentence structures related to CBECE is ﬁltered out.
At the end of the screening, obtained papers are studied in a full
review to analyze their content, ﬁndings, contribution, subject,
stage, and scale under the scope of CBECE to be used for descriptive
analysis, review framework, and literature synthesis. Other biblio-
metric information such as date, author, publisher, etc. needed for
descriptive analysis is obtained with the help of citation informa-
tion via Zotero software ( “Zotero | About, ”n.d.). However, the dates
of some studies derived automatically from the citation informa-
tion did not match with the actual dates on the published papers,
hence they were corrected manually.
3. Results
3.1. Descriptive analysis
The descriptive research analysis is a type of quantitative anal-
ysis ( “Descriptive Research Design | De ﬁnition, Methods and

Examples, ”2019 ) suitable for studies to track the academic prog-
ress and investigate the themes within the research domain
(Haneem et al., 2017 ). The ﬁnal production of a descriptive analysis
is considered the actual state of the research ﬁeld ( Yang and Tate,
2012 ). Descriptive analysis is commonly used in systematic litera-
ture reviews ( Haneem et al., 2017 ) to describe the data gathered
from the literature ( Trochim, n.d. ) in an interpretable model often
in the form of frequency analysis ( Yang and Tate, 2012 ). It helps to
reduce and simplify a large volume of data to describe a population
of studies accurately ( Descriptive Research Design ). Therefore, due
to the suitable structure of this study with review frameworks
(Schlagenhaufer and Amberg, 2015 ) and the study goals stated in
section 1, a descriptive analysis is performed and its results are
provided in the following subsections of 3.1.1, 3.1.2, 3.1.3, 3.1.4
along with a text analysis (see section 3.1.5 ) being in line with the
results of descriptive analysis.
3.1.1. Publication trend by years
Studies regarding CBECE started emerging in 2008 but the vol-
ume remained low for more than 5 years. To better illustrate
exponential growth in recent years, the number of publications is
demonstrated by a bar chart along with a trend line (see Fig. 6 ), and
the majority of the studies are found to be published within the last
4 years. As 2020 has not concluded at the time of this review, it is
noted that there have been 45 studies published in the ﬁrst 4
months. When taking into account the trend line ( Intel
Corporation, 2010 ) generated based on the previous year ’s
numbers, it is estimated to exceed 120 papers by the end of 2020.

3.1.2. Publication shares by journals
After conducting a systematic literature review based on the
method explained in Section 2, 238 papers in total are obtained that
are published by 96 different journals. However, since the distri-
bution of publishing is not homogenous, it is imperative to list the
topﬁve journals separately as they hold 45% of the total papers
published (see Table 1 ).For the remaining 91 journals, the number of papers per journal
is very limited (see Table 2 ).
3.1.3. Publication shares by authors and countries
804 authors in total contributed to publishing 238 papers during
the period from 2008 to 2020. The average number of authors who
contributed per paper is 3.37. The top 5 authors who contributed
the majority of CBECE literature are shown in Table 3 .
China has been the leading country in terms of publication
share, in particular with studies mainly focusing on the CE devel-
opment of industrial parks and regions (See Table 4 and Fig. 7 ).
3.1.4. Establishing stage-scale-subject framework
3.1.4.1. Circular economy subjects. The review framework proposed
in this study is a three-tier conceptual framework designed to
capture the literature ’s progress as well as understudied areas. The
horizontal axis of the framework is based on a built environment
scale which ﬁts well with the horizontal nature of the built envi-
ronment starting from material level to city level as explained in
section 1. Likewise, the vertical axis of the framework is based on
stages that include preconstruction, construction, and post-
construction where the built environment components go
through. Finally, the subject dimension of the framework is deter-
mined after evaluating stages and scales within the context of 10 Rprinciples of CE ( Potting et al., 2017 ), resulting in 25 different CE
subjects that focus on the CE aspect of the reviewed paper (see
Fig. 8 ).
When looking at the existing R principles from a linear to a more
circular order, we see principles of recover (material is incinerated
to recover energy), recycle (material is processed to obtain a new
material), repurpose (using discarded components for a different
purpose), remanufacture (using abandoned parts for a new product
with the same function), refurbish (updating or restoring an

Yanya (2018) could be classi ﬁed under one large topic of Waste
Management this would not help in differentiating the two studies
asJim/C19enez-Rivero et al. (2017) focused on several waste manage-
ment practices at a construction site while Yao (2018) studied the
narrower topic of waste, speci ﬁcally recycled pervious concrete.
Even though both studies focused on waste, one was about the
management aspect of waste while the other was the material
production through waste recycling. This way of classi ﬁcation al-
lows escalating CE subjects in a higher-level group when needed.
InFig. 8 , CE subjects, starting with “Decoupling ”and ending
with “Sustainable Material Replacement ”, are the combination of
the construction stages with R principles. CE subjects beginning
with “Material Reuse ”and ending with “Service Life Extending ”are
the combination of the built environment scale with R principles.
Finally, CE subjects starting with “Beneﬁt Assessment ”and ending
with “CE Transition and Promotion ”are non-scale and non-stage
combinations of the R principles with construction industry-
related topics. During the review process, it is noted that some
studies covered more than one scale, stage, or subject dimensionsresulting in a higher number of CE subjects than the actual number
of reviewed papers. After completion of CE subject development,
each subject is clari ﬁed brie ﬂy with their corresponding acronyms:

3.1.4.3. The new R principle “Replace ”.While the existing 10 “R”
principles have an indirect effect on lowering the environmental
pressure ( Potting et al., 2017 ), it is noticed that some papers
(Campbell, 2019 ;Cejuela et al., 2018 ;Elsacker et al., 2020 ;Lazarevic
et al., 2019 ;Orsini and Marrone, 2019 ) had the sole purpose of
replacing conventional construction materials (see Table 5 ) with
environmentally friendly materials, notably lowering CO 2,t o
reduce the environmental impact which is not directly represented
by the existing 10 R principles (E10RP) ( Potting et al., 2017 ).
As described in section 3.1.4.1 ,E10RP primarily focus on the
existing material. For instance, the Recover principle represents the
incineration of existing material while Recycle is a process to obtaina new material from the existing material. Therefore, the members
of E10RP fall in either one of two efforts, “Increasing ”or
“Decreasing ”. The principles of Recover, Recycle, Repurpose,
Remanufacture, Refurbish, Repair and Reuse aim to increase the
economic value of the existing material after their lifetime has
ended or the need has changed. Whereas the principles of Reduce,
Rethink, and Refuse are concerned with decreasing the use of raw
material.
Although the Replace principle may still result in “Increasing ”
economic value or “Decreasing ”raw material usage as a secondary
beneﬁt, it is mainly concerned with introducing a new sustainablereplacement to existing material. Such as wood material is
considered a replacement to traditional concrete due to lowering
the effect of CO
2which eliminates the use of concrete in future
buildings ( Campbell, 2019 ;Lazarevic et al., 2019 ). The use of
wooden material as opposed to a concrete alternative may be
greater use of natural material but again providing lower CO 2
throughout the economic lifetime of a building. Replace may re ﬂect
the innovative research and development aspect of CE by creating
new material or components to use in future building projects with
no primary intention of Increasing the economic value or
Decreasing raw material usage, but rather lowering the level of CO 2
compared to the existing material. Likewise, Elsacker et al. (2020)
introduced mycelium-based materials to replace traditional
acoustic panels for ﬂoor tiles which indicates a potential replace-
ment by bio-based material to some of the conventional con-
struction material. Among the studies in Table 5 , the study by
Cejuela et al. (2018) could be perceived as part of the Recycle
principle. However, the main purpose of that study is to introduce a
sustainable replacement to the concrete caisson by providing analternative with an extended lifetime. At the material level, the
study investigates ﬁberglass as a replacement for steel bars in
concrete reinforcement and concludes that the impact of maritime
works can be reduced upon replacing traditional material with
more advanced alternatives such as composite and ﬁberglass. On
the other hand, Orsini and Marrone (2019) focus on low-carbon
building materials by analyzing the literature on life cycle assess-
ment and low carbon emission approaches in order to introduce
sustainable material replacements.
It is possible that the Replace principle may require more raw
material usage compared to a formerly used material but still
lowering CO
2substantially.

On
the other hand, Orsini and Marrone (2019) focus on low-carbon
building materials by analyzing the literature on life cycle assess-
ment and low carbon emission approaches in order to introduce
sustainable material replacements.
It is possible that the Replace principle may require more raw
material usage compared to a formerly used material but still
lowering CO
2substantially. Hence, by addressing such a purpose
with an additional R principle, we may now be able to distinguish
even more varying bene ﬁts or results among different R principles.
Therefore, in addition to the existing principles, a new 11th R
principle of CE, namely “Replace ”, is proposed in this review to
represent the aim of replacing conventional construction material

with environmentally friendly alternatives (see Fig. 14 ). This new
principle further contributes to one of the fundamental goals of CE
which is to keep pollution out of the system. After further
extending R principles (11 R Principles) their brief descriptions are
provided in the following:
/C15Replace : A new more sustainable material alternative is
designed or manufactured to replace the existing material
/C15Recover : Material is incinerated to recover energy
/C15Recycle : Material is processed to obtain new material
/C15Repurpose : Using discarded components for different purpose
/C15Remanufacture : Using abandoned parts for a new product with
the same function
/C15Refurbish : Updating or restoring an existing product
/C15Repair : Repairing a product to continue its function
/C15Reuse : Reusing a product discarded by another user
/C15Reduce : Increasing the ef ﬁciency of natural resources to make a
product
/C15Rethink : Enhancing product usage/C15Refuse : Removing functions to make products redundant
By introducing the new principle “Replace ”, it was possible to
establish the CE subject of “Sustainable Material Replacement ”for
relevant studies after applying the “Manufacturing ”stage to “R”
principles (see Fig. 14 ).
3.1.5. Text analysis
Selected papers of CBECE had a corpus with 238 documents
totaling 2,357,824 words and 146,116 unique word forms. The
corpus is analyzed with a text analysis tool ( “About - Voyant Tools
Help, ”n.d.) to determine the most frequently used terms within the
reviewed papers. The text analysis resulted in “Waste ”as being the
most popular term which con ﬁrms the result of the review
framework since the “Waste valorization ”is found to be the most
studied CE subject. Frequently used terms in CBECE are illustrated
in a word cloud (see Fig. 15 ) and the top ﬁve most frequently used
terms are listed in Table 6 which are used when establishing the
Scale-Stage-Subject dimensions of the framework.

3.2. Review framework
Findings obtained within literature review studies need to be
organized around a conceptual framework to identify existing
states and gaps of the literature logically and clearly ( SAGE
Publications, 2019 ). Besides, in the absence of such a framework,there is a high chance that the study might drift away from the
main purpose of the study ( Rocco and Plakhotnik, 2009 ). Therefore,
considering the comprehensive and integrative nature of this re-
view, a novel framework synthesizing the studies of CBECE was
developed and utilized to serve as a guiding map ( “Conceptual
Framework, ”n.d.;Stein and Lee, 2003 ) to understand and illus-
trate ( “Developing a Conceptual Framework for Research
(Sample), ”2015 ) the state of CBECE literature. In addition to map-
ping CBECE literature, the framework helps clarify the collected
data to spot literature gaps and understudied ﬁelds.
3.2.1. Structure of the framework
The structure of the framework is based on the combination of
the built environment scales, construction stages, and CE subjects
which are all integrated in a novel way. Reviewed studies are
categorized based on those dimensions and the number of their
occurrences within the relevant dimensions are also demonstrated
in the cells of the framework. The number of total occurrences is
greater than the number of reviewed studies due to the fact that
some studies covered multiple dimensions at once as seen in the
study by Esa et al. (2017) which covers the multiple stages of
planning, design, and construction.
As shown in Fig. 16 , CE subjects are placed in a typical module
with 5 *5 cells which are repeated throughout the entire framework
with built environment scales and construction stages. The acro-
nyms used in the module are explained in the following:
WM: Waste Management WRc : Waste Recycling WR: Waste
Reduction.
WVCDR : Waste Valorization Construction and Demolition
Related.
WVNCDR : Waste Valorization Non- Construction and Demoli-
tion Related.
PS: Product as Service QA: Quality Assessment RER: Resource &
Energy Reduction SLE: Service Life Extending.
SMR : Sustainable Material Replacement IA: Impact Asses-
sment IS: Industrial Symbiosis.
LSA: Literature and Standard Assessment MFB : Material Flow
and Bank MR: Material Reuse.
CPD: Circular Planning &Design CA: Comparative Assessment D:
Decoupling EC: Earth Construction.

The entire framework consists of 600 cells within 24 typical
modules each containing 25 cells. As seen in Fig. 16 , the built
environment being the ﬁrst dimension of the review framework, is
a vertical nature phenomenon ( Bartuska, 2007 ) where the volume
of its elements increases in ascending order and is categorized as
meso, micro, and macro scales ( Anastasiades et al., 2020 ). The
module has construction as the second dimension, with pre and
post-stages as horizontal and its sub-stages placed in a timeline
from left to right. These two domains of construction and built
environment are brought together in a two-dimensional matrix
shape, further enhanced by the 3rd dimension whereby CE subjects
discover their relation to CE.
As a result, this paper provides integration of construction and
built environment for the ﬁrst time in literature which can be also
used for different studies and purposes. The primary reason to
establish such a framework is the necessity to evaluate resources in
a cyclical manner where their processes (construction) and product
forms (built environment) are combined in lifecycle thinking
(Kobza and Schuster, 2016 ). By differentiating the scale, stage, andsubjects of the studies as proposed in this study, it is expected to
develop a more precise CE strategy suitable to those varying as-
pects. For instance, when investigating the “Planning ”stage under
CE, it is important to acknowledge whether it is for a single house
“Building ”or a “City ”development since each may require different
CE principles to be prioritized. After setting up the Stage, Scale, and
Subject framework dimensions in sections 3.1.4.1 and 3.1.4.2 ,
selected papers are evaluated based on said dimensions to under-
stand the current literature progress and spot possible under-
studied areas.

With the help of a three-tiered framework (see Fig. 17 ),
reviewed literature by their corresponding CE subjects are placed in
4 built environment scales and 6 construction stages providing a
snapshot for the maturity of CBECE literature. The numbers within
the cells represent the number of studies reviewed within a
particular subject. Since some studies investigate more than one
dimension, the total number of CE subjects is 321 which is greater
than the total number of papers (238). Because of the limited
number of research topics shown in the framework, it is possible to
say that CBECE literature is still at an early stage.Table 5

The literature synthesis combines and gathers the reviewed
studies ( Levy and J. Ellis, 2006 ) and can be organized thematically
(“How to Synthesize Written Information - 4 Steps &Examples |
Simply Psychology, ”n.d.) by looking for common points and dif-
ferences ( DeCarlo, 2018 ). It requires critical evaluation to
acknowledge differences and similarities and is commonly used for
literature review papers ( Lai) synthesizing important points or

sections. The literature synthesis provided here is also used for
developing section 4of this study which includes discussions,
proposals, and future research ideas.3.3.1. Construction industry, enablers, and barriers
Introducing CE to CBE is imperative to reduce environmental
impact as well as improving the quality of life ( Ness and Xing, 2017 )
which utilizes an interdisciplinary approach. To demonstrate the CE
transformation of the building industry, Nu~nez-Cacho et al. (2018)
developed a scale to measure the importance of CE for companies.
Utilizing CE in the construction industry ( Benachio et al., 2020 ) and
searching circular business models (through industrial symbiosis,
product life extension, and take-back model) ( Charlotte Heesbeen

and Alejandro Prieto, 2020 ) are all part of efforts to achieve circu-
larity within the construction industry. In addition to the new
business models, CBECE requires a new ownership model and
interdisciplinary approach ( Leising et al., 2018 ) in which green
supply chain practices help in reducing carbon emissions ( Nasir,
2017 ). In this complex and multidisciplinary environment, Yu
et al. (2015) studied industrial symbiosis by enabling waste valo-
rization across different industries. Among one of the barriers of
waste valorization, the lack of a market mechanism to reuseconstruction material ( Chang and Hsieh, 2019 ) is addressed by
another study proposing a virtual marketplace to facilitate inter-
sectorial waste recycling ( Migliore, 2019 ). By utilizing a multidis-
ciplinary approach, Gan et al. (2020) studied to achieve both human
wellbeing and environmental sustainability via socio-technical
solutions. Additionally, interdisciplinarity within CBE is taken
from an education standpoint under Interdisciplinary Sustainable
Architecture Lab by Orozco-Messana et al. (2020) to further
improve interdisciplinary built environment collaboration.
