16

In the dynamic environment of the construction industry,
embracing CE principles might play an even greater role in the
future for especially large construction companies to maintain their
economic growth ( Jones and Comfort, 2018 ). The ﬁnancial stability
and capacity of a company to embrace CE ( G/C19orecki et al., 2019 ) are
other enablers to CE transition and stakeholder collaboration ( Shi
and Zhang, 2013 ). Economic bene ﬁts and ﬁnancial incentives
such as tax arrangements and ﬁnancial subsidies are important
factors for construction stakeholders when adopting CE principles
(Yu et al., 2015 ). However, the diversity of stakeholders in the
construction and their lack of understanding of sustainability pose
a challenge for CE ( Liu et al., 2019 ). To help overcome such
misunderstanding and ensure the CE reliance within a construction
team, G/C19orecki (2019) proposes a CE manager to provide additional
knowledge and support for CE practices. Among the several
stakeholder challenges, Ploeger et al. (2019) found the economic
ownership of a building as a long-standing issue since it is not
deﬁned in the real estate law to date. When looking at the other
barriers and challenges to implementing CE in the construction
industry, lack of awareness, ﬁnancial, and political support are
found to be the main issues ( Wu et al., 2019 ). The social dimension
of construction is added as being another barrier by Mikul /C20ci/C19c et al.
(2020) . Barriers to city-level CE included CE adaptation of design
and technology, material information, and additional investment
for CE business models ( Campbell-Johnston et al., 2019 ). To help
overcome similar barriers and achieve easier CE transformation at
the city level, Lee et al. (2016) suggested sourcing locally and
adopting clean transportation as important strategies. Additionally,
public policies and ﬁnancial incentives for material reuse, waste
collection, and the creation of the recovery market are other
important factors in facilitating CE ( Nubholz et al., 2019 ).
3.3.2. Material
3.3.2.1. Sustainable material. CE aims to use environment-friendly
material alternatives replacing the conventional to prevent
adverse environmental consequences. In this regard, the use of
organic waste to produce clay bricks provided a decrease in the
environmental impact ( Martínez-García and Jos /C19eRojas-Sola, 2018 ).
However, Ros-Dosd /C19a et al. (2019) argued that the best environ-
mental performance achieved by inorganic coverings (ceramics and
stone) compared to the alternatives of polymer and wood-based
ﬂoor coverings. Because of its sustainable characteristics, timber
is studied under CE principles such as design for disassembly and
improved durability by Campbell (2019) while Lazarevic et al.
(2019) proposed ways for increasing timber usage in general.
Other studies regarding the replacement of conventional materials
included composite material for caisson production ( Cejuela et al.,
2018 ), pervious concrete made with the recycled aggregate ( Yao
Yanya, 2018 ), bio-based material to provide a natural glue for the
production of construction materials ( Elsacker et al., 2020 ), all fa-
voring the use of sustainable material alternatives to replace con-
struction materials most notably concrete and cement.
Additionally, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the cement
industry, Orsini and Marrone (2019) implemented a Low-Carbon
Environment Approach.
In order to increase sustainability and extend the service life of
the material, we see more products offered in the “Product-as-a-
Service ”system offering various bene ﬁts including the lower cap-
ital requirement for the user and maintaining the retention of
material ownership by the supplier ( Juan Francisco Azcarate-
Aguerre et al., 2018 ). Smart technologies to enhance material
functionality ( Lyubenova et al., 2018 ) and innovative assembly
systems of material such as interlocking shape for an all-glass
system ( Faidra Oikonomopoulou, 2018 ) can help improve mate-
rial sustainability. Though, implementing such applications in theearly stage of a project may require a decision-support framework
combining system thinking and architectural design ( Ahmed Kamal
Ali, 2017 ).

Smart technologies to enhance material
functionality ( Lyubenova et al., 2018 ) and innovative assembly
systems of material such as interlocking shape for an all-glass
system ( Faidra Oikonomopoulou, 2018 ) can help improve mate-
rial sustainability. Though, implementing such applications in theearly stage of a project may require a decision-support framework
combining system thinking and architectural design ( Ahmed Kamal
Ali, 2017 ).
When aiming for the CE transformation, sustainability is needed
to be quanti ﬁed and measured throughout the transition period to
track the progress. The utilization of recycled mass at the
manufacturing stage is found to be an important factor in
increasing material sustainability ( Giama and Papadopoulos, 2020 )
which can be further exploited with the use of available technology
to reduce environmental impact to a greater extent ( Boer et al.,
2020 ). However, a series of leaching tests demonstrated that
there may be a variance between different quality standards when
assessing the environmental impacts ( Duester et al., 2017 ). Keeping
that in mind, the studies evaluating the performance of sustainable
material on resistance to carbonation, frost ( Teplý et al., 2018 ), and
water ( Huber et al., 2020 ) veri ﬁed the technical feasibility of con-
struction and demolition waste (CDW) for reuse. This viability of
CDW is also con ﬁrmed by Hahladakis et al. (2020) through a SWOT
analysis for concrete production. Although it is possible to lower
environmental and economic impacts by design solutions to
implement component reuse ( Buyle et al., 2019 ), reusing compo-
nents at high temperatures such as composite shear connectors
may pose a risk for the overall material performance ( Sencu et al.,
2019 ). Nevertheless increased material circularity is claimed to
have no negative impact on overall material health ( Bob
Geldermans et al., 2019a ).
3.3.2.2. Material stock and ﬂow. City-level CE requires us to look at
the existing buildings and infrastructure as a material stock that
needs to be ef ﬁciently used. Improving the present resource pro-
ductivity rates while maintaining economic growth requires a shift
by implementing the “product as service ”principle ( Ness, 2008 ).
Introducing the term “urban mining ”,Arora et al. (2020) proposed a
framework to estimate the buildings ’city-wide recovery and reuse
potential of the building components. Some of those components
are used during building ﬁt-outs and interestingly they occupy the
most replacement of the built environment ( Casas-Arredondo et al.,
2018 ). On the other hand, studies focusing on sustainable infra-
structure indicate several issues for resource productivity. Roads in
this manner, are considered important resource consumers due to
highly linear economic attributes ( Wen and Li, 2010 ). Even though
industrial symbiosis may enable roads to utilize recycled hazardous
material ( Karayannis et al., 2017 ), increased road layers due to
maintenance and improved driving quality might be one of the
reasons for boosted material consumption by the roads ( Miatto
et al., 2017 ). To limit material usage, Schiller et al. (2017) investi-
gated regional limits and proposed a regionalized continuous ma-
terial ﬂow analysis (MFA) based on the dimensions of waste
management technology, building structure, and process engi-
neering. When combining material ﬂow analysis with industrial
symbiosis, transportation emerged as an important issue at the
urban level ( Georg et al., 2017 ). Industrial symbiosis with its po-
tential environmental bene ﬁt is also spotted by Sun et al. (2017)
when quantifying symbiotic networks with MFA.
Estimating material stock and analyzing its ﬂow gained some
academic attention in the literature since mapping material stock-
ﬂow along with the quantity and quality dimensions serve valuable
information for future material circulation. Combining material
stock and ﬂow analysis also helps identify resource conversation
potential, material in ﬂow, and out ﬂow ( Volk et al., 2019 ). However,
necessary policies are needed to facilitate such transition ( Luciano
et al., 2018 ).

Combining material
stock and ﬂow analysis also helps identify resource conversation
potential, material in ﬂow, and out ﬂow ( Volk et al., 2019 ). However,
necessary policies are needed to facilitate such transition ( Luciano
et al., 2018 ). Besides, material intensity database ( Marinova et al.,
2020 ), Material Composition Index, and calculation of the total
mass material ( Ortlepp et al., 2016 ) as well as a web-based “ma-
terial-component bank ”(Laddu Bhagya Jayasinghe and Daniele€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180
17

Waldmann, 2020 ) may help enhance the potential of urban mate-
rial stock towards circular cities. To estimate building stock,
Stephan and Athanassiadis (2017) utilized modeling a building ’s
geometry to use in material survey calculations while Deetman
et al. (2020) studied residential new buildings and demolished
buildings for the total ﬂoor space and building materials to estimate
the annual demand for construction material globally. When ma-
terials are deconstructed at the end of their service time, accu-
mulating within a material bank can play an important role in a
sustainable built environment ( Cai and Waldmann, 2019 ). The bank
can be further combined with energy and raw material factory to
increase resource ef ﬁciency ( van Leeuwen et al., 2018 ).
3.3.2.3. Deconstruction and reuse. Reusing structural elements has
great potential to reduce many environmental impacts including
embodied carbon release. However, the additional cost of reus-
ability, immature market demand, material traceability, and gaps
within the material supply are found to be barriers against struc-
tural steel reuse ( Densley Tingley et al., 2017 ). Such barriers needed
to be solved to reuse structural elements ( Hopkinson et al., 2019 ).To
overcome barriers against structural reuse, Densley Tingley et al.
(2017) offered some solutions such as creating a database to store
and access information of surrounding suppliers and materials to
be reused, market demand creation, education, and guidance on
material reuse and governmental in ﬂuence. Hopkinson et al. (2019)
added designing buildings for easy disassembly and new decon-
struction methods as critical to enabling structural element reuse.
When compared with traditional alternatives, reusable elements
showed a signi ﬁcantly lower environmental impact ( Iuorio et al.,
2019 ). Lastly, to ensure the implementation of recycled material
and design for disassembly principle in construction projects,
Serena Baiani and Paola Altamura (2019) investigated Green Public
Procurement (GPP) verifying the positive effect of GPP on achieving
sustainable results.
Similar to the structural elements, deconstructing and reusing
non-structural building elements can bring many environmental
beneﬁts. Among the different stages of the building lifecycle higher
environmental impacts can be observed in the renovation stage
compared to construction and end-of-life stages ( Hossain and
Thomas Ng, 2019 ).To simplify the deconstruction process of
buildings elements, Zabek et al. (2017) proposed a new approach
employing robotic disassembly. Further improving deconstruction
processes, Marzouk et al. (2019) developed a framework by
implementing BIM and Lean principles needing a system of design
for disassembly. If the deconstructed material is reused, then it is
considered an example of “upcycling ”which is investigated by Rose
et al. (2018) . However, to achieve the intended environmental
beneﬁt by material reuse, there may be a minimum number of
reusing to meet. As in the comparative study between reusable
steel and conventional timber, it is highlighted that the multiple
reuses of the steel-framed wall are needed to offset the additional
environmental impact ( Cruz Rios et al., 2019 ). To analyze the
reusability of building materials, Lukman Akanbi et al. (2018) pro-
posed a tool demonstrating different reusability values based on
different parts of the building. Ensuring the reusability of materials
in a resource-constrained economy, there is also a need for dura-
bility assessment of material and service life planning ( Bourke and
Kyle, 2019 ). For a component-speci ﬁc study, Nijgh and Veljkovic
(2019) considered a method to assess the structural response
from a composite beam under vibration which is produced with a
demountable shear connection.

Ensuring the reusability of materials
in a resource-constrained economy, there is also a need for dura-
bility assessment of material and service life planning ( Bourke and
Kyle, 2019 ). For a component-speci ﬁc study, Nijgh and Veljkovic
(2019) considered a method to assess the structural response
from a composite beam under vibration which is produced with a
demountable shear connection. Even though reusing may provide
environmental bene ﬁts (Zabek et al., 2017 ), component reuse is
affected by several factors such as stakeholder perception of the
risk of material reuse ( Rakhshan et al., 2020 ), recycling ef ﬁciency,
and transportation distance ( Gallego-Schmid et al., 2020 ).Among the triple dimensions of reduce, reuse, and recycle, it is
important to thoroughly research ways for the reduction in
resource usage since it requires less effort while signi ﬁcantly
beneﬁtting the environment and economy. Resource reduction on
the urban scale is studied by Kalmykova et al. (2016) indicating that
even though there have been several successful implementations
for fossil fuel consumption-related practices, policies, in general,
failed to provide a substantial reduction in resource usage. In the
only study concerned with machine remanufacturing in CBECE,
Xiao et al. (2018) concluded that remanufacturing the machine at
its regional dealers rather than its original factory is the best option
for environmental and economic bene ﬁts.
3.3.3. Waste
3.3.3.1. Recycle and reuse. Recycling in the literature mainly
focused on popular construction materials such as concrete, steel,
and road pavements. Recycling concrete waste reduced the overall
environmental impact when used as supplementary cementitious
material ( Moreno-Juez et al., 2020 ). Similarly, Puthussery et al.
(2017) veriﬁed that recycled aggregates, in general, showed
similar properties to natural aggregates making them suitablematerial for road construction. Moreover, the strength of the
recycled aggregate can be further improved by controlling crushing
parameters ( Coudray et al., 2017 ). Besides, the recycling of CDW
showed environmental bene ﬁts, noting the role of transportation
distances ( Cuenca-Moyano et al., 2018 ) as in the case of plaster-
board recycling which needed more transportation in addition to
the recycling process. However, plasterboard recycling is evaluated
as environmentally bene ﬁcial due to the prevention of land ﬁlling
(Jim/C19enez Rivero et al., 2016 ). An alternative to traditional recycling,
Drzyzga and Prieto (2018) proposed recycling plastic waste by
microbial communities to be integrated with mechanical recycling.
Despite the clear bene ﬁts of recycling, Chen et al. (2019) found
some barriers against recycling including lack of traceability of the
waste origin, insuf ﬁcient evaluation of recycled material properties,
limited ﬁeld of application, disconnected knowledge, etc. Among
the barriers, Gupta and Chaudhary (2020) analyzed legal barriers to
promote the utilization of sustainable cementitious material and
proposed a support tool for industry professionals.
By bridging the automobile and construction industries, Ali et al.
(2019) tried to turn the waste of automobile sheet metal into a
façade system. Similarly, end-of-life vehicles from the automotive
industry can be also used in the construction industry via recycling
(Wong et al., 2018 ).Wang et al. (2020) proposed a model to help to
predict the supply and demand of tire waste and offered recycling
of crumb rubber for asphalt construction. Based on the satisfactory
results of the bio-recycled asphalt mixture performance, Blanc et al.
(2019) found that the existing practice needs to be further studied
with biomaterials to replace petroleum-based products. Addition-
ally,ﬁbers obtained from municipal waste, tires, etc. are studied by
Merli et al. (2020) for reinforced concrete made with recycled ﬁ-
bers. Other examples of waste recycling included a vitri ﬁcation
experiment on the bottom ash of municipal solid waste ( Stabile
et al., 2019 ) and high-calcium ﬂy ash treatment with mineral
carbonation to obtain economic and environmental bene ﬁts (/C19Cwik
et al., 2019 ).

are studied by
Merli et al. (2020) for reinforced concrete made with recycled ﬁ-
bers. Other examples of waste recycling included a vitri ﬁcation
experiment on the bottom ash of municipal solid waste ( Stabile
et al., 2019 ) and high-calcium ﬂy ash treatment with mineral
carbonation to obtain economic and environmental bene ﬁts (/C19Cwik
et al., 2019 ).
3.3.3.2. Waste valorization. Attributable to the large quantity and
necessity of immediate disposal, slags became a popular subject of
waste valorization. Zhu et al. (2013) studied steel slag ’s cementi-
tious properties to verify its use as cementitious material to be used
as part of a concrete admixture. Studies regarding air-cooled slag
(Tripathy et al., 2020 ), steel slag ( Parron-Rubio et al., 2019 ;Shu-
Yuan Pan et al., 2017 ), Electric Arc Furnace Dust (EAFD) ( Lozano-
Lunar et al., 2019 ), and lead slag ( /C20Stulovi /C19c et al., 2019 ) proved€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180
18

their suitability to substitute construction materials including
cement related ones. Cifrian et al. (2019) on the other hand, used
EAFD to optimize ceramic production. The feasibility of using EAFD
as secondary material for mortar production is veri ﬁed by Lozano-
Lunar et al. (2018) . Similar to steel slag, ﬂy ash obtained from
different processes is investigated through several studies for waste
valorization practices. Sas et al. (2019) found that ground-
granulated furnace slag had a positive effect on the radiological
properties of the alkali-activated material. Also, a certain amount of
ﬂy ash can suitably replace calcite with some possible concerns due
to the deterioration when ﬂy ash was used as a replacement
(Modolo et al., 2017 ). Fly ash with other industrial waste such as
river sand, silica fume, or dolomitic waste can signi ﬁcantly improve
the material characteristics of ﬂy ash bricks ( Aneke and Awuzie,
2018 ). Using ﬂy-ash in different amounts within the mixture of
ready mix concrete also resulted in performance improvement
(Carla Costa and Jos /C19e Carlos Marques, 2018 ). Another waste com-
bination in a ternary blended binder of metakaolin, biomass ﬂy ash,
and lime hydrate proved to meet the required technical standards
of mortar ( Pavlíkov /C19a et al., 2019 ).Saeli et al. (2019a) studied the
recycling of lime slaker grit and biomass ﬂy ash to use as aggregate
in a green mortar made with geopolymers. Further extending this
research, Saeli et al. (2019b) investigated the performance of geo-
polymeric binders when produced with ﬂy ash and alkaline ef ﬂuent
to ensure required compressive strength and workability.
A number of mining activities around the world draw attention
to quarry waste for valorization purposes. Construction, road, and
railroad construction are the most preferred applications for min-
ing waste obtained from rock raw materials ( Ka/C19zmierczak et al.,
2019 ). Mining waste was reviewed for its waste valorization prac-
tices ( Boltakova et al., 2017 ) and technical feasibility to be used as a
replacement material for pavement production ( Zhang et al., 2019 ).
Mine tailings can be combined with other wastes such as furnace
slag and metakaolin in the production of a geopolymer binder to be
used as ﬁne aggregate ( Helena Paiva et al., 2019 ). Processing quarry
waste by using hydroclones to make it suitable for the material
production showed no signi ﬁcant performance decrease
(Men /C19endez-Aguado L.D. et al., 2019 ). Not only ﬁne quarry waste but
also slate quarry sludge showed a feasible alternative to be used as
supplementary material of cement ( S/C19aez del Bosque et al., 2018 ).
Due to a large number of industrial and urban activities, sewage
sludge ( Smol et al., 2015 ), plastic, textile waste, and some other
industrial waste are studied to produce sustainable construction
materials. Palmieri et al. (2019) investigated cellulose materials
found in sewage sludge to improve binder-based construction. As
an additive material for construction, slag obtained from municipal
solid waste meets the quality requirement to substitute cement
(Czop and Ła/C19zniewska-Piekarczyk, 2020 ). In addition to the studies
concerning industrial and municipal sewage, Lambert and Randall
(2019) studied human urine used as bio-cement for brick produc-
tion by implementing the process of microbial-induced calcium
carbonate precipitation. The study provided experiments demon-
strating that the suggested bio-brick met the required compression
strength performance hence offering an alternative to conventional
bricks. However, different sewage treatment processes are needed
to be used since the quality requirement for recycled material mayvary in different applications ( Verbinnen et al., 2016 ). With some
compromise on the mechanical properties, adding plastic waste in
brick production increases thermal performance ( Mondal et al.,
2019 ) as well as reducing material treatment costs for brick pro-
duction ( Limami et al., 2019 ). Further, Díaz-García et al.

However, different sewage treatment processes are needed
to be used since the quality requirement for recycled material mayvary in different applications ( Verbinnen et al., 2016 ). With some
compromise on the mechanical properties, adding plastic waste in
brick production increases thermal performance ( Mondal et al.,
2019 ) as well as reducing material treatment costs for brick pro-
duction ( Limami et al., 2019 ). Further, Díaz-García et al. (2017)
investigated the residue obtained from olive oil extracting to pro-
duce a ceramic paste and found the improved thermal performance
of the material. Another bio-composite material, leather waste is
studied by Z/C21ainescu et al. (2018) for the material performanceimprovement of paving blocks. To improve a building ’s energy ef-
ﬁciency, waste materials such as textile ﬁbers, ﬂy ash, or rubber
waste can be also utilized by recycling ( Tallini and Cedola, 2018 ).
Other waste valorization studies, via replacing existing mate-
rials or reducing the need for raw material with positive results,
included the use of dredged material for creating new land in
Sweden ’s Gale Port project ( Carpenter et al., 2018 ), production of
self-compacting concrete using ﬁller recovered from hot-mix
asphalt plant ( Esquinas et al., 2018 ), construction of low-traf ﬁc
roads with colliery spoils used as a sub-base layer ( Suescum-
Morales et al., 2019 ), lightweight concrete production with
expanded polystyrene waste ( Bedekovi /C19c et al., 2019 ), arti ﬁcial stone
production from oyster shell waste used as tabletops ( H. Silva et al.,
2019 ), brick production by different types of industrial waste
(Migliore et al., 2018 ) and by waste brick within green recycling
process ( Li et al., 2020
), manufacturing to stabilize bentonite-based
concrete for road construction by use of phosphogypsum waste
(Safae Oumnih et al., 2019 ) which indicated mechanical strength
improvement after using phosphogypsum waste. In addition to
those studies of brick production with waste material, Martínez-
Martínez et al. (2020) investigated waste from ceramic and
marble industries for the design of new cement clinkers. Instead of
traditional composting of waste from the pruning or removal of
trees as part of urban afforestation, Cyntia Malaguti de Sousa (2019)
offered alternative use of wooden artifacts. Material features of the
residues generated within the agriculture industry are generally
suitable for thermal and acoustic insulation applications ( Ricciardi
et al., 2020 ).
3.3.3.3. Construction and demolition waste. Under the CE approach,
construction and demolition waste (CDW) are seen as resources
that are needed for societal development in both economic and
social dimensions ( Blengini et al., 2017 ) providing economic and
environmental bene ﬁts (Ghisellini et al., 2018b ).G/C19alvez-Martos
et al. (2018) studied the best practices of CDW to synthesize core
principles for waste reduction. In a comparative study, Aslam et al.
(2020) argued that the USA has advanced more in terms of the CDW
management system compared to China. Another comparative
study of Brazil, the European Union, and the USA stated that per-
formance in CDW management of Brazil is lower than both the USA
and EU ( Nunes and Mahler, 2020 ). Along with different approaches,
CDW management practices also varied in developed and devel-
oping countries ( Jin et al., 2019 ) and were in ﬂuenced by population,
urbanization, GDP, CDW policies, and standards ( Aslam et al., 2020 ).
Promoting CE in CDW, Mihai (2019) identi ﬁedﬁve main stages of
CDW management, starting from illegal land ﬁlling and ending with
material recycling. Nevertheless, CDW management is not fully
employed due to the economic and legal barriers owing to the
proﬁt-driven and change-resistant nature of the construction in-
dustry ( Ghisellini et al., 2018a ).

Promoting CE in CDW, Mihai (2019) identi ﬁedﬁve main stages of
CDW management, starting from illegal land ﬁlling and ending with
material recycling. Nevertheless, CDW management is not fully
employed due to the economic and legal barriers owing to the
proﬁt-driven and change-resistant nature of the construction in-
dustry ( Ghisellini et al., 2018a ).
Barriers against CDW utilization included; insuf ﬁcient design
standards, low cost of waste disposal over recycling, improper city
planning, the immature market for recycled waste, lack of CDW
processing ( Huang et al., 2018 ), lack of performance measurements,
human factors, and integration with technological advancements
(Jin et al., 2019 ). Ineffective CDW management, transportation is-
sues, CDW ownership, and uncertainty after implementing CDW
are considered high priority barriers to CE in CDW ( Mahpour, 2018 ).
However, Blengini et al. (2017) argued that even though some
challenges exist, CDW may still be incorporated through a sus-
tainable supply mix. Other factors to overcome CDW barriers
included of ﬁcial policies and regulations ( Ghisellini et al., 2018a ),
smart deconstruction, government incentives, the collaboration of
key stakeholders and improving the material quality of CDW(Ghaffar et al., 2020 ), recycled product certi ﬁcation, and advancing€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180
19

recycling technologies ( Bao and Lu, 2020 ). Within the context of
public-private partnership (PPP) projects, Bao et al. (2019) argued
that the use of relational contracts, protection of both parties ’in-
terests, and transparent information exchange are key to enhancing
CDW procurement. However, it is still necessary to evaluate risk
assessments when recycled aggregate is used ( L/C19opez-Uceda et al.,
2018 ).
In order to reduce CDW, several studies focused on its causes.
Some of the most important factors causing CDW included built
environment development ( Noll et al., 2019 ) and design changes
while lacking coordination between stakeholders is considered the
least important factor causing waste ( Siew Renard, 2019 ). To
minimize CDW, Esa et al. (2017) applied the ReSOLVE framework to
the Malaysian construction industry. Once CDW is generated, the
recycling of CDW becomes an important stage. In this regard, Liu
et al. (2017) studied the behavior of construction workers on
reducing construction waste and found feelings of usefulness,
compatibility, responsibility, ﬁnancial incentives ( Jain et al., 2020 ),
self-ef ﬁcacy, and facility conditions as signi ﬁcant factors towards
minimizing waste. Within a construction team, foremen showed a
relatively negative attitude compared with installers for commit-ment to waste management ( Ana Jim /C19enez-Rivero et al., 2017 ).
Investigating contractors ’behavior showed that economic viability
had the strongest effect on contractors ’behavior, closely followed
by government control ( Wu et al., 2017 ).
Improving the recycling process and quality of CDW are studied
focusing on different aspects of CDW. Esa et al. (2017) developed a
six-loop diagram based on the system ’s dynamics of the industry to
improve the recycling rate of CDW emphasizing the importance of
the design phase of a project. CDW can be used for mix design of
structural concrete ( Cantero et al., 2019 ), in road and building
construction ( R.V. Silva et al., 2019 ) and for concrete production
(Smical et al., 2015 ), resulting in important environmental and
economic bene ﬁts. Cost reduction for recycling is possible by
improving the CDW separation process ( Ambr /C19os et al., 2017 ).
However for the new kind of waste material such as waste glass
from solar panels, Drochytka et al. (2020) argues that European
Commission ’s goals are not clear in terms of recycling, even though
the waste glass is considered a suitable CDW for its next uses.
3.3.3.4. Waste management. Several researches studied the per-
formance of varied materials for effective waste management
practices. Five key stages of waste management included installa-
tion, storing, waste segregation on-site, waste transfer, and storage
at the ﬁ
nal destination ( Ana Jim /C19enez-Rivero et al., 2017 ). Addi-
tionally, two driving factors for the CE adoption indicated waste
management and reuse of secondary materials ( L/C19opez Ruiz et al.,
2020 ). Another study of best practices on waste management
concluded three best practices: on-site waste segregation, clear
acceptance criteria of waste, and quality criteria for recycled ma-
terial ( Jim/C19enez-Rivero and García-Navarro, 2017 ). Material recy-
cling may require additional steps and sometimes pre-recycling
treatment and a new logistics route ( Heller and Flamme, 2020 ).
Therefore, additional tools developed to be used in waste man-
agement included a waste input-output accounting to investigate
waste ﬂow and information ( Zeller et al., 2019 ), a model to deal
with illegal waste dumping to help waste minimization ( Santos
et al., 2019 ), and a tool for analyzing waste by using a prediction
model ( Akinade and Oyedele, 2019 ).
3.3.4. Building and infrastructure
Adaptive reuse of buildings not only provide environmental
beneﬁts but also economic bene ﬁts e.g. a decrease in the overall
building cost throughout the building lifecycle ( Sanchez et al.,
2019 ), and social bene ﬁts e.g. creating a sharing economy to helpthe homelessness problem ( Renato Morganti et al., 2019 ).

3.3.4. Building and infrastructure
Adaptive reuse of buildings not only provide environmental
beneﬁts but also economic bene ﬁts e.g. a decrease in the overall
building cost throughout the building lifecycle ( Sanchez et al.,
2019 ), and social bene ﬁts e.g. creating a sharing economy to helpthe homelessness problem ( Renato Morganti et al., 2019 ). Despite
the growing demand for resource usage due to the increased
comfort, buildings in the future are expected to be energy ef ﬁcient
and constructed with more natural material ( Cret¸ u et al., 2019 ). At
the intersection of both relational and intrinsic properties (building
use, material, and building design) building circularity can be
achieved ( Geldermans, 2016 ). The circular building design also
concerns the residential well-being and health bene ﬁts including
the indoor air quality ( Bob Geldermans et al., 2019b ). In addition to
the health bene ﬁts, buildings that can quickly adapt to changing
structural forms bring us ﬂexible, modular buildings that provide
environmental bene ﬁts (Mignacca et al., 2020 ). Such ﬂexible and
modular buildings can also help meet the changing housing de-
mand over time caused by the population movement, and change
in urban settings ( Zairul et al., 2018 ) and reduce carbon emission
which can be veri ﬁed by BIM ( Hao et al., 2020 ). Based on the
ﬂexible nature of prefabrication combined with CE principles,
seven CE strategies are determined as waste reduction, using by-
products, reusing replacement parts, adaptive use of components,
designing for disassembly, material recyclability, and material
tracking ( Minunno et al., 2018 ). Relocating buildings from one
location to another not only provides easy and fast installation with
low risk of leasing but also ﬂexibility in adding/removing modules
when needed ( Kyr€o et al., 2019 ). Rural areas can also bene ﬁt from a
ﬂexible approach ( Babenko et al., 2019 ) in which the combination
of building and bio-agricultural technologies may provide afford-
able housing solutions. However, the feature of adaptive reuse
might cause an increase in overall complexity which can be iden-
tiﬁed as interface problems against adaptive reuse ( Ekin Eray et al.,
2019 ) and buildings lifespan can be shortened by non-technical
reasons such as social or cultural factors as in Japanese buildings
(Wuyts et al., 2019 ).
Unlike modern buildings or affordable housing solutions, his-
torical or heritage buildings may become a challenging issue when
deciding among different alternatives for adaptive reuse. In a study
about adaptive reuse of a building formerly used as a monastery,
the anti-violence center for women was found to be the best reuse
alternative ( Francesca Torrieri et al., 2019 ). Another study of cul-
tural buildings found that the extension of the building ’s service life
to reduce the environmental impact of the building is possible by
the utilization of earth-concrete, ﬂax, reed, and straw ( Foster,
2020 ). Despite the suitability of earth construction on many occa-
sions, an environmental permit may still be needed since earth
construction is not commonly regulated ( P€oyki €o et al., 2019 ).
Reusing a building over constructing a new one requires a decision-
making process. Therefore, Fregonara et al. (2017) developed a
decision-making method based on a combination of economic and
environmental factors used during the design phase for building a
new building or retro ﬁtting an existing building. Additionally, for
decisions on capital projects between the alternative of reusing or
constructing a new one, the pre-project planning phase becomes
important to sustain a successful closed-loop cycle ( Sanchez and
Haas, 2018a ).
When aiming for circular buildings, designing buildings for ease
of deconstruction is one of the earliest actions to take. To quantify
the environmental bene ﬁts of deconstructability, Eberhardt et al.
(2019) proposed a lifecycle assessment in which the structural
components are designed for disassembly.

When aiming for circular buildings, designing buildings for ease
of deconstruction is one of the earliest actions to take. To quantify
the environmental bene ﬁts of deconstructability, Eberhardt et al.
(2019) proposed a lifecycle assessment in which the structural
components are designed for disassembly. To reduce the additional
cost of deconstruction, planning methods can help with ﬁnding the
optimal deconstruction sequence of a building by storing the in-
formation regarding deconstruction via utilizing BIM ( Sanchez and
Haas, 2018b ). Further advancing in design software, analyzing the
disassembly performance of a building at the end of its life can now
provide valuable information in the early design stage ( Akanbi
et al., 2019 ). Optimizing the deconstruction process based on€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180
20

project constraints and strategies is also possible by employing
multi-objective optimization analysis based on economic, envi-
ronmental, and physical constraints ( Sanchez et al., 2020 ).
Maintaining sustainability within buildings and infrastructure
concerning CE has been examined in a limited number of studies.
Despite the common use of the terms of sustainability and CE,
Anastasiades et al. (2020) clariﬁed sustainability as the ultimate
goal while CE is a means to achieve that ultimate goal. To achieve
sustainable buildings, new business models in CE and the inte-
gration of key stakeholders with the construction value chain are
essential ( Munaro et al., 2020 ) since the main industries of CO 2
generation are found to be concrete manufacturing, power gener-
ation, distribution, and production of the lighting ﬁxture ( N.
Muhammad Aslaam Mohamed Abdul Ghani et al., 2017 ). Among
different types of buildings, it is recommended for future studies to
be directed towards non-residential buildings as their CO 2emission
is found to be higher than residential buildings ( Hossain and Ng,
2018 ). In a more speci ﬁc case, Ueda et al. (2019 ) found that there
is a negative correlation between the size of the Micro hydropowers
installation and the environmental burden it causes. As part of
sustainability in power generation, Li (2017) proposed natural gas
as the main fuel for power generation. To evaluate such efforts for
building sustainability, appraisal standards are needed. However,
scores in appraisal standards can be disproportionate to their life
cycle impact ( Saheed O. Ajayi et al., 2019 ) or lacking consideration
of the complexity and diverse stakeholders of the built environ-
ment ( Pomponi and Moncaster, 2019 ).
3.3.5. Areas
Industrial parks with their magnitude and cohesive structure
play an important role in the CE transition. They may also
contribute to investigating the decoupling relationship between
GDP and the environmental impacts ( Bai et al., 2014 ). When con-
structing industrial parks; multi-project management theory can
be utilized to consider areas for production, accommodation, and
planning goals ( Liming Xiao et al., 2017 ) along with the policies and
best practices ( Wen et al., 2018 ). At regional level CE imple-
mentation, cluster structurization can be considered as a necessary
base for policy implementation ( Оliynyk О.V. and Serhiyenko L.V.,
2018 ). However, the development of industrial parks is depen-
dent on many factors. Such as when Liu et al. (2018) explored the
effect of country development level on the economic development
of industrial parks from developing and developed countries, the
study found that industrial park development in China is mainly
driven by a top-down approach whereas in Canada the government
and market act together as a common driving force. Therefore, for
an effective campus development under CE, the complexity of
development should be reduced along with ensuring consistent
policy, stakeholder support, establishing speci ﬁc and solid objec-
tives, clarifying circularity, and making it accessible and under-
standable ( Hopff et al., 2019 ). Combining CE principles with
industrial park construction can help as a planning guide for cir-
cular park development ( Jia Ruan and Wan Na, 2017 ).
Evaluating an industrial parks ’level of CE implementation is
mainly studied from an environmental aspect. However, a
comprehensive evaluation is proposed by Zhao et al. (2018) based
on environmental, social, and economic bene ﬁt criteria to decide
the optimal eco-industrial park among ﬁve candidates. Some of the
evaluation systems included an evaluation index system for the
marine economy ( Lu, 2014 ), performance evaluation of an agri-
cultural industrial park ( Lulu Yang et al., 2017 ), environmental
performance evaluation of an eco-industrial park with different
perceptions ranging from administrators to companies and habi-
tants ( Yang Yao et al., 2014 ). Additionally, Liu et al. (2020) devel-
oped a sustainability evaluation system and energy decouplingindex to assess the sustainability of a coal mining area. To reduce
emission by a coal-fuelled power industrial park, Wang et al. (2019)
proposed an emission reduction matrix for carbon footprints and
estimates. Zhao et al.

Additionally, Liu et al. (2020) devel-
oped a sustainability evaluation system and energy decouplingindex to assess the sustainability of a coal mining area. To reduce
emission by a coal-fuelled power industrial park, Wang et al. (2019)
proposed an emission reduction matrix for carbon footprints and
estimates. Zhao et al. (2017) tried to bring together economic, so-
cial, environmental bene ﬁt criteria, ecology industry construction
criteria, and management level criteria to develop a CE evaluation
framework for the bene ﬁts of eco-industrial parks. Finally,
Santagata et al. (2020) developed a new method using EMA
(emergy accounting method) to identify the improvement resulting
from CE implementation to reduce total emergy.
3.3.6. Cities and regions
Developing a circular city may require frameworks and models
to interpret the CE principles into actionable items. Pomponi and
Moncaster (2017) explored CE dimensions and their relation to
the built environment to frame the fundamental dimensions of CE.
Strategic implementation areas of CE are included in the built
environment, energy, mobility, waste and water management, in-
dustrial production, agri-food, public, and society ( Gravagnuolo
et al., 2019 ). By simulating the system tendencies it is possible to
reduce building operation costs, improve the enterprise income,and promote a CE transition ( He, 2018 ). By further combining
system dynamics with material ﬂow analysis, it is found that the
most effective CE is achieved when the birthrate is reduced by 2%
and the growth rate of tertiary industry increased by 2% ( Gao et al.,
2020 ). In order to facilitate CE transition at an urban level, the
environmental issues resulting from company operations should be
taken into account and city-wide data should be collected from
smart data processing ( Edi Valpreda et al., 2018 ). After exploring
how CE is understood in cities from a sociotechnical standpoint, it is
suggested that future research should pay attention to the knowl-
edge production process about CE imaginaries and urban transition
(Fratini et al., 2019 ). Under the new urban planning theory in CE,
distributed energy systems with shared electric vehicles become
vital ( Liaros, 2019 ) while ﬁnancing plays an important role in CE
implementation, along with regulations, policies, and socio-
economic factors ( Silvestri et al., 2020 ). In this regard, the green
tax policy ( Sun, 2013 ) and interdisciplinary collaboration ( Lica,
2019 ) can play a signi ﬁcant role in expediting the CE transition at
a city level.
Throughout the CE transformation of cities, the evaluation of CE
levels and impacts must be analyzed. Resource consumption,
environmental impact, recycling, and social development can be
used to measure the level of CE development at a regional scale
(Guo-gang, 2011 ).Chang et al. (2017) combined aspects of the
environment, resource, society, and economy under a sustainable
development index to quantify sustainable city development. A
longer period of performance evaluation proved that CE is bene ﬁ-
cial in many ways including ecology, economy, and resource ef ﬁ-
ciency ( Cheng et al., 2019 ). CE-based eco-city may also provide
beneﬁts for sustainable development ( Du, 2016 ). For urban level CE
development, there is a relationship between the evaluation index,
urban types, and economic development ( Wang et al., 2018 ).
Another relation between economic structure and smog control putforward by Zhong (2019) concluding that replacing traditional
industrialization with CE industrialization can help control smog
levels. However, there might be a risk that CE may be responsible
for transforming industrial areas into circular residential andcommercial spaces which con ﬂicts with the principle of CE for
internalizing waste recycling ( Van den Berghe and Vos, 2019 ).
Urban development is rapidly growing ( Min Pang, 2017 ) and
urban planning needs to break down high scale CE principles into
performable actions ( Bolger and Doyon, 2019 ). It also needs inte-
gration of built environment in CE ( van der Leer et al., 2018 ),
embracing smart growth to sustain effective economic€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180
21

development ( Huang et al., 2015 ) and a comprehensive rethinking
such as space centralization, organizing bicycle lane, forestry zone,
and road infrastructure. In this regard, a “harmonic society ”is
proposed as a criteria to be considered for regional planning ( Liu
et al., 2012 ). Further, there may be a positive relationship be-
tween urbanization and GDP per capita and inverted the U relation
between urbanization and solid waste per capita ( Zhang et al.,
2008 ). Even though urban-wide zero waste is a commonly
referred phenomenon, Pelorosso et al. (2017) argue that zero waste
growth is impossible due to the thermodynamics law which calls
low-entropy city principles an achievable goal. Urban planning and
improving the ecological construction may call for government
leadership, education of environmental protection, management
improvement of ecological environment, legislative amendments,
investments for environmental protection, and structuring regu-
lators ( Zhang, 2014 ). To further transform city-wide CE, Hilde
Remøy et al. (2019) suggested embracing a multi-faceted gover-
nance approach, developing living labs and integrating main
stakeholders, gathering lessons learned, proposing a circular design
approach integrated with stakeholders, geo-design approach,
technology, and system thinking.
4. Discussion
As with most studies, this study is subject to some limitations.
Literature synthesis conducted in section 3.3is primarily based on
the author ’s interpretation. Additionally, the scope of this study is
limited to the domains of construction and built environment only
in relation to CE. This paper included the studies obtained by the
systematic literature review with a prede ﬁned set of criteria con-
ducted on an academic database. As explained in section 2, in order
to distinguish the CE domain from former studies related to the
broad ﬁeld of sustainability, this study focuses on the studies
containing the term CE within any of their title, abstract, or
keyword ﬁelds. Even though such screening method may not
capture the entire relevant literature and possesses the risk of
resulting in fewer studies than are available, it is still needed to
provide the replicable nature of a study example and set the bor-
ders of the study scope for which CE is considered a standalone
domain. Studies concerning broader topics of sustainability or
waste recycling of individual manufacturing industries are
excluded to maintain the boundary of the study. However,
manufacturing industries that are directly linked to the construc-
tion materials under CE principles are included in the study scope
since they base the material level of the built environment.
Based on the results from section 3.1and themes that emerge in
section 3.3, it is evident that academic attention to CBECE is not
adequately established. A signi ﬁcant part of the literature is con-
ducted in China and published by the Journal of Cleaner Production.
However, there has been exponential growth and diversi ﬁcation of
CE subjects in the last four years, favoring CE as a sustainable and
inevitable economic model. Furthermore, the body of CBECE liter-
ature is fragmented and spread in diverse ﬁelds with a limited
number of studies in the evolving nature of previous studies.
In reﬂecting on the new understanding of CE, slag valorization
caught high academic attention, possibly due to its large avail-
ability, economic value, and fast adoption by the construction in-
dustry when utilized. Additionally, mining waste and sewage
sludge waste are now seen as circular replacement alternatives to
conventional materials or as an additive. Under CE, organic waste
can be valorized as a bio-composite material and it is also possible
to introduce biomaterials to replace petroleum-based products.
Although some studies highlight the need for collaboration as a
vital component in CBECE, the literature lacks sound evidence andclear instruction to form such collaboration within the complexnature of the construction industry. Similarly, due to the opportu-
nities offered by cross-sectoral waste valorization, industrial sym-
biosis caught academic attention. However, not only does CBECE
lack a platform to facilitate industrial symbiosis and waste recy-
cling, such interaction within different sectors may increase the
complexity from which construction already suffers which may
affect the CE purpose of narrowing the material loop and
boundaries.
Despite the priority of resource reduction over recycling in CE
principles, it is noted that the literature did not develop in line with
such prioritization.

However, not only does CBECE
lack a platform to facilitate industrial symbiosis and waste recy-
cling, such interaction within different sectors may increase the
complexity from which construction already suffers which may
affect the CE purpose of narrowing the material loop and
boundaries.
Despite the priority of resource reduction over recycling in CE
principles, it is noted that the literature did not develop in line with
such prioritization. Instead, several studies were found on waste
valorization and recycling, but little research was found on resource
reduction. Studies on recycling with a focus on CDW and aggregates
demonstrated economic and environmental bene ﬁts but CDW
management is not fully developed due to the pro ﬁt-driven and
change-resistant nature of the construction industry. Even though
reusable components can reduce the environmental impact, com-
posite technology studies within CBECE focused primarily on
extending durability, quality, and cost reduction rather than
deconstructing or valorizing parts for the next use.
The environmental impact of buildings can be reduced by
different design alternatives while its material and components ’
sustainability can be enhanced by smart technologies and products
as service. Buildings embracing CE, as in cases of modular and
ﬂexible buildings, can also help ﬂuctuating housing demand over
time caused by population movement. Additionally, the adaptive
reuse of a building provides environmental bene ﬁts and decreases
the overall building lifecycle cost. In this regard, BIM is an effective
tool for estimating carbon emission of construction as well as
verifying the reduction of carbon emission by prefabrication. By
further utilizing BIM and employing a multi-objective optimization
analysis based on economic, environmental, and physical con-
straints, it is possible to optimize the deconstruction process based
on project constraints and strategies. Evaluating building perfor-
mance under CE may bring some additional challenges due to the
extended stages of a building ’s lifecycle, starting from the feasibility
phase to the end of life. For instance, when a building is described
as economic under CE, it is not clear to which phase of the build-
ing ’s lifecycle or to which stakeholder it is referred. Due to differ-
ences in expectations and con ﬂicting interests from one
stakeholder to another, it is dif ﬁcult to make project performance
evaluations that satisfy the expectations of all stakeholders.
Although there have been studies focusing on building scale in
the design stage, no study found a circular area scale in the design
stage other than a few studies concerned with high-level planning
aspects with CE principles. However, the literature included a few
studies acknowledging the importance of the design phase where
CE principles can be introduced with maximum potential. The
reason for the lack of studies regarding the design phase might be
due to the short-term and pro ﬁt-driven nature of the construction
industry which may perceive a building project as expensive or
require a longer time to build when designing under CE principles
such as design for deconstruction, modularity, use of recycled
material, etc. Although the Design stage has not ful ﬁlled its po-
tential under CE this may change soon as the construction industry
transforms and embraces CE principles. Additionally, areas that aredesigned with CE principles need more attention as they hold
signiﬁcant potential for expediting CE transformation in CBE. On a
greater scale, city-wide circularity required local material supply,
minimized, and clean transportation.
Studies in CBECE generally lack consideration of the diversity of
stakeholder type, interest, and motivation. Studies, speci ﬁcally
LCA-related, may need to consider the in ﬂuence of multiple
stakeholders on different lifecycle stages. Among those stake-
holders, it is noticed that the behavior of construction workers on€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180
22

reducing construction waste is driven by the feeling of usefulness,
compatibility, responsibility, ﬁnancial incentives, self-ef ﬁcacy, and
facility conditions which can be observed when considering the
behavior of other stakeholders. Another key stakeholder of owners
may need to be included when considering the ownership chal-
lenge as required by new business models in CE. However, the
ownership issue within CBECE still poses an unanswered challenge
in terms of who will hold the responsibility of material circularity at
the end of its lifetime. Finally, in addition to the environmental and
economic aspects, users of the buildings and infrastructure can see
potential bene ﬁts and effects of CE on their personal health through
studies concerned with health effects and improving ef ﬁciency in
public services via integration of sharing economy.
4.1. Proposals and future research agenda
Based on the literature review, the following is proposed for
future research to contribute to CBECE literature:
/C15After reviewing CBECE, an 11th “R”principle of CE “Replace ”is
proposed.
/C15The literature contains studies employing various life cycle
assessment approaches for impact assessment. Given the nature
of construction projects, it is necessary to acknowledge that
there are separate and distinct project phases under the in ﬂu-
ence of various key stakeholders and stage owners (investor at
feasibility stage, architect at the design stage, etc.) with different
interests (not only greenhouse gas emission but additional as-
pects such as initial cost, operation cost, recycling/reusing cost,
reusability rate, water usage, energy consumption, renewable
energy usage ratio, soil movement ratio, etc.), motives and ex-
pectations from the project.
/C15The complexity of diverse project stakeholders, along with
conﬂicting interests, may require a unique framework for CE to
act as a transparent platform to be communicated through.
/C15The traditional understanding of the project-product-delivery
cycle of a construction project can be improved as a project-
product-delivery-project cycle in line with a closed-loop of CE
which would essentially provide a complete after-life project
focusing on reusing or recycling the material once the service
life ends.
/C15Existing CE can be further enhanced by a Dynamic Circular
Economy approach due to the variety of built environment
scales and construction stages which would imply adaptive
solutions based on the scale and stages of CBE. Factory con-
struction in a highly central industrial area may require different
prioritization of CE principles compared to a housing unit in a
remote area with logistics challenges. For the ﬁrst case, the
deconstructability of components may be more important than
implementing biodegradable material during the construction
which might be a feasible alternative for the second case.
/C15To sustain material ownership and responsibility, ﬁnancial or-
ganizations including banks and public entities can be consid-
ered part of a national resource bank that would enable materialleasing to the developers, and leasing can be encouraged over
property ownership by communicating its bene ﬁts.
/C15As seen in the reviewed literature, top-down approaches by the
government to force organizations to embrace CBECE may not
be suf ﬁcient to achieve CE. Studies focusing on bottom-up ap-
proaches that analyze CE bene ﬁts for key stakeholders are
necessary so that collaboration among the stakeholders can be
developed naturally.
/C15Policies that are aimed to promote CE in CBE via regulations and
ﬁnancial incentives can be further investigated under the
interaction of cross-sectoral waste policies./C15
To help develop bottom-up approaches, short-term CE bene ﬁts
are needed to be investigated. Although environmental bene ﬁts
have a positive impact on overall public health, individuals
(decision-makers or buyers in construction projects) may need
to see instant, clear and direct bene ﬁts to human health that can
be further investigated.
/C15Studies focusing on the shift from permanent ownership to
temporary usage may improve the social and psychological di-
mensions of the CE. This topic is also related to sharing economy
which can bring additional perspectives to the subject.
/C15CBECE can bene ﬁt from investigating smart material and
blockchain technology to help improve material management
and material ownership issues.
5. Conclusion
This study provides a comprehensive literature review of CBECE
based on a systematic literature review of 238 papers with three
primary goals: demonstrating literature development trends,
investigating literature state and gaps, and critically reviewing
literature ﬁndings while proposing future research ideas.

/C15CBECE can bene ﬁt from investigating smart material and
blockchain technology to help improve material management
and material ownership issues.
5. Conclusion
This study provides a comprehensive literature review of CBECE
based on a systematic literature review of 238 papers with three
primary goals: demonstrating literature development trends,
investigating literature state and gaps, and critically reviewing
literature ﬁndings while proposing future research ideas. The study
concluded that CBECE is still at an early stage with increasing ac-
ademic attention and diversity in recent years. With China as the
leading country and Journal of Cleaner Production as the leading
journal, the literature of CBECE shows a fragmented body of
knowledge in disperse ﬁelds with a limited number of studies in an
evolutionary manner of previous studies.
This study debuts a matrix shape review framework that brings
built environment scales and construction stages together while
combining CE subjects to quickly evaluate the maturity and
understudied ﬁelds of CBECE. In line with construction being a
material intense sector, the three-tier framework of Stage- Scale-
Subject showed that the “Material ”scale in “Manufacturing ”and
“Construction ”stages have gained the most academic attention
thus far. However, no study was found for the “Area ”scale in
“Design ”and “End of life ”stages which could provide a valuable
contribution to CBECE when considering the importance of the
design stage on the built environment circularity. Likewise, a
limited number of studies were found in “Building ”and “City ”
levels in the “Manufacturing ”stage and “Area ”level in the “Plan-
ning ”stage proving the need for more academic attention to
facilitate area and city level CE transition. While developing the
three-tier framework, it is noticed that some studies were primarily
interested in offering a mere sustainable replacement alternative to
the conventional construction material to lower the environmental
impacts. As a result, this study proposed the “Replace ”principle to
be added to the existing “R”principles of CE.
Although improving collaboration among the stakeholders to
facilitate CE in CBE is addressed in several studies, the construction
industry still lacks the needed platforms to establish such collab-
oration. Moreover, the necessary market mechanism to contribute
material circularity or manage the increased complexity of the
construction when interacting with cross sectors is still needed. In
this complex and pro ﬁt-driven industry, construction companies
may have to embrace CE sooner than expected to maintain their
economic growth which is steadily progressing as a phenomenon
that cannot be thought of separately from environmental sustain-
ability. However, among all policies and measures to expedite CE
transformation, ﬁnancial subsidies are still the most important
driving factor, both at the corporate and individual levels in the
construction industry.
With the emerging understanding in CE, raw material and waste
are now considered equally important resources for both new
construction and renovation. While composite materials are
investigated from the points of durability enhancement and€O. Çimen Journal of Cleaner Production 305 (2021) 127180
23

environmental impact minimization, alternative materials with
improved deconstructability and adaptability contribute to circu-
larity. This brings new challenges such as tracking material stock
andﬂow along with the information to be stored in an interna-
tionally standardized resource bank. As agreed in the literature,
reusing both non-structural and structural building elements are
important to reduce the environmental impact of the built envi-
ronment. However, welcoming the reuse of those materials and
elements is highly related to the market dynamics and economy
which are the primary deciding factors in the construction industry.
Even the risk perception of users in reuse plays a major role when
constructing a new building with reused material. In this regard,
while top-down approaches for promoting CE in CBE can be
initially led by public projects, bottom-up motivations are still
needed from all the decision-makers in the industry to facilitate CE.
Identi ﬁed as a major gap within the literature and further dis-
cussed by this study, the complexity of the diverse project stake-
holders along with their con ﬂicting or differing interests and
expectations in CBE may require a unique framework to act as a
transparent platform to be communicated in line with CE princi-
ples. Additionally, due to the diversity in built environment scalesand construction stages, a Dynamic Circular Economy approach is
proposed which would help prioritize and/or customize CE prin-
ciples based on the magnitude of the built environment scale and
construction stage.
This study contributes to CBECE literature by providing a
comprehensive literature state with the subject maturity and di-
versity, understudied ﬁelds, gaps, and challenges. It also provides
extensive discussions, critical review, and future research ideas
with sound proposals in CBECE. The combination of the built
environment and construction stages along with the proposed re-
view framework can be used for different studies and purposes as
well. The newly introduced “R”principle “Replace ”is expected to
enhance the present understanding of CE. As another innovative
approach that can be used in future studies, the study projected the
number of publications within the actual year based on the data
from previous years to better visualize the publication trend which
predicts the number of publications for the year 2020 to be over
120.

__data__.text:
Journal of Cleaner Production 319 (2021) 128639
Available online 18 August 2021
0959-6526/© 2021 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.Factor dynamics to facilitate circular economy adoption in construction 
Rabia Charefa,*, Weisheng Lub 
aCentre for the Built and Natural Environment, Coventry University, Priory Street, CV1 5FB, Coventry, UK 
bDepartment of Real Estate and Construction, The University of Hong Kong (HKU), Hong Kong   
ARTICLE INFO  
Handling editor: Kathleen Aviso  
Keywords: 
Circular economy 
Construction 
Factors 
Dynamics 
Entity-relationship diagram 
Decision-making tools 
Asset lifecycle 
Material circularity 
Regulations 
Facilitating technology 
Circularity indicators ABSTRACT  
There is enormous potential for the construction industry in adopting a circular economy (CE) approach, but the 
decision-making tools to support its adoption are lacking. This research aims to identify the factors impacting CE 
adoption and understand their dynamics, intending to develop decision-making tools to facilitate CE adoption in 
construction. A mixed-method approach is adopted comprising a literature review, a pre-interview question -
naire, and semi-structured interviews with twenty European experts in the field. A total of 64 factors impacting 
CE adoption were identified and placed into three interconnected categories: organisational, political and pro-
cedural, and technical factors. Also, the connections between the stakeholders ’ backgrounds and the 64 factors 
were explored and illustrated by a Sankey diagram. Lastly, a deeper analysis was performed, exploring the re-
lationships between the 64 factors and five entities, including stakeholders, asset lifecycle, material circularity, 
regulations, and facilitating technologies. As a result, this research further clarifies the impacts of the CE 
approach on five entities and organises the factors and their dynamics in an entity-relationship diagram (ERD), 
being the main contribution to the theoretical foundations. By expatiating how CE can be possibly achieved in 
the construction industry, the ERD is a stepping stone and can inform operable guidance to boost the adoption of 
CE in the construction industry.   
1.Introduction 
Advanced digital technologies and sustainability agendas are trans -
forming the global architecture, engineering, and construction (AEC) 
industry. In particular, a circular economy (CE) strategy is gaining 
momentum as a means of dealing with environmental issues including 
natural resources depletion, greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, and 
construction and demolition (C&D) waste disposal. In contrast to the 
linear economy, “take, made, dispose ”, the CE approach aims to prolong 
the lifespan of goods and reduce waste through efficient design and 
material use. According to the Ellen McArthur Foundation, a CE is: “an 
industrial system that is restorative or regenerative by intention and 
design. It replaces the ‘end-of-life ’ concept with restoration, shifts to-
wards the use of renewable energy, eliminates the use of toxic chemicals, 
which impair reuse, and aims for the elimination of waste through the 
superior design of materials, products, systems, and, within this, busi-
ness models ” (Ellen MacArthur Foundation, 2013 ). 
The CE interest is increasing worldwide, among policymakers and 
industry practitioners. Several countries have set up plans to transition 
away from the linear economy (Chang et al., 2016 ). For instance, in Japan, the journey towards the CE began in the 1990s (Japanese Gov-
ernment, 1991 ). In 2000, the Japanese Government enacted the pio-
neering Law for Promotion of Efficient Utilization of Resources and a 
“comprehensive legal framework for moving towards a recycling-based 
society ” (Su et al., 2013 ). In 2008, the Chinese Government introduced 
“the Law for the Promotion of the Circular Economy ”, to enable a shift 
towards the CE, followed by the “Circular Economy Development Stra-
tegies Action Plan ” and more recently, “the 13th Five-Year Plan 
(2015 –2020) ” (Zhang et al., 2009 ). The European Union has proposed 
moving towards a CE model, aiming to transform production chains and 
consumption habits by turning waste into resources and closing the 
production loop (Robles, 2016 ). CEN/TC 350 requires member states to 
“legislate so that all new buildings are designed from a whole-life 
perspective, which takes into account both operational and embodied 
carbon emissions ”.

The European Union has proposed 
moving towards a CE model, aiming to transform production chains and 
consumption habits by turning waste into resources and closing the 
production loop (Robles, 2016 ). CEN/TC 350 requires member states to 
“legislate so that all new buildings are designed from a whole-life 
perspective, which takes into account both operational and embodied 
carbon emissions ”. More recently, the European Commission published 
“the European Green Deal ”, which aims to make Europe climate neutral 
by 2050 (European Commission, 2019 ). At the same time, the interest 
for CE for buildings is gaining interest among scholars (Akhimien et al., 
2021 ). 
Several studies focus on the CE approach in construction (Benachio
