Journal of Cleaner Production 319 (2021) 128639
2et al., 2020; Munaro et al., 2020; Hossain and Ng, 2018). For example, 
Ghisellini et al. (2016) deliver an extensive review of the CE literature to 
clarify and enhance understanding of the strategy at micro, meso, and 
macro levels. A systematic literature review revealed a progressive 
awareness of the CE for buildings and analysed sixty-four journal papers. 
The review put forward the application of CE in the built environment 
and enlighten gaps, particularly the lack of a holistic approach (Akhi -
mien et al., 2021). A systematic review covering the last 3 decades came 
out with areas with in-depth research and those where research is 
lacking (Osobajo et al., 2020). Similarly, by using a systematic literature 
review, some authors proposed a taxonomy containing 16 design and 
construction strategies associated with the CE approach and currently 
occurring within academics and practitioners. The authors concluded 
that a missing link between researchers and practitioners hindering 
greater adoption of the CE approach by the construction industry 
(Eberhardt et al., 2020). Opposingly to the Ellen MacArthur Butterfly 
illustrating the technical and biological cycles, Stephan and Atha-
nassiadis (2018) assert that recycling C&D waste is the key to the con-
struction industry transitioning towards a CE. Bao et al. (2019) use a 
case in Suzhou, China to look at procurement innovations for a CE, while 
Bao and Lu (2020) report lessons learned from Shenzhen, China in the 
broader context of developing efficient circularity for C&D waste man-
agement in fast-emerging economies. Ghaffar et al. (2020) describe a 
pathway to circular construction, advocating integrated management of 
C&D waste for resource recovery. Based on a bibliometric review and 
content analysis, Mhatre et al. (2021), categorized the research portfolio 
by investigating if the research is original, replicated or validated but 
also the development of the CE theory, whether observation, categori -
zation or association (Mhatre et al. 2021). By using a pattern-matching 
method, some authors presented the socio-economic and environmental 
barriers for a holistic view of the asset lifecycle, in the context of CE 
(Charef et al., 2021). In the context of “race for digitalization” of the 
construction industry through the use of BIM (Building Information 
Modelling), other studies looked at how BIM could support the man-
agement and minimization of the C&D waste and came out with eight 
BIM applications (Won and Cheng, 2017; Charef et al., 2018). Com-
plementary to those areas of interest and for the sake of showing the 
benefits for the construction industry, many researchers explored links 
between the CE approach and other approaches such as industry 4.0 and 
reverse logistics. The authors also looked at how the CE could tackle 
environmental issues, whether Sustainable Development Goals (SDG), 
waste minimization, climate change and GHG emissions. Industry 4.0 
and CE approaches are topics hugely debated by scholars, policymakers 
and practitioners and their association leads to hybrid categories like 
Circular I4.0 and Digital CE explored by some authors (Rosa et al., 
2020). Indeed, an investigation was done to see how the use of CE and 
Industry 4.0 are addressing the SDG. The authors analysed 50 
peer-review articles and concluded that the CE-I4.0 nexus is pivotal for 
the achievement of the SDG and identified that they directly benefits to 6 
SDG (Dantas et al., 2021). Other authors looked at the interplays be-
tween CE and reverse logistics. Based on the content analysis of a sample 
of 66 reviews, the authors explored the critical success factors of reverse 
logistics and proposed a taxonomy. They also came out with a frame -
work depicting the circular supply chain perspective (Julianelli et al., 
2020). More widely, Gallego-Schmid et al., (2020) analysed, through a 
literature review, the links between CE solutions and climate change 
mitigation. They concluded that CE solutions do not lead systematically 
to the reduction of GHG emissions (Gallego-Schmid et al., 2020).

They also came out with a frame -
work depicting the circular supply chain perspective (Julianelli et al., 
2020). More widely, Gallego-Schmid et al., (2020) analysed, through a 
literature review, the links between CE solutions and climate change 
mitigation. They concluded that CE solutions do not lead systematically 
to the reduction of GHG emissions (Gallego-Schmid et al., 2020). In 
addition, some authors have presented examples of successful waste 
minimization initiatives, which follow the CE principles (Low et al., 
2020). 
Despite studies emphasizing the environmental benefits of the CE 
approach, circular buildings are still rare, as the construction industry is 
highly regulated and must respond to emerging technological challenges 
and opportunities. Moreover, as highlighted a long time ago, stake -
holders are multiple, fragmented and scattered along this lifecycle (Egan, 1998) extending 50 years or longer. As a main contribution to the 
theoretical foundations, a study stressed the importance of interdisci -
plinary research as a driver towards circular buildings (Pomponi and 
Moncaster, 2017). More recently, Charef and Emmitt (2021) explored 
more specifically how the current BIM uses could support the transition 
to CE. Based on interviews results, they concluded that seven specific 
BIM uses should be created. The authors expatiated how those seven 
uses of BIM could help to overcome impediments faced by circular 
thinking (Charef and Emmitt, 2021). More recently, Charef and Lu 
(2021) analysed how the use of BIM could help to address the 15 prin-
ciples of the CE approach extracted from a real-life pilot project in 
Denmark (Lejerbo, 2018). They also looked at the relevance of BIM to 
overcome the CE shortcomings by presenting an entity-relationship di-
agram (ERD) illustrating the interrelationships between the barriers for 
the implementation of a CE approach, the BIM uses and the fifteen CE 
principles (Charef and Lu, 2021). 
In response to these shortcomings, some authors started to supply the 
construction industry with tools for collaboration, such as the 
empirically-based tool to support supply chain collaboration (Leising 
et al., 2018). In response to the massive material consumption and waste 
generation of buildings, some authors proposed a decision-making tool 
to support designers for the selection of the best option for the end-of-life 
(EOL) of buildings by using a multidisciplinary approach (Fregonara 
et al., 2017). To increase the circularity level of buildings, some authors 
claimed that the material passport is a supporting tool for designers and 
used it to compare the environmental impact of two variants, timber and 
concrete (Honic et al., 2019). In line, some authors proposed an online 
platform rostering secondary materials available for future construc -
tions. In addition, to generate and register material passports, this ma-
terial depot calculates circularity indicators of the building from the 
construction phase to the end-of-life phase (Heisel and Rau-Oberhuber, 
2020). Although a growing momentum towards a CE in construction is 
discernible, many gaps do still exist and hinder the implementation of 
the CE principles. Some of them are the need to create resource markets 
to connect the waste management loop nationally and internationally 
(Low et al., 2020) and the paucity of standardized methods and practices 
for its adoption in this industry (e.g., Benachio et al., 2020). 
In that respect, research work is required to connect general CE 
principles with the construction industry in all its heterogeneity. Against 
this backdrop, this doctoral project was initiated, which this study is part 
of, to develop construction-oriented CE decision-making tools. The 
study aims to identify factors that can facilitate the adoption of CE by the 
construction industry, in developed countries (in Western Europe) and 
understand their interconnections. The article has three specific 
research objectives: (1) to identify factors that will facilitate a transition 
to a CE approach in construction; (2) to identify entities involved in 
these factors, and (3) to classify and organise these factors in an entity- 
relationship diagram (ERD) to understand how their interactions impact 
the adoption of a CE approach. 
The rest of the paper comprises four sections.

The article has three specific 
research objectives: (1) to identify factors that will facilitate a transition 
to a CE approach in construction; (2) to identify entities involved in 
these factors, and (3) to classify and organise these factors in an entity- 
relationship diagram (ERD) to understand how their interactions impact 
the adoption of a CE approach. 
The rest of the paper comprises four sections. Following this intro-
duction, Section 2 presents the methodology involving a series of semi- 
structured interviews with 20 European experts in sustainable buildings, 
CE or BIM. In Section 3, the barriers and drivers raised by the in-
terviewees are analysed, classified and entities involved in those factors 
are identified (objectives 1 and 2). The impacts of a CE approach are 
explored, and an entity-relationship diagram is drawn and elaborated 
(objective 3). The discussion follows in Section 4 and conclusions are 
drawn in Section 5. 
2.Research method 
A mixed-method approach structured in four stages is adopted (see 
Fig. 1). Data collection in the first stage uses three channels: literature 
review, pre-interview questionnaire (PIQ), and semi-structured inter-
view (SSI). The primary and secondary data were analysed by using 
different methods. The literature review was primarily a content-based R. Charef and W. Lu

Journal of Cleaner Production 319 (2021) 128639
3analysis of the selected journal papers to extract factors for the adoption 
of sustainable practices. The primary data coming from the PIQ was 
analysed by using Excel and the data collected with the SSI was pre-
dominantly performed by engaging the qualitative technique with the 
assist of NVivo 12 software. 
2.1. Data collection: stage 1 
2.1.1. Literature review 
The literature review was twofold: (i) to have an overview of the 
various sustainable approaches used for buildings and (ii) to understand 
preliminary factors that can be hurdles or drivers to the adoption of CE or sustainable building approaches, in construction. Keywords “circular 
economy ”AND (“building ” OR “construction industry ” OR “built envi-
ronment ”) AND (“business model* ” OR “supply chain integration ”) were 
searched in Scopus, the largest database of peer-reviewed documents. 
The search was extended to the concept of sustainable approaches 
(named “X”), such as the “design for X′′techniques. More than 100 
journal papers were deemed relevant for the content examination and 
authors came out with the following outputs. First, questions for the Pre- 
Interview Questionnaire (PIQ) were set up. Then, based on the literature 
review, preliminary factors were identified, categorized and presented 
in a unified modelling language (UML) diagram (Fig. 2). Lastly, the 
analysis of the literature review supported the authors for the design of

2.1.2. Pre-interview questionnaire (PIQ) 
A PIQ can help the interviewer focus on the interview questions 
(Amundsen and McAlpine, 2009) or can be used “to give time to the 
respondent to source the information required” and increase the reli-
ability of data (Mccarron et al., 2013). The PIQ aimed to collect infor-
mation on the backgrounds of the interviewees and the companies. The 
authors sought to obtain an overview of the interviewees’ understand -
ing, awareness, knowledge, and use of design principles having CE po-
tential. By doing so, the authors were able to straight focus on the core 
subject and avoid losing time with information that could be collected 
through a questionnaire. The PIQ comprised 18 questions split into four 
parts, as shown in Table 2. The various types of design principles used in 
the PIQ questions were found in the literature. 
The selection for the sampling was performed by using convenient 
and snowball techniques for sampling (Hodgson et al., 2011). Experts 
were purposefully sought in the areas of CE, sustainable buildings, BIM 
technology, or a combination thereof. The selected participants have 
been asked for support to find more experts to interview. Two in-
terviewees helped the authors to connect with three participants. A 
unique sampling was used for both the PIQ and the SSI. Potential in-
terviewees received an email, explaining the aim of the research, the 
duration of the interview, and a link to the PIQ. The email also contained 
a participation sheet and the planned interview questions. Seventeen 
participants out of 20 filled the PIQ. The three missing ones were 
re-launch by email. The PIQ was designed, distributed, and analysed 
with the Bristol Online Survey and was accessible via an online link over 
the same period as the SSIs, from May 2018 to April 2019. The basic 
profiles of the interviewees comprising the sample are provided in 
Table 3. The approaches listed in Table 3 are the summary of the re-
spondents’ architectural approaches and how they tackle the environ -
mental impact of their activities. The summary is extracted from the 
analysis of the data coming from the PIQ and the SSI, conducted after the 
PIQ. 
2.1.3. Semi-structured interviews (SSIs) 
After completion by respondents of the PIQ, SSIs were conducted to 
explore the barriers and drivers for CE adoption. Due to the nascent 
nature of the CE in the built environment context, the inductive 
approach (Dubois and Gibbert, 2010) was adopted and the data has been 
collected cross-sectionally. A descriptive, interpretative approach was 
adopted to collect facts (Rowley, 2012), highlight common emerging Table 1

5ideas (Creswell and Poth, 2007 ) comprehend the phenomenon, the 
reasons for the lack of adoption of CE approach (Silverman, 2000 ), and 
seek experts ’ views (Gill et al., 2008 ). According to Moustakas (1994) , 
descriptive, interpretative research uses dominantly two types of 
methods: in-depth interviews or focus group (Moustakas, 1994 ). Due to 
the interviewees ’ extensive experience, high level of responsibility, 
disparate locations (France, UK, Ireland, Spain, Belgium), and lack of 
availability, interviews (face-to-face or telephone) were used instead of 
focus groups. In addition, by collecting data over a relatively long period 
of ten months, the data could be analysed successively, the questions 
adjusted, uncertainties eliminated and uncovered areas identified, as the 
interviews progressed. As recommended by Fellows and Liu (2015) , to 
increase the validity of the data, interviews were recorded, and tran-
scription was performed word-by-word and validated by each 
interviewee. 
2.2. Data analysis: stages 2 and 3 
Firstly, after the transcription and translation, the data analysis 
aimed at searching patterns and similarities using a qualitative tech-
nique with the assist of NVivo 12 software. In qualitative interpretative 
research, data is analysed following structured methods, including “the 
description of textual and structural discussions of the interviewees ” 
(Creswell, 2012 ). Following this approach, the 20 interview transcripts 
were analysed for themes and concepts relevant to CE adoption factors. 
Factors were clustered into three categories: (i) organisational (O), (ii) 
political and procedural - related (P), and (iii) technical (T). Overlaps 
between the three were sought and their relationships were organised in 
an ERD diagram. Secondly, relationships between the factors identified 
and two variables, the roles of the interviewees and the phases in which 
they are involved, were analysed. The results were presented in a Sankey 
diagram (Fig. 3). Lastly, based on the factors analysis and the relation -
ships between them and the interviewees ’ backgrounds, five entities 
have been identified as playing important roles in building and material 
lifecycles: (E1) Asset lifecycle, (E2) Stakeholders, (E3) Central facility repository (Asset & components), (E4) Collaboration platform (Material 
bank) and (E5) Regulation bodies. To build the ERD diagram, the re-
searchers have identified, for each factor, the relationship that it has 
with the five entities. 
3.Results and findings: stage 4 
3.1. Pre-interview questionnaire results 
Sustainable building approaches related to the asset life (design, 
construction, in use and EOL phases) used by the interviewees, their 
years of experience, and company size are summarised in Table 3. 
Company activities range from design to facility management and deal 
with all asset phases, from programming to deconstruction (Table 3). 
Projects include residential, office, educational and health buildings, 
among others. 
Of the 20 interviewees, two respondents recognize themselves as CE 
practitioners and 11 use a sustainable building approach close to the CE 
principles, as defined by Ellen MacArthur Foundation (2013) and 
Guldager Jensen and Sommer (2019) . The 14 respondents using BIM, 
enrich the model with graphical data. However, seven practitioners 
embedded in their model data related to material specifications and four 
embedded with maintenance requirements, structural and thermal 
properties. Four of 14 respondents using BIM, indicated that they inte-
grate cost and guarantee data into their BIM model. Three of 14 re-
spondents used models with lighting, acoustic, regulations and planning 
properties embedded. 
The last area explored with the PIQ is the understanding and use of 
“design for” principles and identifying which ones are most suitable for 
deconstruction. A consensus on design for deconstruction and disas-
sembly was noticeable. Nine respondents expressed the view that design 
for prefabrication or design with reclaimed components was not 
appropriate. Table 3

63.2. Factors for the adoption of a circular economy approach 
From the SSIs, 64 factors affecting CE adoption were identified and 
organised according to their characteristics into seven categories, as 
shown in Table 4. The first category contains eleven factors belonging to 
a single category, among which six organisational (O), three political 
and procedural (P), and two technical (T). The second category contains 
38 factors belonging to two categories, of which 24 are organisational/ 
political and procedural factors (OP), 10 are organisational/technical 
(OT) and 4 are technical/political and procedural (PT). The last category 
concerns 14 factors belonging to three categories organisational, polit-
ical and procedural, and technical (OPT). All those categories, their 
related factors and which factors were recommended by which re-
spondents are listed in Table 4. The interviewees are referred to by the 
“R” number, listed in Table 3. In the following subsections, categories 
containing organisational factors (O), Political and procedural factors 
(P) and Technical factors (T) are presented. 
3.2.1. Organisational factors 
From the 20 interviewees ’ opinions, 54 organisational factors 
(related to project team organisation and roles and responsibilities) were identified as affecting CE adoption (Table 4). CE implementation re-
quires a new budget, new role creation, preparing information infra-
structure, making information available, and so on (see (O) in Table 4). 
Included in organisational factors are database creation and manage -
ment but also activities related to exchange and collaboration between 
the stakeholders (see (OP) in Table 4). These factors should be built on 
an asset collaborative platform. In particular, the implementation of CE 
in construction requires consideration of EOL phase and emphasizes 
sustainability (see (OPT) in Table 4). It integrates the organisation of the 
EOL activities, including processes set up for EOL activities and recov -
ered materials flow, planning, execution and recovered materials re- 
processing, whether for reuse or recycling. To achieve the CE 
approach, stakeholders must consider the EOL from the design stage, e. 
g., through the application of design for deconstruction or design for 
manufacturing and assembly (DfMA), introducing low-waste designs, 
and so on (see (OT) in Table 4). 
3.2.2. Political and procedural factors 
There are 45 political and procedural factors identified from the 
interviews (see (OPT), (OP), and (P) in Table 4). They may include 
contractual agreements, tendering, and procurement. The identification

Factors facilitating circular economy adoption in construction.

Journal of Cleaner Production 319 (2021) 128639
7and specification of clients ’ requirements and those of builders, facility 
managers, and end-users regarding the data, classification, and updating 
expectations are included in this category. For all deliverables, the 
validation process is identified, framed, and contractually agreed upon. 
Similarly, collaboration and exchange rules are defined and agreed upon 
by all stakeholders. BIM content is also expressed at the beginning of the 
project (see (OPT) and (OP)). All the required data are specified, and the 
checking process also addresses data validity and compliance. Stake -
holders of projects are all involved in the writing of contracts, rules, and 
guidelines. The client, the architect, and the CE specialist are key roles in 
the drafting of the contractual documents, clearly expressing the pro-
ject’s CE expectations. 
3.2.3. Technical factors 
There are 30 technical factors identified by the 20 interviewees. 
These factors include, among others, the update of the data technolog -
ically to enable its access anytime (see (OPT) in Table 4), the building 
components and their composition, construction systems (see (OT) in 
Table 4), and requirements for deconstruction or disassembly of asset 
components (see (T) in Table 4). DfMA, modularization, and other 
design innovations were frequently recommended by interviewees. BIM 
and its requirements (setting up the EIR, the BIM execution plan, the 
AIR, among others) appeared frequently as a technical factor facilitating 
CE adoption because they set up the project ’s objectives and the roles 
and responsibilities of the stakeholders. 
After the organisation of the 64 factors, key entities in the asset and 
materials lifecycle were sought. First, the relationships between factors 
and the interviewees ’ backgrounds were analysed (Fig. 3). Then, for 
each factor, whether a barrier or a driver, the authors looked at which 
entity is key. By applying that at all the factors, the authors came out 
with a set of five entities: (E1) Asset lifecycle, (E2) Stakeholders, (E3) 
Central facility repository (Asset & components), (E4) Collaboration platform (Material bank) and (E5) Regulation bodies. Next, the factors 
were organised into an ERD to clarify how they are interconnected and 
changed across the whole asset lifecycle. Fig. 4 schematises the ERD to 
explain how factors are structured before a detailed ERD is introduced 
(Fig. 5). In the following subsections, the Sankey diagram, the ERD and 
its five entities are presented. 
3.3. Relationships between factors and the interviewees ’ backgrounds: 
stage 3 
Based on the results of the analysis of the SSI transcripts, 64 factors 
were identified and categorized. Those factors were further analysed 
with the results of the PIQ. The outcome, a Sankey diagram, shows the 
relationships between three variables, (i) the factors, (ii) the in-
terviewees ’ roles and (iii) the phases in which they are involved. Among 
the sampling of 20 interviewees, architects and BIM managers are over- 
represented with 6 architects and 3 BIM managers. As a result and un-
surprisingly, they are the stakeholders being associated with the highest 
number of factors. However, clients were under represented but are 
associated with a large number of factors. At a lesser proportion, the 
manufacturer and the BIM manager O&M, involved in the interviews are 
also connected with many factors. 
Regarding buildings ’ phases, the Sankey diagram pointed out the 
lack of involvement of several stakeholders, whether in the program -
ming and design stages or the EOL stage. For instance, although the 
experts selected for this study are precursors for the use of circular ap-
proaches, the structural engineer and the manufacturer are disconnected 
from the EOL phase. Alike, the deconstruction manager, despite he is 
deconstructing the buildings, is not involved upstream in the program -
ming and design phases. This is an important barrier for the CE adoption 
where the design for disassembly or deconstruction to increase the reuse 
of components are critical principles.

8Additionally, to the purpose of giving an overview of the interplays 
between the interviewees ’ backgrounds and the factors, the Sankey di-
agram also helped the authors to identify the entities used for the ERD. 
Indeed, E1 and E2 were given and fuelled by the interviewees ’ 
involvement in several asset/material phases. Similarly, the in-
terviewees using BIM and involved in all the asset phases provided the 
E3 and E4 entities. Regarding the E5, it was provided by the variety of 
the interviewees ’ roles and phases in which they are involved. The 
Sankey diagram is a stepping stone used to build the ERD and to further 
analyse the relationships between the 64 factors and the five entities, 
presented in the following subsection. 
3.4. Entity-relationship diagram: stage 4 
The ERD is illustrating the relationships between the factors and the five entities. The ERD is composed, at its core with the 64 factors 
(extracted from interview transcripts) and organised in seven categories, 
(O), (P), (T), (OP), (OT), (PT) and (OPT), as explained in the previous 
section. Five entities E1–E5 emerged from the 64 factors (also extracted 
from the interviewees feedback). E1 represents the phases in the assets 
and materials lifecycle, whereas E2 refers to the stakeholders involved 
within those phases. E3 is a central facility repository and E4 contains 
the entities, material bank and collaborative platform. And finally, E5 
refers to the regulatory bodies governing CE development in construc -
tion. After defining the entities, for each factor, the authors looked for 
which entity they could be associated with. Then, all the links found 
have been hierarchized according to their importance (See the caption in 
Fig. 5), based on the factors analysis between the factors and indicated 
with two types of arrows. The dotted arrows illustrate the entities 
feeding other entities (in terms of data), such as the material banks that

10will feed the asset phases. Inversely, when the asset is deconstructed, the 
salvaged materials will feed the materials bank, in the same way as 
manufacturers will fuel the bank with their new materials. The plain 
grey arrows show the connections between the factors and the phases 
(asset and materials), the stakeholders, and the collaborative platforms. 
A schema was developed, simultaneously with the ERD (Fig. 4) and used 
to ease the understanding of the readers and guide them through the 
read of the ERD, a more complex figure illustrating the relationships 
between the 64 factors for the adoption of CE in construction and the 
five entities. In the following subsections, the five entities are explained, 
within the CE context and in the BIM environment. 
3.4.1. Asset phases and stakeholders (E1 and E2) 
A CE in construction will involve the whole asset lifecycle (from 
design to construction, operation, maintenance and EOL) and will 
require to set up, at the start of any project, a collaborative platform. It is 
onerous to achieve in the construction industry, which is highly frag-
mented and necessitates bringing together parties from multiple disci-
plines. Empirical studies pointed out the importance of collaboration 
and coordination between the supply chain, producers and suppliers, 
and professionals (Sacks and Gurevich, 2016). To support this argument, 
nearly half of the 64 factors, extracted from the SSIs, show an impact on 
all phases (E1) and stakeholders (E2), as illustrated in the ERD. Thus, 
they require working collaboratively, from inception to EOL and even 
beyond for the processing of recovered materials (EOL contractors, 
manufacturers, E3 and E4). In addition to its multiples phases, the asset 
involves as well many stakeholders through its lifecycle. 
In the context of CE, the importance and appearance of the stake -
holders through the asset phases are, somewhat modified. First, as 
shown in Fig. 5, the client is associated with many factors for CE uptake 
and plays a leading role in any project, particularly in the CE context. 
Indeed, when the project begins, the client selects the multidisciplinary 
design team, including designers, engineers (structural, energy, acous -
ticians, among others), quantity surveyors, and the like. Secondly, de-
signers play a central role in the CE by selecting circular materials and 
through their involvement during the construction phase to make sure 
that the circularity of the asset is not compromised and is compliant with 
the design (Son et al., 2015). Then, the construction team usually ap-
pears when the design is fixed and oversees the construction phase. 
However, with approaches like CE, DfMA, or design for deconstruction, 
manufacturers and contractors have a more important role and are 
involved in the design process. Contractors and manufacturers are 
pivotal players in closing the material loop and avoiding waste and 
component toxicity. Similarly, stakeholders dealing with the asset EOL 
are involved during the design phase to give their requirements related 
to deconstructability that must be considered during the design to 
facilitate the disassembly of the building and optimize the material re-
covery rate. Several interviewees suggested the creation of new roles 
related to the CE and involved in the asset lifecycle, including recovering 
materials, and supporting clients, designers, and EOL contractors. To 
support the stakeholders involved in assessing the circularity of assets, 
some authors have dedicated and detailed a specific use of BIM to it and 
have stated that the circularity must be preserved throughout the asset 
lifecycle and make sure that the material loop is closed (Charef and 
Emmitt, 2021). To summarize, the CE approach changes ways of 
thinking, designing, constructing, and managing assets. As a result, and 
in the context of BIM, a huge amount of data will be generated and 
shared between multidisciplinary stakeholders through 3D Models and 
will require efficient and specific management. 
3.4.2. Central facility repository (E3) 
To solve the data management issues, the central facility repository is 
a key component, distinguishing between the BIM models, the BIM di-
mensions, and the data whether related to buildings or their compo -
nents. For the management of the data, projects’ databases and 
collaborative platforms were suggested by several interviewees and have been reported in many studies.

3.4.2. Central facility repository (E3) 
To solve the data management issues, the central facility repository is 
a key component, distinguishing between the BIM models, the BIM di-
mensions, and the data whether related to buildings or their compo -
nents. For the management of the data, projects’ databases and 
collaborative platforms were suggested by several interviewees and have been reported in many studies. Those platforms host all the in-
formation about the asset from its inception to its EOL and are central -
ized (E3 in Fig. 5). The common data exchange (CDE) platforms are set 
up by stakeholders throughout the asset lifecycle and end up in the 
central facility repository. Among scholars, Chen (2015) created a 
“single database” as a collaborative platform enabling all stakeholders to 
access the central database (Chen, 2015). More recently, some authors 
explored the potential of BIM for the CE in the construction industry and 
came out with specific BIM uses for managing projects and materials 
through the asset and materials lifecycle. For the management of the 
asset, they proposed project databases and materials banks for managing 
materials, whether new or recovered (Charef and Emmitt, 2021). The 
central facility repository will be managed by the owner of the asset and 
will be fed with the appropriate data emerging from all the asset phases, 
from programming to EOL management. The design team will have the 
responsibility to collect and verify the reliability and completeness of the 
data from the start of the project until its completion. Thus, the central 
facility repository raises several issues, including data updating, and the 
reliability of the data assessed by checking and secured by validation. 
The data must be updated periodically and stay accessible. The risk of 
lack of updating might be exacerbated by the change of assets’ owner -
ship but also by the asset and material lifespans. Several checking and 
deliverables must be set up by the designer and the client throughout the 
asset lifecycle. The responsibility rests on several stakeholders and must 
be set up contractually (see Table 4). Some authors have identified BIM 
as a driver that can support the stakeholders with their data. Indeed, the 
BIM use “data validity and update checking” has the potential to anal-
yse, examine and evaluate the quality of the data. Thus, data validity 
throughout the asset lifecycle will be guaranteed (Charef and Emmitt, 
2021). The central facility repository will be fuelled by two types of 
collaborative platforms, one related to the asset and the other related to 
the material level, whether recovered or new. 
3.4.3. Collaborative platform for materials (E4) 
Since one of the environmental impact factors is an inbound disease, 
to realize the CE in construction, the interviewees proposed the creation 
of a platform including material banks (new and recovered materials) 
fed by the processing and re-processing databases. To address the huge 
amount of recovered materials, coming from existing buildings, whether 
during the refurbishment phase or the EOL activities, specific plants for 
materials re-processing, must be developed. Several interviewees rec-
ommended considering the material level and suggested linking the 
central facility repository with the collaborative platform for materials 
(E4), including the materials’ bank (e.g., new and recovered materials) 
and material processing and re-processing (e.g., arrow linking E3-E4 in 
Fig. 5). Some authors considered that the use of BIM is a facilitator and 
proposed a specific BIM use to address the missing link between the EOL 
activities and the material banks. They proposed to use BIM for materials 
recovery processes, even though recovery actors are still lagging behind 
digitalization (Charef and Emmitt, 2021). The digitalization of the re-
covery sector will stimulate the market by providing for example the 
quantities and the location of the reclaimed materials. Indeed, architects 
must have that information to be able to prescribe the recovered ma-
terials and adapt their design accordingly. Furthermore, at a different 
level, having a reasonable estimation of what resources are available 
will be crucial to facing natural resource depletion. Several countries 
including Germany and Austria have begun to create a regional cadastre 
of secondary resources able to quantify and forecast the availability of 
their anthropogenic stocks (Kleemann et al., 2017; Oezdemir et al., 
2017).

Furthermore, at a different 
level, having a reasonable estimation of what resources are available 
will be crucial to facing natural resource depletion. Several countries 
including Germany and Austria have begun to create a regional cadastre 
of secondary resources able to quantify and forecast the availability of 
their anthropogenic stocks (Kleemann et al., 2017; Oezdemir et al., 
2017). According to the Cradle-to-Cradle® approach, buildings are 
material banks. Geldermans (2016) defined a material bank as “tem-
porary storage of materials that comprise the building assemblies” and 
asserted that it should be combined with concepts such as design for 
adaptability or design for deconstruction to enable materials’ recovery 
and smooth the path for CE implementation (Geldermans, 2016). The 
collaborative platform will contain data about the actual material R. Charef and W. Lu

Journal of Cleaner Production 319 (2021) 128639
11available and the forecast materials. A reclaimed materials bank and a 
bank for new materials could be managed at the regional or national 
level. The reclaimed materials bank can be fed by the recycling and 
reuse plants, after characterization of the salvaged materials. Having 
said that, the market for recovered materials must be developed and 
structured in accordance. Also, if the material required to meet CE re-
quirements does not exist, the market should be prepared. Manufac -
turers will be involved during the programming phase to be aware of the 
clear requirements, and they will have enough time to adapt their 
products (OPT-08 in Table 4). Therefore transparency on products’ 
composition is a sine qua none condition. In that regard, the Green -
Format approach, a web-based database containing information about 
products, should be widely used by clients, designers, and manufac -
turers to make sure that building components are reusable or recyclable 
and free from all toxic elements. Also, architects and specifiers must 
know the products’ composition and understand the impacts of the 
choices they make. According to several authors, in the context of the 
CE, the selection of materials should be made purposely for reuse or 
recycling possibilities (Esa et al., 2016). In early 2007, the “eco-design” 
approach, also known as “design for environment”, recommended 
avoiding hazardous and toxic materials (Ljungberg, 2007). As a result, 
more transparency about product content is required from manufac -
turers and should be supported by regulatory bodies. 
3.4.4. Regulatory bodies (E5) 
Regulatory bodies (E5) will play a crucial role in the transition to a 
CE economy, in terms of policy-makers and procedures (tendering and 
procurement, contracts, permit approval). Interviewees reported that, in 
the dynamics of digitization, construction contracts had been recently 
modified for the BIM context by adding the BIM protocol as a contrac -
tual document. Similarly, the standard contracts’ forms must be adapted 
to introduce CE contractual terms and specify specific needs for the 
management of the asset EOL and the fate of each component, whether 
recycled, reused, or otherwise. The contract will also specify collabo -
rative boundaries and related responsibilities. In that regard, Huang 
et al. (2018) suggest involving the purchasing of recovered materials in 
the government procurement system to encourage clients and designers 
to use salvaged materials. To support this argument, several in-
terviewees advocated that adaptations should also be made to the 
traditional tendering and procurement methods. Indeed, the traditional 
procurement methods allow the discovery of a contractor very late or 
once the design and detail specifications are fixed. In a CE approach, it is 
crucial to involve builders earlier, during the design phase, when de-
cisions are made about which building systems to adopt and which 
material to use. For instance, some designers among the interviewees 
use earth as a structural material and reported that the design is 
completely different for earthen architecture, in terms of structure, 
space design, building orientation and use of finishing works materials, 
among others. They advocate that builders must take part in early design 
decisions and policies around earth material should be set up to facilitate 
the approval by insurance bodies and by permit approval authorities 
(Morel et al., 2021). Therefore, policymakers are the cornerstone of the 
effective adoption of the CE by setting new policies for the use of ma-
terials, the transparency required about their composition and certifi -
cation schemes regarding building circularity, among others. Also, 
policymakers must promote and encourage the use of reclaimed mate-
rials by setting standards, as well as extended producer responsibility 
legislation putting manufacturers responsible for taking back their 
products from end-users. Incentive programs could be used to increase 
adoption rates. Conclusively, even though the adoption of circular 
strategies by using reclaimed materials is environmentally friendly, its 
use is usually up to the owner and policies in place. This could be 
strengthened by implementing more adapted, stricter and global 
policies. 4.Discussion 
4.1. The client and designer as key roles 
Clients alongside designers will play a significant role in CE adop-
tion. The CE leads to a swing towards circular and reverses design 
thinking (UK GBC, 2019).

This could be 
strengthened by implementing more adapted, stricter and global 
policies. 4.Discussion 
4.1. The client and designer as key roles 
Clients alongside designers will play a significant role in CE adop-
tion. The CE leads to a swing towards circular and reverses design 
thinking (UK GBC, 2019). Designers must modify the way they tackle 
their job, and to optimize deconstruction, the use of an open building 
system with interchangeable parts is recommended (Kibert, 2003). 
Designing “flexible and adaptable” buildings will require architects to 
use demountable parts of the building to make it adaptable, over time, to 
an external and internal change (Ajayi et al., 2015). Deconstructability 
or demountability are approaches that consider the composition of 
buildings in several layers. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors 
(RICS) split building systems into six groups: substructure, superstruc -
ture, finishes, fittings and furnishings, services, and external works. 
Other authors support the layers approach (Brand, 1994) and group 
them into six categories: site, structure, skin, services, space plan, and 
stuff (Geldermans et al., 2019; Brand, 1994). By avoiding finishing 
works, the space plan layer responsible for a massive amount of waste 
due to its short lifespan is absent (Harvey and RICS, 2001). Some de-
signers of earthen architecture, among the interviewees, reported that 
the project is designed to avoid hiding structural walls or HVAC systems 
that are fully integrated into the design (Morel et al., 2021). In addition 
to this approach, several others share CE principles, such as “design for” 
approaches (e.g., design for deconstruction) and “designing out waste” 
approach, which is seen as the aim of the CE approach (WRAP, 2009; 
Ellen MacArthur Foundation, 2014). Some interviewees highly recom -
mended the use of the DfMA approach to facilitate the implementation 
of CE principles. Similarly, many studies have addressed DfMA as a 
means of tackling wastage during construction and associated it with the 
use of BIM. By manufacturing building parts under factory conditions, 
prefabrication or off-site construction are also strategies to improve the 
construction stage, in terms of waste reduction, quality control 
improvement, and construction time reduction, among others (Jaillon 
et al., 2009). Moreover, the association of prefabrication, modular 
design, standard components, and BIM is an interesting approach for 
construction and design cost reduction, time-saving, and waste reduc -
tion. According to Charef and Lu (2021), both approaches have great 
benefits for the CE, especially when they are associated with BIM and the 
Internet of Things (IoT) technologies. The IoT supports collecting all the 
data generated by sensors and connecting all the stakeholders involved 
throughout the asset lifecycle (Zhong et al., 2017) ((O-T) in Fig. 5). 
While some of the design approaches ((O-T) in Fig. 5) discussed above 
are sometimes used by designers, they are not commonly used practices 
because they disrupt conventional design practices and require a radical 
shift in the way projects are designed. 
4.2. Early involvement of stakeholders before/during the design phase 
This point is raised in E1 and E2 in the ERD (Fig. 4) but cannot be 
overemphasized in achieving the CE in construction. In response to the 
early involvement of project stakeholders, the use of Integrated Project 
Delivery or innovative procurement methods is a promising strategy. 
Some authors believe that the use of the Integrated Project Delivery 
(IPD) method and collaborative BIM environment can enable the early 
involvement of contractors (Pheng et al., 2015). Based on a systematic 
review to look at the use of BIM standards and guidelines for sustain -
ability purposes, Chong et al. (2017) came out with the conclusion of a 
lack of innovative procurement systems. Consideration of the asset as an 
assembly of systems requires contractor know-how during the early 
programming and design phases (Song et al., 2009).

Based on a systematic 
review to look at the use of BIM standards and guidelines for sustain -
ability purposes, Chong et al. (2017) came out with the conclusion of a 
lack of innovative procurement systems. Consideration of the asset as an 
assembly of systems requires contractor know-how during the early 
programming and design phases (Song et al., 2009). However even if 
they are still in their infancy, several innovative procurement methods 
have been developed, such as Cost Led Procurement (CLP), Integrated 
Project Insurance (IPI), Two-Stage Open Book, IPD, and Project 
Alliancing (PA), among others. For example, new tendering technologies R. Charef and W. Lu

Journal of Cleaner Production 319 (2021) 128639
12enable the early involvement of the contractor, higher transparency and 
the use of independent assurance (Ciribini et al., 2015). In line with 
those previous arguments and the CE matter, many interviewees believe 
that the early involvement of all stakeholders is crucial, particularly to 
get their requirements regarding the design, construction, management 
and EOL of the asset. Likewise, involving the manufacturers during the 
programming phase and setting the CE requirements of the project, will 
allow them to adapt their products to the CE requirements regarding 
products’ innocuous, reusability and recyclability. The early involve -
ment of the stakeholders support the CE principles and coupled with the 
use of BIM could accelerate the speed of embracing circular thinking. 
4.3. BIM as a driver for CE adoption 
The digitalization of the construction industry, gaining momentum 
around the world has already proven its worth in many activities and 
seems to be promising for the transition from linear to the circular 
economy. An overall improvement is reported, in terms of visualisation, 
coordination, estimation and scheduling, whether during design or 
construction activities. It is also an excellent tool for strengthening the 
handover phase and streamlining facility management. During the 
design and construction stages, the project information model (PIM) is 
developed. After the project handover, the AIM is delivered to the fa-
cility management team to help them during the operation and main -
tenance phase. The AIM will evolve according to events that occur while 
the building is in use (Carbonari et al., 2015). As a result, a huge amount 
of data is available and has the potential to be used for the management 
of the EOL activities. For example, the development of Construction 
Operations Building Information Exchange (COBie) is usually required 
by the client and delivered by the design team during the handover and 
closeout stages (Gething, 2011; Sinclair, 2012). COBie is an interna -
tional standard enabling facility managers to use the data embodied into 
the BIM model for maintenance and operation activities. Similarly, the 
COBie could be used to exchange data with other entities such as 
stakeholders involved in materials recovery processes, whether for reuse 
or recycling (Charef, 2019). More recently, some authors have identified 
BIM technology as a means of managing the asset EOL (Won and Cheng, 
2017). In line with this argument, Charef (2019) advocated that several 
models are created throughout the asset lifecycle, including a Decon -
struction Information Model (DIM) for the management of EOL activ-
ities. In that regard and complementary to previous work initiated by 
Won and Cheng (2017), some authors have recognized that BIM is an 
enabler for the CE approach and have identified 7 new BIM uses to 
accelerate the CE uptake (Charef and Emmitt). To go further, Charef and 
Lu (2021) explored more specifically how the use of BIM can help 
achieve the fifteen CE principles developed by Lejerbo (2018). Under 
these arguments, many respondents believe that BIM could facilitate a 
transition towards the CE, particularly by supporting owners to engage 
serenely in the CE approach. Indeed, knowing the asset lifecycle cost is 
facilitated through BIM and will help to overcome the false belief that 
engaging for the CE is costly. BIM can help predict the return of in-
vestment and reassure clients reluctant to embrace the CE. Also, the BIM 
process necessitates changes in the roles of the stakeholders (e.g., cli-
ents, architects, contractors), who need to collaborate in sharing a vast 
amount of data from design to completion (Fadeyi, 2017; Zhu et al., 
2017) and adopt an overall view of an asset lifecycle. 
In that respect, a strong agreement between the stakeholders is 
crucial and must be clearly defined with boundaries set up contractually, 
at the beginning of a BIM project (Sebastian, 2011; Sinclair, 2012; 
Bouwens et al., 2016). Similarly, in the CE matter, roles and re-
sponsibilities, slightly different compared to a linear project, must be 
defined during the programming and design phases. Some roles will gain 
importance (builders) and others will become secondary (finishing 
works contractors).

Similarly, in the CE matter, roles and re-
sponsibilities, slightly different compared to a linear project, must be 
defined during the programming and design phases. Some roles will gain 
importance (builders) and others will become secondary (finishing 
works contractors). Additionally, some new key roles appear, such as CE 
and recovered materials specialists (stakeholders in grey in Box E2, 
Fig. 5) who will be in charge of the circularity assessment. Consequently, the overall project budget will be divided differently. Also and due to the 
huge amount of data, the many exchanges between the stakeholders, 
and the importance of working with valid data throughout the asset 
lifecycle, checking procedures become vital to ensure reliability and 
availability of the data, continuously. BIM can help with checking and 
validation tasks. Kassem et al. (2014) propose protocols for BIM 
collaborative design to support the entire supply chain in exchanges and 
deliverables, the goal being the improvement of flow and consistency for 
data and deliverables. In the context of the CE approach, several factors 
are associated with the need to clearly define the circularity re-
quirements and the deliverables for the project. 
5.Conclusion 
The construction industry worldwide is exploring the adoption of a 
circular economy (CE), but the effort is hampered by the lack of 
decision-making tools. This research focuses on these tools’ antecedents, 
i.e., the factors facilitating CE adoption, and understanding their dy-
namics. Through data collection and analysis, 64 factors impacting CE 
adoption in construction were identified and further organised into 
three categories related to organisational, political and procedural, and 
technical aspects. Their dynamics were further delineated in an entity- 
relationship diagram (ERD) comprising the factors affecting the CE 
implementation and five entities: the asset and material phases with 
their related main stakeholders (E1-E2), the central cility repository 
(E3), the collaborative platform and material bank (E4) and the regu-
lation bodies (E5). The research reported represents only preliminary 
steps towards operable decision-making tools. The main contribution to 
the knowledge of this study, the factors and their dynamics organised in 
an ERD, help to improve the understanding of how the CE can be ach-
ieved in the heterogeneous construction industry. The ERD is a stepping- 
stone illustrating where efforts should be put and informing operable 
guidance to boost the adoption of CE in the construction industry. 
Incontestably, the CE requires non-trivial changes in terms of pro-
fessional knowledge, stakeholders engagement, and their involvement 
in the asset lifecycle, material circularity, procurement, policies, 
incentive schemes, and technologies. The ERD shows that achieving the 
CE in the construction industry involves different stakeholders across an 
asset lifecycle from inception, design, construction, to end-of-life. It also 
depicts the urgent need to shift towards circular thinking and design 
with the end in mind. The ERD shows that the belief in the CE of clients 
and designers is pivotal, but other stakeholders such as contractors, fa-
cility managers, and suppliers are also important. Another implication of 
this study is to re-consider the ways products are designed and put 
manufacturers and designers at the core of the circular design process. 
Also, the order and intervention of the stakeholders involved throughout 
the asset lifecycle change, leading some roles to be more important 
(clients, designers, manufacturers, builders) and some less (finishing 
work contractors). Indeed, CE requires downstream stakeholders (e.g., 
material suppliers or EOL contractors) to be involved at the upfront 
stage. Moreover, new roles are needed, such as CE specialists who are 
key players throughout the asset lifecycle. The EOL phase will also see 
new roles appear and some existing roles will become crucial. The 
process of EOL activities will be redesigned, such as the pre- 
deconstruction audit and the execution of the deconstruction requiring 
delicacy to avoid deterioration of materials and components. Therewith, 
new plants and processes are expected to be created to absorb the 
enormous amount of recovered materials, whether for reuse, repair, 
remanufacturing and recycling (upcycling and downcycling). Addi-
tionally, achieving a CE also requires rich technical knowledge, which 
can be accumulated in material banks (e.g., low-waste materials, 
avoiding finishing).

Therewith, 
new plants and processes are expected to be created to absorb the 
enormous amount of recovered materials, whether for reuse, repair, 
remanufacturing and recycling (upcycling and downcycling). Addi-
tionally, achieving a CE also requires rich technical knowledge, which 
can be accumulated in material banks (e.g., low-waste materials, 
avoiding finishing). 
Indeed, given the fragmentation of stakeholders involved in a pro-
longed building asset lifecycle, a central facility repository based on BIM 
is proposed in this stage. In this respect, the implication of this study is to 
have a holistic view of buildings and consider them as materials stocks R. Charef and W. Lu

Journal of Cleaner Production 319 (2021) 128639
13that could be used later when buildings end their life. Their components 
should still be reintroduced into the material loop instead of ending in 
landfills. As a result, another implication of this study is the necessity to 
set up organised resource markets for recovered materials to connect the 
waste management loop nationally and internationally. Irrefutably, 
storage spaces must be created. Although this research is part of a cur-
rent emulsion around the CE and worldwide digitalization, the associ -
ation of both disciplines is still in its infancy. Digital technologies, such 
as BIM, appears as a promising means of providing a one-truth infor-
mation hub for decision-making related to CE in construction. There -
fore, implications around the reliability and validity of the data created 
and exchanged are critical. Also, new technologies such as blockchain 
and the Internet of Things (IoT) are emerging to present both opportu -
nities and challenges. 
Achieving the CE in construction is not only about people and 
technologies, but also requires regulations and policy knowledge. Inte-
grated project procurement/delivery will reduce discontinuity, 
encouraging commitment from all stakeholders over a relatively long 
period. Incentive schemes should be developed to encourage material 
circularity not only during the design stage but also during the operation 
and EOL stages. Moreover, new certification schemes like green building 
rating tools should be promptly developed to recognize and encourage 
the CE in construction. Circularity indicators must be defined to be able 
to assess the circularity of buildings. Moreover, certification schemes 
around recovered materials are also lacking and must be regulated to 
stimulate the market and reassure the users on the quality and perfor -
mance of recovered materials. Testing processes are needed prior to the 
certification, a sine qua non condition before re-injecting any system, 
product and component into the market. 
Although this study is contributing to knowledge by providing an 
ERD to support the understanding of the CE shortcomings, the study 
presents some limitations that could be addressed by further research. 
Indeed, the reported findings are obtained by the use of semi-structured 
interviews within the construction industry in Westen Europe. Differ -
ences in construction regulations across countries may raise concerns 
regarding the generalizability of the results. Consequently, further 
works are recommended to refine the ERD by contextualising it in 
different scenarios within or outside Europe. The research reported is 
mainly informed by interviewees and represents only preliminary steps 
towards operable decision-making tools. Thus, research and develop -
ment works are desired to refine the factors facilitating CE adoption in 
construction and their relationships further by providing, for example, 
frameworks and guidelines considering the five entities identified in this 
study. Researchers are encouraged to turn the ERD into operable guid-
ance or decision-making tools. Lastly, validation works should also be 
carefully designed and implemented before such guidance, and decision- 
making tools can be widely accepted in real-life construction practices. 
New technologies such as BIM, blockchain, and IoTs can be explored to 
enrich the tools. Espousing institutional arrangements such as amenable 
procurement models, waste management incentive schemes, and CE 
certification systems should be considered.

products in Norway 
Katrin Knotha,*, Selamawit Mamo Fufaa, Erlend Seilskjærb

Keywords: 
Reuse 
Construction material 
Building industry 
Circular economy ABSTRACT  
Reuse of construction materials and products has great potential to reduce the environmental footprint of a 
building. However, the way buildings are designed and constructed rarely considers closed loop materials sys-
tems and the implementation of reuse in building projects is associated with many hurdles. Various professionals 
might experience different challenges or might be affected to different degrees. The objective of this paper is to 
provide an insight into experiences and perspectives of professional actors involved in projects with a focus on 
reuse in Norway. A series of interviews with manufacturers, architects, contractors, environmental consultants, 
and public institutions was conducted to (i) identify barriers and success factors for reuse in pilot projects, (ii) 
capture the issues that seem most pressing for different actors, (iii) identify which actors in the value chain need 
to be more included into reuse processes, and (iv) define and prioritise necessary actions to advance reuse in 
Norway. The results suggest that reuse in Norway could be greatly advanced by more communication and 
cooperation between different actors in the value chain. Especially manufacturers can play an important role and 
need to be more involved in reuse processes. Planning for and practical execution of reuse will benefit from well- 
functioning research infrastructure. However, legislation needs to be adjusted in favour of reuse. Currently being 
one of the greatest barriers as experienced by most actors, it has the potential to become the greatest enabler for 
the reuse of materials and products in the Norwegian building sector.   
1.Introduction 
The Norwegian building and construction industry is responsible for 
approximately 26% of the total national waste stream (Statistics Nor-
way, 2021 ). From 2018 to 2019, the amount of waste from construction, 
rehabilitation, and demolition further increased by 5.6%. Less than half 
of this waste was recycled (Statistics Norway, 2021 ), which is below 
national and EU requirements of 70% reuse, recycling and recovery of 
non-hazardous materials (European Commission, 2018 ). The vast ma-
jority of construction waste in Norway consists of non-contaminated and 
inert materials and could be reused without any health or environmental 
risks (Statistics Norway, 2021 ). 
Reuse is a key principle in the waste hierarchies. It improves material 
efficiency across all economic sectors and represents the second-best 
choice after waste prevention to decrease resource consumption and 
carbon emissions, and divert demolition waste from landfills (Akinade 
et al., 2017 ; Rakhshan et al., 2020 ). A Nordic study states that reuse of 
construction products has the potential to reduce resource consumption by 20% in the Nordic construction sector resulting in greenhouse gas 
emission (GHG) savings of approximately 900 000 tons CO2equivalents 
(Høibye and Sand, 2018 ). At the same time, it can create social and 
financial benefits for private companies equating to 1.7% of the annual 
growth rate (Høibye and Sand, 2018 ). 
The concept of design for deconstruction (DfD) has been introduced 
decades ago (Akinade et al., 2017 ), however, traditional methods of 
end-of-life building disposal are dominating since modern society rarely 
designs with material recovery in mind (Guy and Shell, 2002 ). Con-
struction materials hold the potential of lowering overall embodied 
impacts of buildings from the early stages (Rahla et al., 2021 ) and de-
signers, contractors and other construction actors must act together to 
define ambitions for material loops.

Con-
struction materials hold the potential of lowering overall embodied 
impacts of buildings from the early stages (Rahla et al., 2021 ) and de-
signers, contractors and other construction actors must act together to 
define ambitions for material loops. 
Key drivers for reuse in the Norwegian building sector are the 
reduction of GHG emissions and enhanced company image by fulfilling 
criteria of sustainability schemes. The latter often combine sustainabil -
ity and circular economy concepts (Rahla et al., 2021 ). BREEAM-NOR 
(Grønn Byggallianse, 2020 ) and the Norwegian FutureBuilt criteria for

2circular buildings (FutureBuilt, 2020) include both reuse and circular 
economy principles. In addition, national initiatives such as the "Na-
tional Strategy on Circular Economy" (Ministry of Climate and Envi-
ronment, 2021), requirements for the assessment of reuse of 
construction products (Direktoratet for byggkvalitet, 2021), and the 
establishment of digital reuse platforms (Loopfront, 2021; Rehub, 2021) 
demonstrate the growing interest in circular practices. 
Reuse is still in its early stage in Norway. Only few pilot projects are 
currently testing reuse solutions and processes. The first FutureBuilt 
projects testing the feasibility of reuse in construction projects have 
recently been completed (Entra, 2021). The lessons learned from these 
pilot projects will play a major role in the development and imple -
mentation of measures to advance the reuse of construction products 
and materials. 
In the framework of the research project "REBUS – Reuse of building 
materials - a user perspective ", a series of interviews with different 
groups of actors from the Norwegian construction industry was con-
ducted to identify barriers and success factors for reuse as experienced 
by different experts and professions. 
Several studies have identified a range of sectoral, financial, regu-
latory, and cultural factors affecting material reuse in the building sector 
(Camacho-Otero et al., 2018; Debacker and Manshoven, 2016; Dunant 
et al., 2017; Hart et al., 2019; Nordby, 2019) showing that addressing 
reuse obstacles requires a holistic approach (Rakhshan et al., 2020). 
While barriers and success factors identified from the interview data 
coincide to a great extent with findings from other studies (Rakhshan 
et al., 2020), the analysis of perceptions and viewpoints of different 
actors add a new level to studying the adoption of reuse in the Norwe -
gian building sector. The groups of actors participating in the interviews 
were chosen based on their first-hand experience in pilot projects or 
other direct professional experience with reuse of building materials. 
The principal objective of the article is to provide an insight into 
experiences and perceptions of different groups of actors concerning 
practical challenges, barriers, and success factors related to the reuse of 
construction products. Secondary objectives are to (i) isolate differences 
between different groups of actors and identify specific needs and re-
quirements in terms of successful implementation of reuse, (ii) capture 
the issues that seem most pressing for different actors, (iii) identify, 
which actors in the value chain need to be more included into reuse 
processes and (iv) define and prioritise necessary actions to advance 
reuse in Norway. 
Section 1 introduces the topic with a theoretical background, study 
goal and scope. Section 2 describes the interview methodology, inter-
viewee profile, and data analysis (section 2). Next, the results of the 
thematic analysis are presented discussing and investigating barriers 
and success factors with a focus on different groups of actors (section 3) 
and in a Norwegian context (section 4). The article closes with a short 
conclusion (section 5). 
2.Methodology 
2.1. Interview format and procedure 
Semi-structured interviews were conducted between November 
2020 and February 2021 in Oslo, Norway. Due to Covid 19 restrictions, 
all interviews were conducted online via Microsoft Teams. Twelve in-
terviews were conducted with a total of 21 actors participating. Two 
participants unable to take part in the online interviews due to time 
constraints answered the questions in written form. 
All interviews followed a standardized set of questions (appendix A) 
that was sent to all participants prior to the interviews. The following 
main themes were covered:  
(i) General project information: Background information of the pilot 
project that interviewees were involved in and their role in the 
project. Participants that did not take part in a relevant pilot project, were encouraged to provide experiences on reuse ini-
tiatives and approaches in their workplace.  
(ii) Reuse potential: Detailed questions concerning reuse potential, 
material sources and experiences concerning the reuse of various 
materials.  
(iii) Mapping and evaluation: Questions focusing on product selection 
criteria, evaluation methods, and practical challenges for reuse.  
(iv) General comments and opinions: Personal views and reflections on 
success factors for the reuse of building products.

material sources and experiences concerning the reuse of various 
materials.

criteria, evaluation methods, and practical challenges for reuse.

Actors participating in the same pilot project were interviewed in 
groups, where different actors could answer the questions they consid -
ered relevant for their role in the project. Interviewees were free to go 
into detail when giving their answers and follow-up questions were 
asked to allow participants to elaborate on matters specifically relevant 
for the research objectives. Between one to four persons participated in 
each interview session, which lasted between 60 and 90 min. 
All participants signed an agreement prior to the interviews con-
senting to the recording of the interviews and the use of information in 
research activities and publications. Data collection was conducted in 
the form of recordings and notes, and interviews were transcribed. 
Transcripts of the interviews were sent to interviewees for comments 
and verification. Due to data protection requirements, only profession 
and role of the interviewees in pilot projects may be revealed in the 
article. 
2.2. Interviewees’ profile and pilot projects 
All interviewees are involved in projects that have a focus on reuse 
and/or have a professional interest in reuse of building material. Par-
ticipants from four different pilot projects (Table 2) were part of the 
interviews. The aim was to cover a range of different professions and 
functions within the value chain. Interview participants have various 
backgrounds and hold different roles in pilot projects. This approach 
was taken to find out whether perceptions, experiences, and mindset 
towards reuse of building material differs depending on a person’s 
background, role, and responsibilities. 
Interviewees were chosen from five groups of actors typically 
participating in construction or rehabilitation projects:  
(i) manufacturers: Participant P4 represents a company selling used 
products and is directly involved in the reuse business. Partici -
pants P20 and P21 represent a manufacturer that is following a 
linear business model but has started to investigate recycling and 
recovery of raw materials from their products.  
(ii) architects: Participants P5, P10, P12 and P15 were part of pilot 
projects (Table 2). Their main task was to design and develop 
reuse solutions.  
(iii) building owners/contractors: Participants P6, P7, P9 and P16 were 
part of pilot projects (Table 2).  
(iv) environmental/reuse consultants: Participants P1, P2, P8, P11, P13, 
P14, and P18 took part in the pilot projects. Participants P2 and 
P8 are reuse experts currently developing tools for reuse of 
building materials.  
(v) Public institutions: Participant P3 represents a programme for 
climate friendly urban development funded by several munici -
palities supporting pilot projects to achieve sustainability criteria 
including reuse. Participant P17 represents a public building 
owner for social housing and participant P19 functioned as 
project leader for developing reuse infrastructure for a Norwe -
gian municipality.

32.3. Data analysis 
The qualitative data collected in the interviews was analysed using a 
thematic coding and categorization scheme. Interviews were coded 
using NVivo qualitative data analysis software (QSR International Pty 
Ltd., 2020). 
2.3.1. Thematic analysis 
A thematic analysis approach (Braun and Clarke, 2006 ) was applied 
for an overall categorization of all data. The first step of the analysis 
consisted in the coding of extracts in the interview transcripts following 
a preselected set of themes based on the research objectives. Data ex-
tracts demonstrating individual themes were collated together within 
the relevant codes. New themes and sub-themes were created based on 
patterns, concepts, and new revelations which emerged while coding the 
data. The full data corpus was coded for all themes. 
Interviews were individually coded by two researchers, both of 
which were present during the interviews. Analysis results were jointly 
refined, and categorisations finalised to ensure a common agreement on 
overarching key themes and sub-themes. 
2.3.2. Visualising distribution and relative importance for different groups 
of actors 
Following the thematic analysis, the identified barriers and success 
factors were allocated to five groups of actors. Every actor mentioning 
one of the barriers or success factors was counted and an overview was 
created showing the distribution and relative importance of the key 
themes for different groups of actors. Group size varied (see Table 1) due 
to limited reuse experience, few pilot projects focusing on reuse and 
availability of experienced actors in Norway. The number of responses 
was converted into a colour-coded chart based on the percentage of 
group members mentioning a certain barrier or success factor. 2.4. Definition 
During the interviews, no exact definition was offered by the in-
terviewers or interviewees when referring to "reuse of construction 
products and materials". The term "reuse" may therefore refer to one of 
the following options: (i) Reusing old products or materials for the same 
purpose with or without processing, (ii) repurposing products or mate-
rials with or without processing for an alternative function/use, (iii) 
repurposing damaged new products or materials for an alternative area 
of use, and (iv) preserving and lifetime extension of existing components 
and other structural or non-structural features in rehabilitation projects. 
3.Barriers and success factors for different groups of actors 
The following section summarises the findings from the interviews 
categorised under four main themes with a focus on different groups of 
actors and their perception, viewpoints, and experiences. Distribution 
and relative importance of barriers and success factors for individual 
actors is discussed on the background of conditions in Norwegian pilot 
projects, regulations and in the context of the existing literature. 
3.1. Key themes 
The thematic analysis of all 12 interviews resulted in four over-
arching key themes – each comprising a set of identified barriers and 
success factors concerning reuse of construction materials: (i) mindset 
and knowledge, (ii) reuse infrastructure, (iii) business framework and 
(iv) legal framework. The resulting thematic map representing main 
themes is presented in Fig. 1. 
Different actors tended to express the same factor in different ways, 
which made it sometimes difficult to clearly separate barriers from 
success factors. Some actors expressed an issue in form of a barrier, Table 1
