Indicators are necessary to track progress and domain for action on 
the transition towards CE in the BCDW management. The promotion of 
CE in any sector requires the deployment of monitoring and evaluation 
tools (indicators) to measure and assess progress. Indicators are usually 
adopted to measure construction industry performance towards circu-
larity in waste management. Table 4 presents the common indicators for 
BCDW used in existing studies. 
4.4. BCDW management circularity models 
Circular business models are considered essential to promoting the 
sustainable management of waste in the construction industry (Wuni 
and Shen, 2022 ). Adequate understanding of existing models on BCDW 
management in a CE is imperative in shifting from waste to wealth 
(treating BCDW as viable resources) in the construction industry. Also, 
various models related to CE developed in literature may be a veritable 
pathway to developing a circular business model. This is essential to-
wards closing the circularity gap in the construction industry. Therefore, 
proper integration and understanding of various existing models in 
literature may be useful to create and capture value while achieving 
sustainable production and consumption. This may eventually support 
the development of a holistic circular business model for the construc -
tion industry. Models in extant studies related to BCDW circularity are 
presented in Table 5. 
4.5. BCDW effective management operations in a CE in existing research 
studies 
Management operations are necessary for BCDW circularity in the 
construction industry. These operations are required to promote effec-
tive circularity (G´alvez-Martos et al., 2018 ). Understanding these op-
erations may be useful in establishing an innovative best management 
framework (Iodice et al., 2021 ) for BCDW circularity and flow in a close 
loop. This may enhance sustainable development in the consumption of 
resources in the construction sector. The BCDW management operations 
in a CE in existing studies are presented in Table 6. 
5.Future salient research areas 
These reviews show that CE adoption in construction projects is still 
emerging. Very few specific topics in CE adoption in construction have 
gained attention. More studies (Table 7) should be conducted to harvest 
CE’s full opportunities and potential in the construction industry. As 
numerous technicalities and processes exist for a successful CE adoption, 
hence, the research directions highlighted and discussed in the subsec -
tion (see Fig. 8) are imperative for a successful CE in BCDW 
management. 
5.1. Implementation of CE strategies in the construction sector 
CE is regarded as the pathway to cleaner and more efficient resources 
consumption with numerous potentials in the construction industry 
(Bilal et al., 2020 ). Realising these potentials of CE is pegged to under -
standing the various issues surrounding its implementation, especially 
in developing economies. Therefore, there are still many unanswered 
questions in adopting and implementing CE in the industry. CE adoption 
and its strategies cannot happen in isolation without considering the 
contextual issues, measures, and dynamism of factors surrounding it. 
Previous studies place more emphasis on the experimental aspect of CE. 
To date, several aspects of CE implementation have not been empirically 
evaluated, such as the – (i) dynamism of factors affecting CE strategies, 
(ii) measures for integrating CE strategies across the building lifecycle, 
and (iii) contextual parameters for implementing CE-based on the 
economy (developing/developed) and stakeholders. Investigating these B.I. Oluleye et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 357 (2022) 131927
10issues critically by verifying the degree of the influence of the individual 
or combined would enhance CE adoption. 
5.2. Best practice framework for CE adoption 
Implementing CE strategies is usually possible by paying attention to 
the management practice to achieve success (Antwi-Afari et al., 2021 ; 
Hossain et al., 2020 ). The management practices help in designing a 
comprehensive framework for implementing CE on a global scale. But it 
is worrisome that till now, there is still a dearth of agreement on the 
appropriate CE framework that would guide construction and demoli -
tion waste management (Bilal et al., 2020 ). As construction practitioners 
rely more on an effective framework for better implementation of a 
process, future studies could consider developing best practice frame -
works (tools, guidance, and standards) for CE adoption and 
implementation. 
5.3. Circular lifecycle assessment indicators for building construction 
Studies on the lifecycle assessment of building construction waste are 
prominent in the literature. However, research efforts linking the life-
cycle assessment indicators for buildings in a CE are still scarce. Un-
derstanding these indicators may be a pointer for evaluating the 
circularity performance of every construction material at different levels 
in their respective lifecycle. Therefore, it is essential to conduct an 
exploratory study on the various lifecycle assessment indicators at the 
material extraction stage, manufacturing stage, logistics stage, and 
construction operation and demolition phase for building construction 
and demolition waste in CE. 
5.4. Application of technologies for CE in building construction and 
demolition waste 
The application of industry 4.0 technologies such as (artificial in-
telligence, blockchain, internet of Things, digital twin, additive 
manufacturing) in CE for construction and demolition waste mini-
misation is still limited as well as the research efforts (Rajput and Singh, 
2019 ). Without innovative technologies, a smooth circularity in the in-
dustry would be truncated. Recently, industry 4.0 technologies have 
emerged as a key roadmap to facilitate a shift from a wasteful economy 
(linear economy) to a sustainable economy (circular economy) in the 
industrial sector (Norouzi et al., 2021 ). Furthermore, one of the best 
ways to promote sustainable development goals is to link CE and in-
dustry 4.0 together, especially in the construction industry, across the 
building lifecycle (Chauhan et al., 2021 ; Dantas et al., 2021 ). With Table 4

5.5. Circular business models for building construction and demolition 
waste 
The existing business models in the construction and demolition 
sector still have their foundation firmly standing on the linear economy. 
There is a dearth of a coherent and suitable business model for circu-
larity in construction and demolition (Govindan and Hasanagic, 2018 ). 
Many studies suggested adopting a cradle-to-cradle model as a 
replacement for the business model for CE in construction (Hossain 
et al., 2020 ). This model has failed with myriads of challenges such as 
inadequate standards on product refurbishment, weak economic in-
centives, an inappropriate trade back system, and life cycle cost. There is 
a pressing need to expedite research on CE by developing a compre -
hensive and sustainable business model for managing construction and 
demolition waste. This could be modification to the existing model, 
development of a holistic new business model, and a hybrid CE business 
model. Therefore, future research could develop a new model or 
improve existing models towards circularity of BCDW. 
5.6. Circular economy knowledge management systems 
Knowledge is a great weapon that could bring about innovative 
change in any organization (Ghasemi and Valmohammadi, 2021 ). 
Creating, sharing, and managing knowledge is imperative to attain this 
change. However, there has not been comprehensive knowledge man-
agement of CE in the construction industry over the years. There has 
been limited active research linking knowledge management to a CE. 
More so, many construction industries in the developing and developed 
economies are still in the dark about what could be done to promote CE 
(Mahpour, 2018 ). This is because of their lack of awareness and inef-
fective knowledge management practice for CE. Therefore, with 
knowledge management being a veritable tool to create awareness and 
improve understanding (Ghasemi and Valmohammadi, 2021 ), more 
research is needed to investigate the best way knowledge management 
could help improve CE with attention to the people, process, content, and strategies across the building lifecycle stages. 
5.7. Intelligent decision support systems for circular economy in 
minimising building construction and demolition waste 
Research on intelligent decision support systems (DSS) for circularity 
in construction and demolition waste management is scanty. The need 
for a DSS is imperative in a CE as it will help ascertain the best alter-
native solutions to any given problem in a close loop. A DSS could be 
designed for predicting waste generated and procurement in a circular 
economy. With the significance of the DSS to motivate the construction 
practitioners to opt for circularity decisions. Hence, the development of 
an intelligent decision support system for CE in construction and de-
molition waste minimisation is needed in future. 
6.Conclusions 
Circular economy is poised to make a tremendous impact in facili -
tating sustainable production and consumption and waste management 
in the construction industry. To unravel the trend of CE research in 
BCDW, a mixed-method review was adopted. This review approach was 
important to overcome the loopholes in adopting qualitative or quan-
titative reviews independently. Extant literature on CE in BCDW was 
analysed to reveal the research pattern and existing pulsating argu-
ments. This helps in creating the knowledge gap for future research. This 
study presents key research topics, CE indicators in BCDW management, 
BCDW and CE management strategies, challenges of BCDW manage -
ment in a CE, and the knowledge gaps to guide future studies. It was 
found that previous studies adopted the experimental research type as 
the most used in CE research for BCDW management. Moreover, the CE 
strategies adoption have gained attention in the literature as the best 
way to minimise BCDW. 
This study has provided valuable insight into CE adoption in the 
management of BCDW by analysing the recent literature to promote CE 
practicability and sustainable consumption in the construction industry. 
The findings of this study have set the path for future studies by 
providing future research directions in CE for BCDW management. This 
study explored the various BCDW from extant literature and the 
Fig. 8.Future research hot spots and opportunities.  B.I. Oluleye et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 357 (2022) 131927
13appropriate circularity strategies. This would be a valuable reference 
point for practitioners to understand the categories of BCDW and the 
suitability of CE strategies. Practitioners and policymakers may use the 
identified CE indicators and effective BCDW management operations to 
monitor progress and action towards CE transition in BCDW manage -
ment. The identified probable challenges may be used by practitioners to 
understand the bottlenecks on the road to CE. Hence, potential solutions 
can be understood. The existing models for BCDW in a CE revealed in 
this study may be useful in extending knowledge towards developing the 
CE business model for the construction industry. For all construction 
stakeholders, the implementation of CE in BCDW management would 
represent key progress towards sustainable consumption. Based on the 
findings and analysis of the study, future research should consider smart 
circularity of BCDW management, intelligent decision support system 
for CE in BCDW management, and circular business model development 
for BCDW. Also, with the role of knowledge in promoting CE, knowledge 
management in a CE needs to be investigated. Best-practice framework 
for CE adoption and lifecycle assessment indicators are the grey areas 
that may be considered for further investigation. 
Despite its substantial contributions, this study has limitations that 
should be considered when interpreting the findings. Only papers ob-
tained from the Scopus database were used in the analysis, which may have influenced the coverage of publications in the subject topic. 
Furthermore, the scope of this study was restricted to academic papers. 
In the future, studies may integrate different databases and document 
sources. The terms used for the search may be biased, and so may not 
provide a complete view of the study field. In future investigations, these 
keywords may be modified.

Circular economy in the built environment: A systematic literature review 
and definition of the circular construction concept 
Felipe Ossio*, Carlos Salinas, H´ector Hern ´andez 
Escuela de Construcci ´on Civil, Facultad de Ingeniería, Pontificia Universidad Cat´olica de Chile, Avda. Vicu˜na Mackenna 4860, Santiago, Chile   
ARTICLE INFO  
Handling Editor: Cecilia Maria Villas Bˆoas de 
Almeida  
Keywords: 
Circular construction 
Circular design 
Construction and demolition waste 
management 
R framework or strategies 
Life cycle assessment 
Circular business model or networks ABSTRACT  
The Circular Economy (CE) has become increasingly important across various industries. It challenges the 
traditional take-make-dispose approach and aims to maximize economic value while reducing waste. However, 
the construction industry is still in the early stages of adopting this concept, and a clear and unified definition is 
needed for Circular Construction (CC) in the built environment. Without a comprehensive understanding, the CE 
principles and practices may be misapplied, leading to inefficiencies. To address this, a Systematic Literature 
Review of 316 publications was conducted to bridge knowledge gaps and to propose a definition for CC. The 
study identified five clusters of conceptual affinities and nine attributes that contributed to the CC definition. The 
results suggest that the CC concept is mainly related to the conceptual affinities of Construction and Demolition 
Waste Management (CDWM) and the “R" strategies, that the environment is prioritized over economic and social 
aspects, and that CC research focuses on building over other infrastructures, especially on aspects of building 
disassembly and reversibility. Still, despite these advances, most research lacks a holistic view of the application 
of the concept. Practitioners looking to promote cleaner construction practices can benefit from this study ’s 
valuable insights, helping to guide decision-making and prevent the misuse of the circular economy concept in 
the built environment.   
1.Introduction 
The urgency of the climate crisis and its implications for the popu -
lation have driven significant changes in resource use, production, and 
economic activity (Menegaki and Damigos, 2018 ; UNEP, 2021 ). How-
ever, the Construction Industry (CI) has a lousy diagnosis regarding 
resource use, waste generation, carbon emissions, and energy use 
worldwide. The CI is responsible for approximately 40% of natural 
resource depletion and 25% of global waste (Kaza et al., 2018 ; Teh et al., 
2018 ), making it the third-largest per capita daily waste generation at 
1.68 kg per person per day (Kaza et al., 2018 ). Moreover, about 35% of 
all Construction and Demolition Waste (CDW) worldwide ends up in 
landfills without proper treatment (Menegaki and Damigos, 2018 ). This 
is in a context where circularity is 8.6% worldwide (Circle Economy, 
2022 ), and it is estimated that 57% of the materials ’ total value is lost, 
although knowing these materials could be revalued (Enkvist et al., 
2022 ). Furthermore, the CI accounts for 36% of energy consumption and 
37% of CO2 energy-related emissions (UNEP, 2021 ). These statistics 
have pushed the CI to seek changes in its practices and redefine concepts such as Circular Construction to become more sustainable. 
Sustainability in the CI encompasses threefold results. The first is 
conservation, care, and resilience in the environment. The second has to 
do with equity and social justice. The third deals with feasibility and 
economic gains (Vogt and Weber, 2019 ). Thus, “Achieving sustainability 
in the construction sector is complex, due to its enormous nature ” (Mhatre 
et al., 2021 ). However, to deal with this complexity, it is affirmed that 
the Circular Economy (CE) is a preliminary conditioning step for an 
activity to be sustainable (Geissdoerfer et al., 2017 ). 
CE has been increasingly studied as a viable alternative to the 
obsolete linear “make-use-dispose ” economy, particularly in recent 
years (Joensuu et al., 2020 ; van Stijn et al., 2021 ).

However, to deal with this complexity, it is affirmed that 
the Circular Economy (CE) is a preliminary conditioning step for an 
activity to be sustainable (Geissdoerfer et al., 2017 ). 
CE has been increasingly studied as a viable alternative to the 
obsolete linear “make-use-dispose ” economy, particularly in recent 
years (Joensuu et al., 2020 ; van Stijn et al., 2021 ). This has allowed 
arising of generally accepted and mutually similar definitions of CE, 
adapted to particular industrial contexts (Benachio et al., 2020 ; Nobre 
and Tavares, 2021 ). For example, a study in which were analyzed 114 
definitions of circular economics concluded that CE is defined as an 
economic system that replaces the concept of limited shelf life with the 
“R” strategies applied to materials in the various processes of produc -
tion, distribution, and consumption, operating across macro-action

2levels (country, city, region), meso-action levels (eco-industrial parks) 
and micro levels (products, companies, consumers) to achieve sustain -
able development by creating new business models and instilling con-
sumer responsibility (Kirchherr et al., 2017). Another study approached 
various contributions over the years toward strengthening the concept 
of CE, defining it as a regenerative system where the intake and waste of 
resources, emissions, and energy leaks are minimized by slowing down, 
closing, and tightening materials and energy cycles, which can be ach-
ieved via enduring design, maintenance, repairs, reuse, re-fabrication, 
restoration, and recycling (Geissdoerfer et al., 2017). 
Circularity in CI is closely related to the CE approach proposed and 
developed by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation (Nobre and Tavares, 
2021). This approach can help the building sector reduce its environ -
mental footprint and waste while avoiding cost increases, delays, and 
other consequences of volatile commodity markets (Akhimien et al., 
2021). In this context, buildings should be designed to reduce waste and 
pollution while promoting the reuse of construction products and ma-
terials, and facilitating the regeneration of natural systems, in line with 
the CE principles outlined by (Ellen MacArthur Foundation, 2019b). 
Thus, Circular Construction (CC) can be comprehended in connection 
with the EC principles applied in the built environment, going beyond 
the green buildings focused on technology and environmental concerns 
or the sustainable buildings focused additionally on the economic and 
societal dimensions. The circular buildings that prioritize stakeholder 
support and behavior (government, clients, suppliers, and constructors, 
among others) (Pomponi and Moncaster, 2017) are designed to embrace 
circular principles and provide closing resource loops at different 
buildings’ spatial-temporal levels (ARUP, 2016). This not only reflects 
that CE in construction is complex but also dynamic in nature, as it is 
necessary to consider and integrate technical, social, economic, envi-
ronmental, behavioral, spatial, and temporal aspects (Papastamoulis 
et al., 2021; Pomponi and Moncaster, 2017; Yu et al., 2022). 
Numerous studies conducted on CE focus mainly on short -and 
medium-lifespan consumer products (Adams et al., 2017), which 
definitively ignores an industry whose final product has a long-term 
scope, such as a building. Unlike what happens, for example, with a 
bottle, building investments and their sustainable impacts throughout 
their lifecycle, such as waste generation, extend beyond the short or 
medium term (Silvestre et al., 2014). In addition, buildings are usually 
one-off projects with an extensive supply chain that only increases 
complexity (Benachio et al., 2020), for what has been proposed that 
more standardized and Industrialized Construction (IC) would be 
conducive to circularity (O’Grady et al., 2021). Therefore, it is necessary 
to understand and conceptualize CE in the CI by considering its complex 
nature and current developments to achieve its consistent and holistic 
adoption (Eberhardt et al., 2022). This is especially relevant in products 
such as buildings that require a systematic perspective at various scales 
(element, building, neighborhood) (Antonini et al., 2020) and at 
different layers (System, Site, Structure, Skin, Services, Space, Stuff) to 
analyze its circularity (ARUP, 2016); where buildings as a whole, or 
either their components or materials, have multiple potential uses and 
additional lifecycles to add value to what is now waste (Malabi Eber-
hardt et al., 2020). From this perspective, the Buildings As Material 
Banks (BAMB) Project promotes buildings’ circularity by creating cir-
cular solutions where valuable materials are recovered or recycled, 
fewer virgin resources are used, and buildings follow reversible designs 
(Durmisevic, 2018). This is based on the fact that, in the future, it will be 
increasingly challenging to extract virgin materials due to 
sustainable-related impacts and the increasing scarcity of resources 
(Wuni, 2022).

This is based on the fact that, in the future, it will be 
increasingly challenging to extract virgin materials due to 
sustainable-related impacts and the increasing scarcity of resources 
(Wuni, 2022). Therefore, present and future buildings must be seen as a 
“material bank”, in which buildings need to be easy to disassemble or 
deconstruct to take their components or elements as “technical nutri-
ents” according to EC principles for being employed in new buildings 
(Ellen MacArthur Foundation, 2019b; Heinrich and Lang, 2019). 
Congruently, buildings should be designed for longevity, adaptability, 
out waste, deconstructability, and reusability, and by selecting circular materials, in which waste should be considered valuable (Cheshire, 
2019), using circular technologies that can provide durability, 
compatibility, and reversibility through building service life (Antonini 
et al., 2020). 
CE definition applied to the CI varies and occurs at different con-
struction project lifecycle stages; therefore, speaking about CC is very 
common but very non-convergent, finding different meanings in the 
literature according to each author’s understanding (Murray et al., 
2017). Some authors associate CE understanding with materials use that 
follows the circular production concept, others view it as a concept that 
influences the entire project’s life cycle during the design phase, and 
others see it solely with a focus on the proper Construction and Demo -
lition Waste Management (CDWM) (Hossain et al., 2020; Yu et al., 
2022). This last a more limited viewpoint can lead to the failure of CC, as 
reuse, recycling, or recovery measures in the CE philosophy (“Rs” 
framework) (Nobre and Tavares, 2021) depend on the given context in 
which they are applied and may only be appropriate in some cases 
(Ghisellini et al., 2016). In line with this, when discussing barriers to 
adopting CE in the CI, the need for a comprehensive understanding of 
the concept and its benefits is often raised (Charef et al., 2021; Mahpour, 
2018; Oluleye et al., 2022; Wuni, 2022). 
As mentioned before, resource use optimization (less waste) and 
technology application for pursuing efficiency in the IC context is 
related to CE in the built environment; however, this relationship has yet 
to be addressed. Nevertheless, some authors have defined their 
connection to the “Disassembly” concept, which can be defined as the 
systematic separation of constituent parts of a product at its End-of-Life 
(EoL) through a series of operations, allowing construction to meet the 
CE principles (Sergio et al., 2022). Moreover, employing technologies 
such as Building Information Modelling (BIM) significantly increases 
project optimization potential throughout its lifecycle (Xue et al., 2021). 
This is through a process of cyber-physical interaction between design 
and manufacturing that enables the disassembly of the building ele-
ments at the EoL, allowing to retain the building parts to their reman -
ufacture or re-use (Viscuso, 2021). Moreover, attention should be paid 
to the fact that the CE in the CI aims to reduce the building’s lifecycle 
waste generated, an objective that is similar to when the use of con-
struction resources is optimized by applying better management prac-
tices such as Lean Construction principles; therefore, this managerial 
aspect linked with CE should be explored and better studied to 
conceptualize the CC (Benachio et al., 2020, 2021; Sergio et al., 2021). 
Research seeking to conceptualize CE in construction has been con-
ducted, but some knowledge gaps still need to be filled (Anastasiades 
et al., 2020; Nobre and Tavares, 2021; Oluleye et al., 2022). Moreover, a 
unified definition of CC that can ensure the correct direction of public 
policies or corporate strategies performed in this area is still missing.

Research seeking to conceptualize CE in construction has been con-
ducted, but some knowledge gaps still need to be filled (Anastasiades 
et al., 2020; Nobre and Tavares, 2021; Oluleye et al., 2022). Moreover, a 
unified definition of CC that can ensure the correct direction of public 
policies or corporate strategies performed in this area is still missing. 
Addressing this lack can avoid misinterpretations and misuses of the 
concept that can lead to unexpected and erroneous results, creating false 
security and a sense of effectiveness (Chen et al., 2022; Yu et al., 2022), 
and unconsciously fall into greenwashing even when Industrial Symbi -
osis (IS) approach – cross-industry waste valorization, where waste or 
by-products of one industry are valorized for another industry (Çimen, 
2021) – can be applied (Joensuu et al., 2020; Nobre and Tavares, 2021). 
Consequently, to address this problem, the main objective of this 
study is to propose a definition for the concept of circular construction 
(CC) by analyzing the spectrum in which the term has been used in the 
literature and its evolution in recent years by conducting a Systematic 
Literature Review (SLR). For this, publications documenting the 
conceptualization of CC and its affinity with other concepts and strate -
gies were analyzed. The outlined significance and contributions of this 
research are as follows. 
-It provides valuable insights by analyzing clusters of conceptual af-
finities related to the CC concept, a theme that has not yet been 
adequately addressed. Five key related concepts were examined, 
namely: 1) the “R" framework or strategies, 2) CDW management F. Ossio et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 414 (2023) 137738
3(CDWM), 3) Building Design Approaches (BDAs), 4) CE business 
models or networks, and 5) Life Cycle Assessment (LCA).  
- It helps to bridge knowledge gaps and offers a concise explanation of 
the circular construction concept. It also helps to address the issue of 
a lack of standardized and unified definitions. 
-It offers insights to practitioners looking to promote cleaner con-
struction practices, helping to align and guide decision-making while 
avoiding the misuse of the circular economy concept in the built 
environment. 
The study is organized into five sections: Section Two provides an 
overview of the previous literature review addressing CE research in the 
built environment, which helps to contextualize the CC research areas 
and clarify the contributions of this study. Section Three presents the 
methodology for responding to the study ’s primary objective and the 
SLR’s steps. Section Four presents and analyzes the results around five 
clusters of conceptual affinities and a sixth considered analysis of pub-
lications that did not meet the SLR inclusion criteria. Section Four offers 
a general discussion and a proposed definition of the CC concept. Section 
Five presents the study ’s conclusions, future research paths, and 
limitations. 
2.Previous literature review studies 
Several literature reviews related to CE in the built environment have 
been published. Most address CE knowledge gaps in the CI by applying 
different review methods, perspectives, or research areas to contribute 
to the CC conceptualization. However, they do not set out an explicit 
definition for CC. Most authors agree that there is a lack of a standard 
and unified definition of CE in the built environment, which is necessary 
since each industry applies the concept of CE according to its own 
business and production context (Anastasiades et al., 2020 ; Benachio 
et al., 2020 ; Nobre and Tavares, 2021 ; Oluleye et al., 2022 ). The 
“Journal of Cleaner Production ” concentrates the largest number of ar-
ticles on the subject, followed by the “Resources, Conservation and 
Recycling ” journal (Munaro et al., 2020 ; Oluleye et al., 2022 ). According 
to these previous reviews, Table 1 groups selected literature reviews that 
addressed a specific focus or particular perspective of CE in the built 
environment. Table 2 groups those studies that covered wider research 
areas for the CE conceptualization in the CI. 
The findings presented in Tables 1 and 2 reveal that past literature 
reviews on sustainable practices in the built environment are primarily 
centered in the “Journal of Cleaner Production. ” Additionally, these 
reviews tend to focus on the research areas of CDWM and Rs strategies. 
Based on the covered areas and their findings, it is clear that evaluating 
CE in the CI requires a comprehensive and multidimensional approach. 
Moreover, there are opportunities from the manufacturing sector to be 
applied in the IC to achieve higher circularity, such as remanufacturing, 
IS, PPS, and innovative business and supply chain models. Furthermore, 
in the circularity assessments, attention is on the lifecycle and mainly on 
the environmental impacts, evidencing more necessity for addressing 
economic and social approaches. Similarly, it is essential to utilize tools 
and technologies and implement CE policies to facilitate the shift to-
wards a circular built environment. This should involve considering 
various aspects such as materials, components, buildings, cities, and 
areas, as well as their interconnections and overall perspective. 
Additionally, in addressing the conceptualization of CE in the built 
environment, several research areas have been covered that promote or 
apply CE principles; among them can be mentioned Modern Methods of 
Construction (MMC), use of OSC techniques, circular designs approach, 
CDWM, assessment methodologies such as LCC or LCA, RHSM, “Rs” 
strategies, circular materials and products, circular practices at different 
scales, tools or technologies to support CE, circular patterns in the 
project ’s stages or lifecycle, green supply chain and logistics, CI, CE 
applied practices from the manufacturing sector, lean thinking and lean 
management, CE policies, and circular behavioral or social rules. Table 1

5steps outlined by (Morse, 2004). The CC concept was identified by 
analyzing data clusters from the literature that shared common themes 
or areas of research. These clusters were thoroughly characterized and 
analyzed in subsection 4.4. Once the features of each group were iden-
tified, it was possible to define the boundaries and attributes for the 
circular construction concept. This process culminated in the develop -
ment of a proposed definition for the concept, which is detailed in 
subsection 4.5. 
The SLR was conducted by searching the Scopus database for sci-
entific peer-reviewed academic journal publications related to CC and 
CE in the built environment. An SLR was adopted because it is the most 
robust, widely accepted, and trustworthy auditable methodology to 
provide an overview of previous evidence on a particular topic of in-
terest. It systematically evaluates and interprets prior literature based on 
particular research objectives and questions (Grant and Booth, 2009; 
Jalonen, 2011; Pati and Lorusso, 2018). 
The number of steps involved in an SLR can differ greatly, ranging 
from five according to (Khan et al., 2003) to as many as 16 according to 
(Pati and Lorusso, 2018). Despite this, they can be set as follows: 1) 
Initial review to frame the problem, questions, and objectives to be 
addressed; 2) Establishing inclusion and exclusion criteria to be 
considered in the review, stipulating a priori what determines the 
eligibility of studies, 3) Establishing strategies to obtain the studies, 
according to which databases will be selected, and performing the 
comprehensive search to identify the relevant studies, 4) Assessment of 
the quality of included studies to eligibility and report those excluded 
that do not meet the pre-established criteria; 5) Collecting data ac-
cording to how it will be obtained 6) Analysis of data collected and Table 2 (continued )

6extracted from the included research according to objectives pursued; 7) 
Presentation and synthesis of the findings; 8) Reporting and transparent 
the methodology and methods conducted in the review (Aromataris and 
Pearson, 2014 ; Benachio et al., 2020 ; Khan et al., 2003 ). This study 
followed this protocol, where publications were systematically coded 
according to clusters that defined a conceptual affiliation with the CC 
concept, allowing the development of the proposed definition for CC. 
3.1. Methodology steps 
To begin the SLR, the first step involved defining the problem, 
research questions, and primary objective to be addressed. Section 1 
highlights the problem of knowledge gaps and the lack of a standardized 
definition pertaining to CE in the built environment, which is further 
addressed in Section 2. Accordingly, the research question is: How can 
CC be defined based on conceptual affinities areas that involve CE in the 
built environment? And the objective is to propose a definition of CC 
according to the analysis of these theme areas. In the second step, 
criteria of inclusion and exclusion have been identified, mainly publi -
cations that used concepts of CE in the built environment. Moreover, 
articles must be contextualized in CC, meaning publications will not be 
considered if they perform chemical material analyses, mechanical 
validations of waste usage, or discuss industries apart from construction. 
The following step was to select publications from the Scopus database 
using three combinations of search operators and Boolean operators as 
follows.  
1. Circularity AND Construction  
2. Circular economy AND Construction  3. Circular AND Construction 
Searches for the operators ’ combinations were set so that they would 
be performed within the articles ’ titles, their keywords, and the abstract. 
The maximum search timeframe was also shortened, focusing on studies 
during the last decade. This will cover the timespan from 2013 to 2022. 
It should be noted that the results were obtained only one month into 
2022 (see Fig. 2). A total of 14038 publications were obtained (see 
Fig. 1, stage 1). In the next step, the quality of included studies to 
eligibility was assessed. Those who were excluded and did not meet the 
criteria were reported. This was based on peer-reviewed articles and

Fig. 2.Publications distribution by year (*R2 represents the reliance of

Journal of Cleaner Production 414 (2023) 137738
7those that meet the criteria for scientific publication. By applying 
criteria, publications were reduced to 1708 (see Table 3). After dupli -
cates were eliminated, this left 808 valuable articles for review (see 
Fig. 1). A final screening was done according to the details described by 
the texts in their titles, abstracts, and keywords to evaluate eligibility; 
when more information was needed, the results and the publication’s 
conclusion were consulted. This led to 316 studies being included in the 
review. 
The following steps involved collecting and analyzing data according 
to research areas or focus. In this, publications were sorted based on how 
the term CC was applied or how the CE concept was related by authors to 
CI. This allowed the clustering of the publications reviewed into 
conceptual-related affinities. Five clusters were identified: The “R" 
framework or strategies, CDW management, Building Design Ap-
proaches (BDAs), CE business models or networks, and LCA. Since ar-
ticles may have more than one relationship to these clusters, these 
relations also were included in the analysis. Codifying belonging to the 
detected groups was generated to analyze these multiple relations. 
Additionally, those articles which did not apply to eligibility in the 
previous step were categorized as “not applicable” with a justification 
for their discard; these reasons were also analyzed. 
The review also included the country’s records according to which its 
primary author belongs to generate a geographical analysis of knowl -
edge production and identify gaps in the use and expansion of the CC 
concept across geographical areas. Also, articles were analyzed consid -
ering what type of construction infrastructure is related. To this, 
constructive works were classified as buildings (dwellings, offices, ho-
tels, among others) or infrastructure to reference other types of civil 
infrastructure such as bridges, roads, and tunnels, among others 
different from buildings. The findings were presented and synthesized 
according to previously established clusters and categorizations via ta-
bles and illustrative graphics to facilitate data management and analysis. 
Finally, at the second stage, a definition for CC was proposed based 
on the data clusters discussion and their characterization in subsection 
4.4. This delineated the conceptual boundaries and attributes, listed in 
subsection 4.5., that should be considered for addressing the CE’s 
conceptualization in the Built environment (Morse, 2004). The overall 
process conducted can be visualized in Fig. 1. 
4.Results and discussion 
This section comprises five subsections. The first presents the general 
results of the bibliographical review, which includes the categorization 
of articles, their year of publication, and their clustering and encoding 
according to the methodology used. The subsequent subsection illus-
trates the geographical distribution of publications and their categori -
zation by construction project type. The following subsection covers the 
analysis of publications by conceptual-affinity clustering, which in-
cludes an analysis of discarded articles. The last subsection presents a 
final discussion and the proposed definition of CC. 
4.1. General results 
4.1.1. Results from the screening process 
Table 3 shows the results obtained for each word combination ac-
cording to Boolean operators within the publication years’ restriction. 1708 publications were obtained overall, and after eliminating those 
duplicated, left a total of 808 valid research to be reviewed. The results 
by publication type category appear in Table 4. 
According to Table 4, the Fig. 2 shows the distribution of these 
publications by year, marking a rising trend confirming that the CE in 
the built environment is receiving attention and scientific interest. 
Of the 808 articles screened, 492 (61%) were non-applicable for the 
study as they did not fulfill the eligibility criteria described in the 
methodology. Therefore, 316 (39%) were part of this study. 
4.1.2. Publications clustered by conceptual-affinity 
After reviewing the articles, it became clear that there were five 
clusters with similar conceptual affinity. These clusters showed how the 
concept of CE was related to or applied in the built environment. The 
five clusters are explained and analyzed in section 4.4. Fig. 3 shows the 
relations of the 316 publications reviewed with one or more conceptual 
affinities. A total of 545 relations were identified, of which 169 were 
classified as exclusive affinity.

These clusters showed how the 
concept of CE was related to or applied in the built environment. The 
five clusters are explained and analyzed in section 4.4. Fig. 3 shows the 
relations of the 316 publications reviewed with one or more conceptual 
affinities. A total of 545 relations were identified, of which 169 were 
classified as exclusive affinity. The other 147 publications presented at 
least two conceptual affinities in the same article, with some showing all 
five. 
Articles with exclusive affinity are shown in Fig. 4. Results from 
Figs. 3 and 4 show that CC is mainly associated with CDWM and 
applying the “R” framework or strategies. 
The coding used to establish the relations among affinities in the 
publications without exclusive conceptual affinity is shown in Table 5, 
with a total of 17 combinations detected. Fig. 5 indicates the number of 
publications related to the 17 types of relations mentioned in Table 5. 
Fig. 5 shows that regrouped articles that combine the application of 
the “R framework or strategies” (R) with CDWM (G) is more relevant 
(27%), followed, with an adjusted difference, by the combination of 
BDAs (D) and LCA (C) (12%), and the quadruple combination of all the 
for ones mentioned above, i.e., RGDC (11%). It should be noted that only 
seven articles (5%) related to the five affinity clusters (RGDNC), 
evidencing a lack of a holistic approach in the research of CC. Moreover, 
only 18 articles combine four groups, and 126 leave out “business 
models or networks” (N). Since “business models or networks” (N) 
presented the lower exclusive conceptual affinity and frequency of 
combinations, it supports previous findings that highlight the impor -
tance of clarifying the connection between CE and business models in 
the CI (Munaro et al., 2020). 
In Fig. 5, a relevant proportion shows a distancing from waste 
management or “R" strategies, while solutions that allow for the integral 
management of construction components or materials are sought. 
However, these solutions are not always feasible given the series of 
features that must be fulfilled, with these components’ design being the 
most complex and fundamental (Cottafava and Ritzen, 2021; Durmi -
sevic, 2018). Design must be done based on repair, reuse, modernization 
(updating it for required needs), recycling, and dismantling (Bocken 
et al., 2016). The problem in this stage is that construction components 
or solutions must consider multiple life cycles for all components and the 
interchange rate between them to extend their service life (Wouterszoon 
Jansen et al., 2020), which is a challenging process. 
The preference for studying CDWM and the “R” framework strategies 
in CC indicates priority research to approaches implemented in two 
lifecycle stages of construction projects: construction and demolition or

(D) and LCA (C) lies in second place, indicating that the scientific

The results in Fig. 6 show the evolution of publications regarding the 
study clusters over time. The graph only goes up to 2021 since only the 
first month of 2022 was considered in the review. Fig. 6 shows that “R 
framework or strategies ” is the only one present from 2013 to the present, and 2018 was the first year in which all affinity clusters had at 
least one relation to CC. The trend from 2018 onwards is upward for all 
groups, with explosive interest from 2020 onwards. Finally, the “R 
framework or strategies ” and CDWM clusters have led from 2018 so far 
in the number of references per year in CC-related publications. 
4.2. Geographical results 
Fig. 7 shows the distribution of the articles by their country of origin. 
It shows that the top countries for articles that relate CE in the built 
environment are, in the first place, the United Kingdom (UK) with 34 
publications, Italy in second place with 31 articles, and China in third 
place with 24 papers. Spain is in fourth place; these four countries 
concentrate 35% of CC-related publications. Australia is the first country 
in Oceania, ranking sixth with 16 publications. In Latin America, Brazil 
ranks 8th out of 46, with 13 publications. Africa only appears at number 
34, with two countries providing one article each. A previous study 
showed that China led in CE research in the built environment, and the 
UK ranked third (Çimen, 2021 ); however, the UK in first place agrees 
with (Munaro et al., 2020 ) and (Benachio et al., 2020 ) reviews. This 
level could be related to the UK’s achievement in the use and develop -
ment of the BREEAM assessment scheme since the 90s (Lee, 2013 ; 
Leising et al., 2018 ), advances in IC (Jin et al., 2018 ) that promote ef-
ficiency and sustainability (Kamali and Hewage, 2016 ; Kedir and Hall, 
2021 ), and UK existing standards that help support market relationships 
and networks that can bring together common thinking on the nature of 
a CE at an elite policy level (Flynn et al., 2019 ). 
Fig. 8 shows that most publications reviewed come from Europe 
(64%), followed by Asia, which generated just 25% as much as Europe 
published. Oceania, North America, and South America contributed 
together with 19%. Meanwhile, Africa and Central America only 
contributed 1% of total publications. In other words, Europe and Asia 
lead the research, agreeing with a previous literature review (Osobajo 
et al., 2022 ). Europe ’s leadership can be explained by the presentation of 
the European Union Circular Economy Action Plan in 2015 at the Eu-
ropean Commission in Brussels, Belgium (McDowall et al., 2017 ). This 
plan mandated all government levels to transition to the CE within 
member countries in areas of production, consumption, and extraction, 
among productive activities, explicitly including construction and 
demolition. 
Two countries lead in Asia and South America. On the one hand, 
China accounted for about 50% of all articles from its continent. On the 
other hand, Brazil accounts for almost 70% of South American output. 
Both countries are in the BRICS group, an organization of 5 countries 
representing about 40% of the global economy and having greater de-
mographic density than their neighbors.

Two countries lead in Asia and South America. On the one hand, 
China accounted for about 50% of all articles from its continent. On the 
other hand, Brazil accounts for almost 70% of South American output. 
Both countries are in the BRICS group, an organization of 5 countries 
representing about 40% of the global economy and having greater de-
mographic density than their neighbors. For China, in particular, their 
higher publication number is due to government policy being applied, 
apart from the urgent need to maximize domestic resource use given 
their demographic growth and constant business expansion (Mhatre 
et al., 2021 ). Brazil shares the diagnosis which would explain its

4.3. Results by construction project type 
The results show a considerable gap between CE research in build -
ings and infrastructure. Fig. 9(b) shows that 296 articles (94%) focused 
on building in contrast to only 20 articles (6%) on infrastructure, highlighting the construction of roads and the construction of stadiums 
for the Qatar 2022 World Cup. 
Fig. 9(c) shows that nine publications in infrastructure (45%) were 
related to “R framework or strategies ” (R) exclusively, and the majority 
have an exclusive relation to a conceptual affinity. Moreover, no link 
was found with the “Business Models or Networks ” (N) group. This re-
flects a scarcity of CE studies in infrastructure and the lack of holistic 
approach research since few combinations of conceptual affinities are 
covered. This is not the case with buildings; see Fig. 9(a), which shows 
more diversity in conceptual-affinities relations, where most are related 
to the “R framework or strategies ” and CDWM. This last with higher 
exclusive association (19%). Only seven articles combined the five 
conceptual affinities (2%), and 155 publications (52%) associated an 
exclusive conceptual affinity. This reflects that the building research in 
EC that is more advanced than in infrastructure but still needs a more 
holistic view. 
Some matters to highlight include the proposal from (Vergoossen 
et al., 2022 ) to reuse prefabricated concrete beams from existing bridges 
in new bridges or overpasses, in which deconstruction and adaptation 
processes are described. There was also an article with a case study from 
port construction, which involves using contaminated dredged materials 
to build a port expansion using CE principles (Carpenter et al., 2018 ). 
Studies conducted on stadiums used during the 2022 World Cup 
included analyzing the life cycle of one of the stadiums, which was 
designed and built under a CC concept (Al-Hamrani et al., 2021 ). Also, a 
stadium was built based on unused shipping containers, which exem -
plifies applying CE principles by using other industries ’ wastes in con-
struction (Kucukvar et al., 2021 ).

More studies on the application of CC in these projects could help 
improve the conditions for projects to benefit communities by adding 
the environmental factor. 
4.4. Discussion by conceptual affinity clustering 
4.4.1. Cluster 1 – “R” framework or strategies (R) 
This cluster associates CC with applying the “R” framework or stra-
tegies with the materials and CDW generated during construction. The 
“R” framework does not have a clear origin (Kirchherr et al., 2017 ) but does have many studies that consider it. The aim is not to delve into the 
specifics of this framework, but to provide sufficient knowledge to un-
derstand what it is about, its connection with CC and how it has evolved. 
Three primary “Rs” are identified: Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle. The 
Reduce principle is directly associated with efficient production. It 
leaves consumer responsibility aside by defining it as minimizing the use 
of resources such as primary energy or raw materials and reducing waste 
via improved production efficiency. Reuse is any action allowing a 
product or its components to be reused for the purpose they were 
designed, which was discarded by another user. Finally, the Recycle 
principle refers to recovering materials from wastes, reprocessing them, 
and turning them into products, materials, or substances that are the 
same as the original purpose or for other ends (Ghisellini et al., 2016 ).
