11The evolution of the “R” framework or strategies has led authors to 
add concepts up to as many as 10Rs (Kirchherr et al., 2017 ; K. M. Rahla 
et al., 2021 ). These go from R9 to R0 by increasing in circularity, moving 
from strategies that allow energy recovery and recycling towards those 
of greater circularity that promote extending the lifespan of products or 
their parts, such as reuse and repair, and beyond when more innovative 
production designs reduce or refuse materials consumption (Kirchherr 
et al., 2017 ). These “Rs” also are related to the waste hierarchy frame -
work in the CDW management practices (Zhang et al., 2022 ), evidencing 
the strong relation of CE with the CDW and the EoL stage in the building 
life cycle (Ghisellini et al., 2018 ; Heinrich and Lang, 2019 ; Ivanica et al., 
2022 ). The R framework is seen as the “11 R principles ” by (Çimen, 
2021 ), who introduces a new R to the previous 10Rs (Refuse, Rethink, 
Reduce, Reuse, Repair, Refurbish, Remanufacture, Repurpose, Recycle, 
and Recovery), termed “Replace, ” to establish the CE subject of “Sus-
tainable Material Replacement ” and defined it as “a new more sustainable 
material alternative is designed or manufacture to replace the existent ma-
terial ”. However, beyond arguing about the proper or most complete 
framework for the study, it has opted to use the main objective of the 
framework, which is to present principles for different phases in the life 
of a product, such as design, production, use, and EoL to facilitate 
multiple life cycles before being considered as waste (Sihvonen and 
Ritola, 2015 ). 
Recycling is among the most cited “R” strategies in the built envi-
ronment (Oluleye et al., 2022 ). However, recycling is at the bottom of 
the waste management hierarchy since it is necessary to consider its 
cost-effectiveness, energy consumption, energy-related carbon emis-
sions, downcycling, and opportunity costs of recycling (Hern ´andez et al., 
2023 ; Zhang et al., 2022 ). 
Consequently, re-introducing the materials and building parts in the 
loop for a higher value and upcycling potential is crucial to meet CE 
principles (K. M. Rahla et al., 2021 ). If technical cycles for the optimi -
zation of the use of resources in the built environment, such as recycling, 
reuse, repair, refurbishment, or energy recovery, do not apply, biolog -
ical cycles should be considered (Munaro et al., 2020 ; K. Rahla et al., 
2021 ); in which buildings ’ materials and components should be biode -
gradable or compostable, providing the ability to buildings ’ elements to 
degrading or disintegrating into natural substances (Antonini et al., 
2020 ; K. M. Rahla et al., 2021 ). 
4.4.2. Cluster 2 – CDW management (G) 
This cluster connects the CC with the proper management of CDW. 
Unlike the “R” framework, the CDW pyramid prioritizes waste man-
agement through five stages, starting with the most favorable “preven -
tion” and ending with the least desirable “disposal ” (Zhang et al., 2022 ). 
This pyramid arose in 1979 within the framework of discussing waste 
management policy in Holland. It was proposed by Ad Lansink and 
christened the “Lansink scale. ” Lansink suggested that all wastes should 
be managed in order of five preferences, allowing four options before the 
waste wound up in a landfill (Vogtl ¨ander et al., 2001 ). The following is 
the original waste hierarchy proposed by Lansink (Zhang et al., 2022 ).  
1. Reuse the product  
2. Reuse the materials of the product  
3. Incineration with energy recovery  
4. Incineration without energy recovery  
5.

The following is 
the original waste hierarchy proposed by Lansink (Zhang et al., 2022 ).  
1. Reuse the product  
2. Reuse the materials of the product  
3. Incineration with energy recovery  
4. Incineration without energy recovery  
5. Landfill disposal 
This hierarchy has evolved, incorporating aspects such as preven -
tion, conservation, recycling, or clever designs (refuse, rethink, and 
redesign); currently, several waste hierarchy has been proposed that can 
either include the designer and waste manager as an influencer or “non- 
waste ” and “waste ” dimensions (Zhang et al., 2022 ). 
One of the most detailed evolutions took place in 2000 and is an 
exclusive hierarchy for the construction sector. It contains ten steps and 
is called the Delft Ladder (Hendricks and Dorsthorst, 2001 ). Its main objective is to improve waste handling effectiveness, reduce environ -
mental impact, mitigate resource exhaustion, and minimize waste pro-
duction (Williams, 2015 ). New waste treatment technologies and 
options justify the waste hierarchy ’s further adaptions (Zhang et al., 
2022 ). However, their applicability depends on factors that include, 
among others, energy level or other economic resources required, the 
construction techniques used, policies and regulations, and the aware -
ness and properly built environment to be applied the waste strategies; if 
negative, it is increased complexity and kept strategies from thriving. 
The waste hierarchy has been studied by many researchers, whether 
to recapitulate the achieved advances or to innovate on newer, more 
complex, and complete pyramids. In the CI, these have been used in 
various public policies and strategies worldwide for the CDWM. 
Although more than one hierarchy exists, the basis for its uses is 
ensuring an order of priorities to properly and responsibly manage 
wastes arising from any productive activity. 
Studies have discussed that CDW can be quantity and costly reduced 
by applying techniques from Lean Construction management and MMC, 
especially when using OSC techniques (Hern ´andez et al., 2023 ; Kedir 
and Hall, 2019 ; Omotayo et al., 2019 ; Razkenari et al., 2020 ). Congru -
ently, waste reduction by applying lean construction practices is 
considered a relevant objective of adopting CE strategies in the con-
struction industry (Chen et al., 2022 ). 
Economic incentives and effective regulation determine the quantity 
of CDW (Calvo et al., 2014 ). Thus, the performance of CDWM needs to 
be measured, in which waste reduction, from the “Rs” strategies, is the 
optimal measure since it has the lowest adverse impacts on the envi-
ronment (Huang et al., 2018 ). EU Action Plan for the CE establishes 
standards to be implemented throughout lifecycle stages (from design to 
waste management) (Villoria S´aez and Osmani, 2019 ), mainly at the 
macro level where metrics are well developed (Rinc´on-Moreno et al., 
2021 ). This allows tracking the performance and progress of CE models. 
However, measuring the performance of CE practices in companies is 
not common; indicators for measuring at the micro level are still needed, 
and metrics at different levels (product, company, and region) do not 
follow a standard (Rinc´on-Moreno et al., 2021 ) as well as holistic ap-
proaches covering micro, meso y macro levels (Cottafava and Ritzen, 
2021 ). Thus, lacking holistic and standard metrics to track EC progress is 
still challenging. Two indicators that relate to CDW management and 
the “R” framework are the material circularity indicator (MCI) (Ellen 
MacArthur Foundation, 2019a ) and the circular transition indicators 
(CTI) (WBCSD, 2022 ). Both have been applied and adapted to the CI to 
evaluate circularity in the built environment (Cottafava and Ritzen, 
2021 ; Dr¨ager et al., 2022 ; Heisel and Rau-Oberhuber, 2020 ; Hern ´andez 
et al., 2023 ). 
4.4.3. Cluster 3 – Buildings design approaches (BDAs) (D) 
This group primarily relates the concept of CC with design strategies 
such as reversible building design (RBD) and other circular design ap-
proaches.

4.4.3. Cluster 3 – Buildings design approaches (BDAs) (D) 
This group primarily relates the concept of CC with design strategies 
such as reversible building design (RBD) and other circular design ap-
proaches. The RBD associates different design phase strategies, which 
allow a building to have additional use opportunities before disassembly 
(Klinge et al., 2019 ). Within the RBD, various strategies focus on 
lengthening building service life. For this, multiple scopes are consid -
ered for its use, understanding that there is more than one way for the 
building ’s lifespan to end (economic, technical, or functional). This 
design suggests applying different types of methods to achieve the goal 
of reversibility. The first is design for longevity, in which a building is 
designed in harmony with the environment to provide a structure that 
can adapt to changing uses and has durable building material that aids in 
its maintenance and upgrading (Sassi, 2004 ). 
There are adaptive and disassembly design approaches. The first 
considers the changing demand or use of the building as a primary factor 
to modify it efficiently without great effort. This leads to the promotion 
of generic and standard systems as an inspirational resource for design, 
which facilitates and helps to reuse the existing built environment (Galle 
et al., 2019 ). The second approach is used when there is no possibility F. Ossio et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 414 (2023) 137738
12that the building can be reused either in its original form or by adapting 
it, leaving only the option of demolition. This method is intended so 
that, during its deconstruction, it can be subdivided into its primary 
components so that they can be revalued by using them to create new 
elements or recycle them appropriately. It is an alternative to the linear 
practice of materials in the built environment (Akanbi et al., 2019 ). 
16 Design Qualities for a CE and 24 Design Principles for design 
change have been developed by Vrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB) 
Architectural Engineering (Cambier et al., 2020 ). These are valuable 
guides for establishing a circular mindset and inspiring circular designs 
(Antonini et al., 2020 ; Askar et al., 2022 ; Cambier et al., 2020 ). Circu -
larity must be addressed in a project ’s early design and planning stages 
to predict potential changes and reuse of resources in the building design 
life to prove adaptability and disassembly (Dams et al., 2021 ). 
The circular BDAs – are those that follow the CE principles such as 
regenerate, share, optimize, loop, virtualize, and exchange (Manninen 
et al., 2018 ; Prendeville et al., 2018 ) and can be applied to any industrial 
sector (Tedesco et al., 2022 ) – affects the built environment at different 
scales (element, building, neighborhood, cities or region) or systemic 
levels (micro, meso or macro) positively (Antonini et al., 2020 ; ARUP, 
2016 ; Nobre and Tavares, 2021 ). It should be noted that there is no 
consensus about what is related to these levels, and even some authors 
establish a “Nano ” level related to materials (Khadim et al., 2022 ). 
Concerning the building scale, six layers – related to the “Six’S” di-
agram (Stuff, Services, Space, Skin, Structure, and Site) – have to be 
considered in the designs to achieve circularity; therefore, the elements 
that constitute these layers need to be durable and uniform, use pure 
materials instead of mixed, use accessible unions that favor disassembly 
and adaptability (dry and mechanical connections such as screws, bolts, 
dowels, and clamps) (Antonini et al., 2020 ; Dams et al., 2021 ). These 
layers relate different life spans (Dams et al., 2021 ) and material in-
formation and properties (qualitative and quantitative) that need to be 
managed through the building ’s lifecycle; for this, the BIM-based Ma-
terial Passport (MP) can be used to assess the circularity of materials 
embedded in buildings and handle the information about their circular 
opportunities among stakeholders (Atta et al., 2021 ; Honic et al., 
2019a ). Providing an MP database for buildings can help to assess and 
optimize CE strategies such as recycling and reuse through the build -
ing’s life cycle (Honic et al., 2019b ). However, there are still challenges 
in political, commercial, and social areas to be addressed for better 
collaboration between stakeholders (Benachio et al., 2020 ), which is it is 
recommended the alignment of EC’s policy synergy with the construc -
tion lifecycle and use of technologies to achieve transparency and a 
collaborative environment (.). 
Regarding at cities scale or the macro systemic level (global, na-
tional, regional, city), the urban metabolism concept arises to define a 
new urban framework termed circular urban metabolism (CUM), which 
encourages urban planners and policymakers to rethink urban infra-
structure and activities on it, to design and manage sustainable cities to 
targeting the sustainable development goals (SDGs) considering a co- 
designing along with communities (Kaviti Musango et al., 2020 ; 
Lucertini and Musco, 2020 ). In this line, previous research has estab -
lished that studies have predominantly focused on micro-level per-
spectives, existing a need to focus CE on macro levels such as cities 
(Çimen, 2021 ; Prendeville et al., 2018 ).

In this line, previous research has estab -
lished that studies have predominantly focused on micro-level per-
spectives, existing a need to focus CE on macro levels such as cities 
(Çimen, 2021 ; Prendeville et al., 2018 ). 
Some authors relate designs for circularity as “Design for X′′ap-
proaches (DfX), such as Design for Circularity (DfC), Design for Disas -
sembly (DfD), Design for Maintenance (DfM), Design for Adaptability 
(DfA), Design for Recovery (DfR), Design for Change (DfCh), Design for 
Deconstruction (DfD) among other (Askar et al., 2022 ; Charef et al., 
2022 ; Jiang, 2020 ), which mostly follow the waste hierarchy strategies 
(Charef et al., 2022 ). These approaches can provide life extension, 
ensure reasonable operational and maintenance costs, facilitate adapt -
ability and deconstruction, provide higher residual value and less waste 
at the EoL stage, and, as a consequence, yields environmental and eco-
nomic benefits (Adams et al., 2017 ; Akinade et al., 2015 ; Gallego-Schmid et al., 2020 ; Jiang, 2020 ). The needs, requirements, 
benefits, and impacts of these approaches for CC have been studied by 
(Charef et al., 2022 ). 
Several authors related IC practices with CE since waste reduction 
and other circular benefits are achieved (Benachio et al., 2020 ; Osobajo 
et al., 2022 ); however, approaches such as Design for Manufacturing and 
Assembly (DfMA) are not directly linked to EoL of buildings (Charef 
et al., 2022 ). This reflects a necessity to adopt strategies for Design for 
Manufacture, Assembly, and Disassembly (DfMAD). This approach 
moves from a wasteful linear model to a circular one by considering the 
EoL stage in the design. Thus, it relates the integrated construction 
process, the use of resources efficiency, the building design “as a prod-
uct” and process-oriented, the standardization, the material circularity, 
lean thinking, innovation, and the use of technology as critical aspects of 
promoting efficiency and sustainability through the building ’s lifecycle 
(Munaro et al., 2020 ; Podder et al., 2020 ; Qi et al., 2021 ; Ribeirinho 
et al., 2020 ; UNEP, 2021 ). Beyond being deconstructable, buildings that 
follow this DfMAD approach must also be durable and adaptable to 
respond to strategies for RBD (Durmisevic, 2018 ). Despite the relevance 
of the EoL stage, there is a lack of incentives for designing buildings for 
dismantling and reuse, representing a significant challenge (Munaro 
et al., 2020 ). 
4.4.4. Cluster 4 – Business models or networks (N) 
This group associates the term CC with implementing business 
models or networks that favor circularity in the CI and the interrelation 
and integration of its practitioners. The differentiation between sus-
tainable and conventional business models lies in integrating concepts, 
principles, or objectives aimed at sustainability, adding sustainability to 
their value propositions, creative activities, deliveries, and value capture 
mechanisms (Geissdoerfer et al., 2018 ). Sustainable business models 
have been categorized into eight archetypes; for each, their “value 
proposition, ” “value creation and delivery, ” and “value capture ” are 
stated (Bocken et al., 2014 ). These can be used as exemplars for com-
panies in the CI that want to create or run new sustainable business 
model ideas. 
The companies that gain CE benefits through sustainable business 
models and innovation practices along the lifecycle of their products 
enjoy a “circular advantage ” that allows them to add value to their 
products and a competitive advantage in front of their competitors. 
(Lacy and Rutqvist, 2015 ). This value added is related to Lean Con-
struction principles such as “reduce the share of non-value-adding ac-
tivities ” or “Increase output value through systematic consideration of 
customer requirements ”; the interactions between Lean Construction 
principles and CE practices in the Built environment were studied by 
(Benachio et al., 2021 ).

(Lacy and Rutqvist, 2015 ). This value added is related to Lean Con-
struction principles such as “reduce the share of non-value-adding ac-
tivities ” or “Increase output value through systematic consideration of 
customer requirements ”; the interactions between Lean Construction 
principles and CE practices in the Built environment were studied by 
(Benachio et al., 2021 ). 
A circular business model transitions from the sustainable business 
model, which provides solutions for sustainability, by promoting closing 
resource loops, intensifying resource loops, slowing resource loops, 
dematerializing resource loops, and narrowing resource loops (Geiss -
doerfer et al., 2018 ). This is achieved through different product or ser-
vice design strategies, such as shortening resource cycles by using 
long-life goods to extend product life, closing resource loops through 
recycling to enable a circular flow of resources, and reducing resource 
flows by optimizing resource use per product, among others (Bocken 
et al., 2016 ). 
Studies established that CE in the built environment business oper-
ations needs to be considered a contributor to cost reduction in the 
construction life cycle (Osobajo et al., 2022 ). The Life Cycle Cost (LCC) is 
an economical technique used in the building sector to assess all costs 
from cradle-to-grave (construction, operation, maintenance, and EoL 
costs) or over a selected period to support decision-making based on the 
present value of total cost (Wouterszoon Jansen et al., 2020 ). Therefore, 
LCC has to be seen as a financial enabler of EC (Hart et al., 2019 ), where 
building projects ’ costs can be reduced considering material circularity, 
the durability of materials, reduction in maintenance, and higher F. Ossio et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 414 (2023) 137738
13residual value, among other requirements to circular construction 
products (Jiang, 2020 ; Wouterszoon Jansen et al., 2020 ). 
To encourage the EC business models, a frequent barrier is the 
insufficient understanding of CE benefits in the built environment and 
the lack of objective data evidencing these benefits (ARUP, 2016 ; Olu-
leye et al., 2022 ; Wuni, 2022 ). There is a consensus on the lack of tools 
and indicators for assessing the benefits of circularity in buildings that 
must be addressed (Askar et al., 2022 ; Munaro et al., 2020 ). 
Decoupling economic growth from resource consumption challenges 
circular business models (Çimen, 2021 ). The product-service system 
(PSS) business model that focuses on selling services and performance 
along with the products to fulfill customers ’ needs and promote CE has 
been proposed to address this (Joensuu et al., 2020 ; Kjaer et al., 2019 ; 
Michelini et al., 2017 ). Several studies have explored the economic 
benefits of using PSS for building equipment (Charef et al., 2022 ) or the 
sustainable benefits of an end-user and service-centered approach to 
infrastructure operation (Knoeri et al., 2016 ). In modular building, some 
critical features derived from the leasing model can support the CE in the 
built environment since modules can be added or removed to provide 
building adaptability and usability (Kyr¨o et al., 2019 ). 
Combining physical products with services can increase value in the 
construction industry (Andersson and Lessing, 2019 ) and provides in-
centives to stakeholders to implement CE principles through new busi-
ness models (Azc´arate-Aguerre et al., 2018 ), in which green supply 
chain practices and CE principles applying helps in the reduction of 
resources consumption and carbon emissions (Çimen, 2021 ; Munaro 
et al., 2020 ). However, this can be not easy due to fragmentation that 
exists in the supply chain, along the projects ’ lifecycle, within the project 
team (owner, designer, engineer, constructor, and operator), and be-
tween projects (Andersson and Lessing, 2019 ; Charef and Lu, 2021 ; 
Sawhney et al., 2020 ). To address the lack of integration and encourage 
construction sustainably, emerging technologies in industrialized con-
struction will provide solutions (Qi et al., 2021 ), mainly based on the 
construction 4.0 framework (Sawhney et al., 2020 ). This evidence a 
need for information and communication technologies (ICT) to support 
CE transition (Yu et al., 2022 ). BIM is critical in applying CE strategies 
and business model innovations (Chen et al., 2022 ). Also, it can be in-
tegrated with approaches such as PPS (Fargnoli et al., 2019 ) and LCA to 
promote CE in the built environment (Xue et al., 2021 ). 
In building projects, thinking early or “front-end ” is critical to 
achieving circularity (Dams et al., 2021 ) and project success in terms of 
sustainability (Sanchez and Haas, 2018 ). Thus, (Sanchez and Haas, 
2018 ) argue that capital projects should migrate to CE and propose a 
capital project planning framework for closed-loop cycle construction 
projects. 
With these backgrounds, this cluster understands CC as a business 
network that includes stakeholders immersed in circular business 
models to contribute to sustainable business practices (Murray et al., 
2017 ). In this context, the creation, delivery, and capture of value in the 
construction value chain are subject to and framed in principles of 
circularity (Munaro et al., 2020 ). That is, all strategies that the com-
panies or organizations perform must include the goal of falling under 
the umbrella of circularity. 
4.4.5. Cluster 5 – Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) (C) 
This group connects the CC with applying LCA to construction pro-
jects. LCA is a methodology governed by various organizations, 
including ISO (International Standardization Organization) or CEN 
(European Committee for Standardization) (van Stijn et al., 2021 ).

4.4.5. Cluster 5 – Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) (C) 
This group connects the CC with applying LCA to construction pro-
jects. LCA is a methodology governed by various organizations, 
including ISO (International Standardization Organization) or CEN 
(European Committee for Standardization) (van Stijn et al., 2021 ). It 
seeks to analyze resource use across the life cycle of a project, indicating 
the inefficiencies and environmental impacts and considering the 
number of resources needed to build and deliver the final product, and 
seeks to analyze resource use across the life cycle of a project, indicating 
the inefficiencies and environmental impacts and considering the 
number of resources needed to build and deliver the final product 
(Genovese et al., 2017 ). Given their rigidity, many products or services cannot adjust to it when performing an LCA on their entire processes. 
Moreover, if products have multiple life cycles, ISO regulations cannot 
cover more than one (Suhariyanto et al., 2017 ). A 2016 study identified 
some shortfalls within the LCA framework, such as a lack of guidelines 
for repaired products by returning them to a quality standard equal to or 
better than the original (re-manufactured products) or for re-fabricated 
products (Peters, 2016 ). Furthermore, product LCA can also not evaluate 
how technological innovation affects the system of products with mul-
tiple life cycles since this aspect is generally not considered in the 
analysis (Suhariyanto et al., 2017 ). 
The multi-cycling perspective and value retention of CE could be 
included within the methods or tools currently in use, such as the LCA 
method or those typically based on multi-criterion assessment, such as 
LEED, BREEAM, or DGNB (Romano and Riediger, 2019 ), avoiding the 
use of additional procedures and supporting the transition of CI towards 
to CC (Antonini et al., 2020 ; Malabi Eberhardt et al., 2020 ). 
Despite previous, some models have been presented to correct these 
limitations and allow for greater synergy between the concepts of CE 
and LCA. For instance, (van Stijn et al., 2021 ) adapted LCA standards 
and proposed a CE-LCA model by identifying gaps and requirements 
considering CE principles. 
LCA of construction products (building components) – that relates to 
environmental product declarations (EPD) (Sparrevik et al., 2021 ) – or 
of buildings themselves entails a dynamic cradle-to-cradle CE scope 
(Hossain et al., 2020 ; Oluleye et al., 2022 ), going beyond the boundaries 
of one building ’ lifecycle in which are considered the benefits and loads 
related to reuse, recovery, and recycling potentials (Hernandez et al., 
2019 ). 
The recycling of CDW, such as recycled aggregate, is the most 
prominent in the LCA (Oluleye et al., 2022 ). Researchers performed an 
LCA in which CDW (concrete and masonry debris) were used in road 
construction, showing that transportation and leaching of oxyanions 
resulted in relevant nontoxic and toxic impacts, respectively (Butera 
et al., 2015 ). 
A commonly used approach combines LCA with LCC to assess CE 
projects or building designs in CDW management (Lovren ˇci´c Butkovi ´c 
et al., 2023 ). Using this approach, (Di Maria et al., 2018 ) analyzed the 
environmental and economic drivers of four scenarios for CDW man-
agement, resulting in the “landfilling ” scenario having the highest 
environmental impacts and total economic costs. Other approaches are 
those that relate CE adoption using LCA and BIM-based, e.g., (Akanbi 
et al., 2018 ) developed a BIM-based Whole-life Performance Estimator 
(BWPE) for assessing the salvage performance of buildings ’ structural 
components right from the design stage, considering the amount of 
reusable and recyclable materials. 
4.4.6. Articles that did not apply to the study 
During the bibliographic reviews, it was observed that a significant 
number of articles did not meet the eligibility criteria described in the 
methodology section (492 articles, equal to 61%), and hence were not 
relevant for the study. However, these articles shared an element in 
common.

4.4.6. Articles that did not apply to the study 
During the bibliographic reviews, it was observed that a significant 
number of articles did not meet the eligibility criteria described in the 
methodology section (492 articles, equal to 61%), and hence were not 
relevant for the study. However, these articles shared an element in 
common. They are all circular strategies directly related to raw con-
struction materials, such as cement, concrete, bricks, bituminous mix-
tures, asphalt, aggregates, plasters, mortars, and ceramic materials. This 
mainly involves incorporating waste products from the CI or other in-
dustries into materials that can either partially or completely substitute 
the original material. Examples are semi-hot asphalt mix with a high 
RAP (recycled asphalt pavement) content (Pasandín et al., 2020 ), using 
glass wastes in cement (Nodehi and Mohamad Taghvaee, 2022 ) or even 
using coffee wastes in the mortar (La Scalia et al., 2021 ; Saeli et al., 
2022 ). 
Although this group of articles did not meet the necessary conditions 
to be considered valid for the study, they were included as a study group 
alongside the previous five. This is due to their common characteristic of 
incorporating waste products in the manufacturing of raw materials. A 
total of 109 articles were referenced in this group, surpassing the F. Ossio et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 414 (2023) 137738
14number of publications in three of the analyzed clusters (BDAs, LCA, and 
business models or networks). 
Including this new group does not necessarily imply that CC means 
adding circular elements to raw materials used in the construction 
process. This is because the CC concept, as studied, is based on the ac-
tivity itself, beyond the origin of the materials used in the productive 
process. This means that a construction project using materials with 
circular characteristics and not implementing circular strategies within 
its life cycle will only be that. By contrast, a construction project using 
materials with circular features and implementing circular strategies 
across its lifespan will genuinely strengthen the CC concept. With this 
clarification, it is established that these references are in the orbit of CC 
and that far from harming the concept, they contribute to diversifying 
circular strategies that aid in understanding what CC is. 
It must be clarified that increasing circularity will not automatically 
lead to more sustainable buildings since using waste as a resource for 
other productive processes will not guarantee reductions in the related 
environmental impacts (Antwi-Afari et al., 2021 ; Zink and Geyer, 2017 ). 
This can be related to the CE “rebound effect, ” which can reduce the 
environmental benefits when CE practices, which have minor 
per-unit-production impacts, also cause augmented levels of production 
or relate a limited ability of the “secondary products ” to substitute the 
primary ones, affecting, e.g., duration or prices, therefore, increasing 
and shifting consumption (Zink and Geyer, 2017 ). 
4.5. A final discussion and circular construction proposed definition 
Most authors agree that there is a lack of a standard and unified 
definition for the CE in the built environment since few focus on the CI, 
and each industry address and applies the CE concept according to its 
own business and production context (Anastasiades et al., 2020 ; Bena-
chio et al., 020; Nobre and Tavares, 2021 ; Oluleye et al., 2022 ), which 
can conducive misunderstanding and misapplying CE practices, e.g., 
“the lack of understanding the difference between several terms such as de-
molition, deconstruction, and design for deconstruction (DfD) is considered 
as one of the main causes of waste generatio n” (Atta et al., 2021 ). 
Most literature cited the definition and principles of CE from Ellen 
McArthur Foundation (EMF), which published several reports promot -
ing CE in society, addressing its opportunities and benefits. Applying 
these principles, it is crucial to use techniques and technologies, such as 
MMC or BIM, to keep construction materials, products, or components in 
use and obtain their highest utility and value across their lifecycles, 
distinguishing between those relying on technical and biological cycles 
(Nobre and Tavares, 2021 ; K. M. Rahla et al., 2021 ). Thus, the CE 
principles that should be transferred to the CI, as 1) design “infrastruc -
ture” out waste and pollution, 2) keep “construction ” products and 
materials in use, and 3) “Build ” to regenerate natural systems (Ellen 
MacArthur Foundation, 2019a ). 
The data collected was mainly related to the environmental 
approach, followed by the economic aspects. The most frequent factors 
related to these approaches were closing loops and value recovery, 
reducing waste and pollution, and achieving efficiency at cost and 
resource use. Scarce data was collected related to social perspective, 
evidencing there is insufficient attention to social aspects in the CC, 
opening, as well as for LCC and LCA, opportunities to apply the Social 
LCA (S-LCA) methodology into the built environment (Dong and Ng, 
2015 ). 
Although the many benefits identified to the adoption of CE in 
construction, many barriers hinder its adoption; up to 95 barriers were 
identified, classified into cultural, market, knowledge, financial, man-
agement, regulatory, technological, supply chain, stakeholder, tech-
nical, and organizational barriers (Wuni, 2022 ). These hinders can be 
addressed by CE enablers (Nobre and Tavares, 2021 ) or by factors that 
facilitate the CE adoption in construction; 64 factors have been identi -
fied clustered into three related categories: organizational, political and 
procedural, and technical (Charef and Lu, 2021 ).

These hinders can be 
addressed by CE enablers (Nobre and Tavares, 2021 ) or by factors that 
facilitate the CE adoption in construction; 64 factors have been identi -
fied clustered into three related categories: organizational, political and 
procedural, and technical (Charef and Lu, 2021 ). It is highlighted that the adoption of CE in the CI need to be assessed 
from a “multidimensional ” approach, in which principal dimensions 
seem to be related to, firstly, “a time reference ” such as projects stages, 
lifespan, or lifecycle (preconstruction, construction, operation and 
maintenance, and EoL), second, the “application of CE principles ” to 
buildings or infrastructure designs, subjects, or construction products or 
materials, and third, a “scales or systematic levels ” where EC principles 
are applied (Çimen, 2021 ; Hern ´andez et al., 2023 ). 
Based on the previous sections ’ findings, a comprehensive definition 
of CC should consist of nine distinctive attributes. 
1.CC is a paradigm or philosophy, a fundamental way in which “pro-
duction ” in the CI must target zero waste and pollution through the 
lifecycles of materials and construction components.  
2. CC is based on applying CE principles in the design of buildings and 
infrastructure, which enables retaining materials and construction 
components in use, maximizing economic value retention, designing 
out waste and pollution, and encouraging the regeneration of natural 
systems. It highlights that making design correct decisions from the 
earliest stages of projects is critical to achieving higher circularity, 
and the stakeholders should be aware of it.  
3. CC comprises economical, sustainable, and social goals to build 
sustainably and efficiently and the methods or philosophies that 
allow it and foster a holistic and integrated construction project 
view.  
4. CC comprises economic value retention in a multi-cycling lifespan 
perspective at different scales (material, element, building, neigh -
borhood, cities, and region) or systematic levels (micro, meso, 
macro). 
5.CC favors projects integration and alignment at different levels, be-
tween stakeholders, between projects (gather past data for contin -
uous improvement), within projects (owner, designer, engineer, 
constructor, and operator should be aligned), and through the pro-
jects (all life cycle stages should be considered).  
6. CC seizes opportunities from CE enablers in the built environment. 
Some enablers are technology (those related to construction 4.0 
framework, with a core in BIM technology), business models (those 
that provide economy, collaboration, transparency, sharing, and 
servitization), measurement and management techniques (such as 
lean construction or continuous improvement), currently sustainable 
tools or methods in use (those related to assessment methods such 
LCA, LCC, S-LCA or those base in the multi-criterion assessment such 
BREEAM, LEED or DGNB), government and politics (it defines reg-
ulations, standards, enforcements, agreements, cooperation, and 
policymaking), supply chain and market places (essential to the 
company to achieve efficiency in the construction process and client 
satisfaction), and bodies of knowledge (those that provides data and 
information to apply the CE principles in the CI, such as universities, 
foundations or other kinds of organization that can give it).  
7. CC departs from the traditional “take-make-dispose ” production 
approach and instead seeks to emulate nature ’s cycle, where the 
conclusion of one “life” provides nutrients for the next one, resulting 
in no waste. Achieving this involves implementing biological and 
technical closure loops, which CC prioritizes.  
8. CC is closely linked to the implementation of the Rs framework or 
strategies, as well as the waste hierarchy for effective CDWM. It is 
crucial to consider the lifecycles of infrastructure components for 
efficient waste management.  
9. CC is the multidimensional approach, in which the construction 
projects ’ life cycle, CE principles application, and different scales or 
systemic levels in which they are applied are dimensions that enable 
assessing the circularity in the CI. 
Based on prior attributes, the authors propose the following defini -
tion for CC: “Circular Construction is a multidimensional and dynamic 
economic system for construction based on the application of Circular F. Ossio et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 414 (2023) 137738
15Economy principles. It aims to achieve buildings and infrastructure designs 
considering different systemic levels (micro, meso, and macro) to achieve a 
built environment that targets zero waste and pollution. It allows construction 
materials and products to remain in use, retaining their maximum value by 
following biological or technical looping strategies through and within the 
whole life cycle of construction projects. This approach operates in a sus-
tainable, clean, and renewable way, allowing for the regeneration of natural 
systems. It is enabled by a context defined by technology, management sys-
tems, government policies and regulations, business models, and social and 
stakeholder behavior that enable construction needs to be met sustainably." 
The research findings and proposed definition enable construction 
organization managers and leaders to develop a clear and shared vision 
for adopting CC practices in their projects and operations. This involves 
understanding the potential benefits, setting measurable goals and ob-
jectives, and allocating the necessary resources. Moreover, the results 
invite fostering collaborative work and knowledge sharing since the 
successful adoption of CC requires collaboration among the stake -
holders, including owners, designers, builders, and suppliers. Therefore, 
fostering collaboration and knowledge sharing among these actors is 
essential, taking advantage of ICT and breaking down projects’ exoge -
nous barriers in which regulations and public policies play a crucial role. 
Finally, in light of the results, it enables the construction maker- 
decision to establish critical indicators related to CC that follow the 
principles of the CE. This will allow them to assess the impact of their 
practices, identify improvement areas and make informed decisions to 
optimize circularity in their projects and operations. 
5.Conclusions 
A unified concept of CC positively affects the result and development 
of applying CE in the CI, along with steering it toward sustainability. The 
main objective of this paper was to propose a definition for CC by 
analyzing the spectrum in which the concept has been used since 2013 in 
research. 316 publications were reviewed, primarily concentrated in 
Europe and Asia. The findings were clustered into five conceptual af-
finities, allowing the authors to conceptualize the CE in the built envi-
ronment and provide a comprehensive and multidimensional vision of 
CC. This made it possible to propose a definition of CC. 
CC is a multidimensional and dynamic concept that has fed off 
various strategic concepts, theories, and research themes in its orbit, 
which have been classified into six in section 4.4. From these groups, it is 
possible to distinguish two focused on the construction and decon -
struction stages within the construction project lifecycle (“R” and “G” 
conceptual affinities, in sections 4.4.1 and 4.4.2). Two others focused on 
applying the CE to construction by considering the whole project life-
cycle, from design to deconstruction or demolition (“D” and “C” con-
ceptual affinities, in sections 4.4.3 and 4.4.5). The fifth is focused on the 
business, networks, supply chain, and contractual relationships between 
practitioners (“N” conceptual affinity). Finally, the group addressed in 
section 4.4.6 does not seek a construction product to become circular but 
introduces circular products or services within the service life stages. 
Additionally, the two DBAs (“D”) and LCA (“C”) clusters seek to 
make construction projects circular, understanding that all life cycle 
stages contribute to circularity, especially preconstruction and EoL 
phases. This conception is the most complete and adjusted to the concept 
of CC since it understands that infrastructure can be viewed as product- 
based, whose production processes allow early planning and design 
actions to achieve efficiency and sustainability throughout the project 
lifecycle. This does not mean these approaches should be chosen over 
the others since it is known that is required and holistic and integrated 
approach. For instance, CDWM strategies must be applied in the con-
struction and demolition stages and R strategies in the design, consid -
ering business models or networks that promote CE in it. However, it is 
possible to speak of CC when all the efforts are framed within these two 
approaches so that the project will be developed by focusing on the life 
cycles of the final product or the multiple cycles of their parts. The articles not included (section 4.4.6) reveal research that focuses 
not on the construction project being circular but on adding value by 
considering circular strategies, such as recycling, to construction prod-
ucts.

However, it is 
possible to speak of CC when all the efforts are framed within these two 
approaches so that the project will be developed by focusing on the life 
cycles of the final product or the multiple cycles of their parts. The articles not included (section 4.4.6) reveal research that focuses 
not on the construction project being circular but on adding value by 
considering circular strategies, such as recycling, to construction prod-
ucts. However, special care must be taken with this group since it can 
create a false certainty that a project is becoming circular. Thus, it can 
fall into greenwashing by ignorance rather than premeditation. There -
fore, it is reaffirmed that comprehending the CC concept allows for 
facing the challenge of implementing it correctly and raising the 
discourse level of public policies to achieve agreements for adopting the 
EC in the built environment effectively. 
The CC concept evolves yearly and gains scientific relevance since CI 
is crucial in reducing environmental impacts. However, it shows ad-
vances considerably different between research areas and types of pro-
jects. The most relevant research areas addressed were the CDWM and 
“R framework or strategies,” followed by LCA and BDAs, and fewer those 
related to business models or networks. Though, last brings essential 
opportunities for benchmarking CE practices from the manufacturing 
industry into the CI. Concerning the type of projects, CE research is 
centered on buildings, and lesser was attended to other kinds of infra-
structure such as bridges, tunnels, or roads. Roads stand out since 
several CDW recycling materials have been incorporated into their 
pavement structure. Moreover, the diversity of CE themes addressed and 
related are much higher in buildings than in other infrastructure. 
Although, in buildings, a significant proportion of articles associated 
with an exclusive conceptual affinity according to the research themes 
addressed (52%), and few (2%) included all of them. This reflects that 
the building research in EC is more advanced than infrastructure but still 
needs a more integrated and holistic view. 
The CC seeks comprehensive strategies that promote the principles of 
circularity applicable to construction processes, avoiding leakage of 
opportunities to apply them. It is highlighted how other practices or 
methods that promote sustainability and efficiency, which currently 
coexist, such as industrialized construction, Lean construction, BIM, or 
LCA, can be added to these strategies for this purpose. It is possible to 
conclude that the CC advocates a systemic change in how construction 
projects are carried out, as well as how materials and products con-
struction are produced and used, inverting the model to construction 
patterns that close resource loops through their life cycle, and ques-
tioning the current paradigm of linear construction. 
CC is a concept that has yet to reach the mass adherence it needs, and 
it is expected that the findings of this study can help disseminate the 
concept and impact sustainably and efficiently the construction sector 
and provides guidelines to policymakers. 
5.1. Future research and limitations 
The study pointed out gaps that must be closed, which are a niche for 
future studies. These include going deeper into studies that cover the CC 
in infrastructure projects different than buildings. There is also a need to 
research the CC in continents apart from Europe, especially in countries 
in Africa, Asia, and America, to identify how current construction 
methods can adjust their techniques to tend to circularity. Moreover, the 
CE opportunities from the manufacturing sector to be applied in the CI to 
achieve higher circularity need to be investigated, as well as their 
business model and supply chain practices that foster circularity. 
Moreover, several authors established the importance of metrics to 
assess CC, and metrics have been proposed and studied; still, few articles 
link to the current measurement methodologies applied in the 
manufacturing sector to the CI. 
Investigating social-related aspects also is needed. For instance, 
research the integration or relationship between Corporate Social Re-
sponsibility (CSR) and the CE in the built environment; these themes 
have been studied in other industries (Fortunati et al., 2020; Morea 
et al., 2021). Also, research on how the S-LCA method or RHSM relates 
to and fosters the CE in the CI. 
Furthermore, further research is necessary on expanding the DfMA F. Ossio et al.

Journal of Cleaner Production 414 (2023) 137738
16industrial approach towards a circular approach (DfMAD) to delve 
deeper into the realm of circular industrialized construction. It has been 
established how regulation and policies enable CC, but more research 
needs to develop global standards to promote a common language and 
practices for the CI. Attention also is required to systemic scales beyond 
materials and buildings, such as neighborhoods, areas, or cities. Tech-
nology is another area of research that needs to be investigated beyond 
BIM-based methods application, especially at the operation stage. 
Additionally, most CDWM is related to massive waste production, but 
research is needed on management strategies for small portions of CDW. 
Some limitations of the study are that selected publications were 
from just one database and used four English terms and just “AND ” as a 
Boolean operator, leaving aside other databases, possible articles ob-
tained by using other Boolean operators, publications in different lan-
guages, and available knowledge not necessary from academic fields 
such reports and guides. The terms used may also leave out various CC- 
related topics, e.g., developments in other industries that could link the 
CC status. Another limitation of the research is that the definition is a 
creation of the authors, based on the literature review that provided 
attributes that served as a skeleton to propose the definition of CC 
(Morse, 2004 ) without the scrutiny of other researchers or without 
including additional information beyond literature, such as interviews 
with experts to collect appraisals.

__data__.text:
From waste to resource management? Construction and demolition waste
management through the lens of institutional work
Rickard Anderssonaand Martine Busera,b
aDivision of Building Design, Department of Architecture and Civil Engineering, Chalmers University of Technology, Gothenburg,
Sweden;bDepartment of Business Development and Technology, Aarhus University, Herning, Denmark
ABSTRACT
The European Union has issued action plans to reduce the production of construction wasteand increase the reuse and recycling of materials in the hope of triggering a rapid transitiontowards a Circular Economy (CE). The management of construction and demolition waste, how-
ever, struggles to apply these measures. Our purpose, therefore, is to analyse how different
actors involved in the management of waste could contribute to transform existing practices so
that they respond to the shifting demands of legislation and support CE. To understand how
this transformation work is performed, we build on the concept of institutional work, which ena-bles us to describe how actors, rather than accepting institutions as permanent and immovable,
contribute to their development by creating, maintaining or disrupting the existing institution.
Drawing on qualitative research methods, we collected empirical data through 31 semi-struc-tured interviews, observations of meetings and site visits. Our results show that whereas the
production of waste is somewhat reduced, and the sorting of fractions improved, the institu-
tional work performed is not sufficient to translate sustainability into new economic values.
Although the work performed legitimizes CE principles and enables new initiatives, it mostly
fails to change normative associations and to define new rules of action that support CE.ARTICLE HISTORY
Received 29 January 2021
Accepted 20 May 2022
KEYWORDS
Circular Economy;construction and demolition
waste; institutional field;institutional work;sustainable agenda
Introduction
It is a common assumption that new legislation sup-
ported by societal and political concerns for the pro-tection of the environment should put pressure on
the construction industry and trigger transformation in
construction processes. Whereas the energy consump-tion of buildings has been considerably reduced,
building processes and handling of waste are still
heavy consumers of resources (Leising et al. 2018 ). In
the European Union, the industry is still responsible
for 25-35% of annually generated waste. After having
focussed on the reduction of waste and disposal atlandfills and the handling of hazardous materials, the
European Commission has recently proposed the
uptake of Circular Economy (CE). The EU Action Plan
for Circular Economy (European Commission 2015 ,
2020 ) has established general measures to support
this transition. It involves all stages of the product
cycle: from design, production and consumption to
waste management. It also includes the creation of amarket for the reuse of secondary raw materials.Accordingly, the construction sector needs to improve
and align its practices towards CE principles; existing
waste should be either reused or recycled and new
production of waste should either be avoided orreduced by optimization of material use and proc-esses (EU2020).
However, in practice, the potential for reducing
Construction and Demolition Waste (CDW) is yet to beachieved (Jin et al. 2019 ). In particular, it seems that
most of the construction companies have not yet
reached the expected level of reuse or recycling (S /C19aez
and Osmani 2019 ). Studies have identified a number
of barriers to explain this failure, such as the low qual-ity of CDW materials, inadequate legislation (Ghaffaret al. 2020 ), lack of public (Wang et al. 2019 ) and eco-
nomic incentives (Lu et al. 2019 ), scarce interest and
demand from clients (Polesie 2012 , Osmani and S /C19aez
2019 ), absence of managers ’commitment (Teo and
Loosemore 2001 ), negative attitudes towards reuse
practices (S /C19aez and Osmani 2019 ), lack of training
(Park and Tucker 2017 ), ineffective contract forms
(Ghaffar et al. 2020 ), shortage of space and
CONTACT Rickard Andersson rickande@chalmers.se Chalmers University of Technology, Sven Hultinsgata 6, SE-412 96 Gothenburg, Sweden
/C2232022 The Author(s).

__data__.text:
information on site (Sezer 2015 ). The situation is espe-
cially critical for Sweden, which has time and againbeen pointed out as performing poorly within CDW(Hall and Nguyen 2012 ,S/C19aez and Osmani 2019 ). To
overcome these barriers, a large number of academicstudies have provided recommendations as to howthe sector could improve by offering simulations or
models of life cycle analysis (Kucukvar et al. 2014
2016 ,R a/C20skovi/C19cet al. 2020 ), improvement of material
flow (Wu et al. 2019 ), adaptation of project planning
to circular economy (Sanchez and Haas 2018 ), diffu-
sion of best practices and supply chain optimization(G/C19alvez-Martos et al. 2018 ) and new business models
(Leising et al. 2018 , Paletta et al 2021 ). Academic stud-
ies also advice construction actors to comply withguidelines and implement one or more of the above-mentioned strategies to recycle waste constructionmaterials (Wu et al. 2019 ) or to optimize and reinforce
policies and guidelines (Ajayi et al. 2017 , Osmani and
S/C19aez2019 , Kabirifar et al. 2021 ).
Scholars working with sustainable transitions have
also criticized the top-down linear thinking whichassumes that the implementation of new legislativeframes is enough to trigger changes. They have under-lined that those governmental, national and locallegislations and incentives may not always be enoughto ensure the application of new directives (Geels2019 ). If sustainable goals must be achieved, there is
also a need to transform existing and often taken-for-
granted established ways of working (Grin et al. 2010 ).
So far, academic studies addressing practices, workand organization and adaptation towards CE remainscarce in CDW (Wu et al. 2019 ), and according to
authors (Kabirifar et al. 2020 , Oti-Sarpong et al. 2021 )
in urgent need to be developed.
In the present paper, we describe and analyse how
actors react to the forthcoming regulations and howtheir actions may contribute or not to the adoption ofnew practices and challenge the established ways ofworking in CDW management (CDWM). To do so, webuild on the concept of institutional work within thecontext of a field-level institution, namely that ofConstruction Waste. This enables us to obtain insightsinto some of the micro-dynamics of institutionalizationto further explore challenges of CDWM. We want toidentify which forms of institutional work are mobi-lized to maintain, create and possibly disrupt actualpractices and enable the principles of CE economy tobe applied (Lawrence et al. 2009 ). So, in this paper we
address the following research question: how does
institutional work contribute to a transformation ofthe Swedish CDW institutional field to enable align-
ment with the CE principles?
The transition to CE implies a transformation of the
organization of the sector and a new distribution of
roles between all actors (Geissdoerfer et al. 2017 ). To
understand how regulators, professionals, formal andinformal governance bodies, field-configuring eventsand organization norms and actors influence eachother and can contribute to the transition of CDWtowards CE principles, we need to conceptualize a
context which is larger than the single organization
and its network and adopt a middle range theory(Green and Schweber 2008 ). Our premise is that CDW
constitutes a field-level institution where actors sharea common understanding of formal and informal proc-esses, norms of conduct, contractual agreement and
taken-for-granted behaviours. This institution regulates
actors
’behaviours and actions in the given field and
simultaneously is shaped by these behaviours andactions (Hampel et al. 2017 ).
Drawing on a qualitative study of the main stake-
holders involved in CDWM, we investigate how institu-
tional work changes over time as actors positionthemselves to respond to the shifting demands oflegislation. We explore how the CDW field institutionmay be shaped under new circumstances by focussingon the ongoing efforts of actors seeking to reconcilecompeting agendas and possibly incompatible objec-
tives (Lawrence et al. 2011 ). The paper contributes to
a better understanding of the barriers to improvementof CDW management and the emerging dynamics topromote a sustainable agenda.

__data__.text:
We explore how the CDW field institutionmay be shaped under new circumstances by focussingon the ongoing efforts of actors seeking to reconcilecompeting agendas and possibly incompatible objec-
tives (Lawrence et al. 2011 ). The paper contributes to
a better understanding of the barriers to improvementof CDW management and the emerging dynamics topromote a sustainable agenda. Whereas waste man-agement has not been a prioritized topic in construc-tion management so far, the recent increased
attention given the Circular Economy principles has
the potential to transform the production and renova-tion of buildings (Adams et al. 2017 , Ghisellini et al.
2018 ). According to these principles, buildings should
be constructed with components and materials whichcan be redeemed and reused for new purposes at theend of the product ’s life cycle, which means that
materials should enter a new life instead of being dis-
carded and burnt (Ilic et al. 2018 ). CE promises an effi-
cient use of resources which would thereby reducethe environmental impact and overconsumption.However, studies in other sectors than constructionhave suggested that the transition to CE is not aligned
with conventional linear models of production and
therefore creates tension in organizations (Ilic et al.
2018 , Stål and Corvellec 2018 ).
Following upon the theoretical frame and the
method sections, we present the outcome of the478 R. ANDERSSON AND M. BUSER

__data__.text:
empirical data with an overview of the institution field
of CDWM and the ongoing changes within the legal
frame. Then, we analyse the different forms of identi-
fied institutional work in this environment and how
these contribute or not to the creation of a sustain-able CDW field before we draw conclusions.
The concept of institutional work
To study the adaptation of CDW Management to a
changing legislation frame, we adopt the lens of insti-
tutional theory, building on the concepts of institu-
tional field and institutional work (Greenwood et al.
2002 , Leca et al. 2009 ). Scott ( 2013 , p. 56) defined
institutions as comprising “regulative, normative, and
cultural-cognitive elements that, together with associ-
ated activities and resources, provide stability and
meaning to social life ”. Accordingly, Suddaby and
Greenwood specified ( 2009 , p. 176): “this institution
may take the form of juridical regulations, informal
rules or codified social arrangements, norms of con-
duct, or cognitive structures that provide understand-
ing and give meaning to social arrangements ”. These
institutions can be described as more or less taken-
for-granted repetitive social behaviours underpinned
by normative systems and cognitive understandings.
By giving meanings to social exchanges, these enable
the self-reproduction of social order (Greenwood et al.
2008 ,p .4 –5).
To connect the macro level of institutional theory
with the lived experience of actors, we rely on the
concept of institutional field. An institutional field rep-
resents an intermediate level between organization
and society and is instrumental to processes by which
socially constructed expectations and practices
become disseminated and reproduced (Scott 1994 ,
2014 ). It is defined as a community of organizations
that interact together “frequently and fatefully ”(Scott
2014 )i na “recognized area of institutional life ”
(DiMaggio and Powell 1983 ). Research on institutional
fields has developed a wide variety of insights (see
Zietsma et al. 2017 for a review). Scott describes a
field as “a collection of diverse, interdependent organi-
zations that participate in a common meaning system ”
(Scott 2014 , p. 106). According to Scott ( 2010 ) even if
the concept is related to that of “industry ”it does not
need to be defined by market criteria but can concern
any kind of involvement in a particular issue or policy
community. In essence “field”is an alternative to mar-
ket concepts (Scott 2010 ). The benefit of building on
the concept of field is the possibility to incorporate
field-level structures, participating organizations andthe actors working within and between these organi-
zations (Scott 2010 , p. 8). The structures include col-
lective interest organizations, regulators, informal
governance bodies, field-configuring events, status dif-ferentiators, organizational templates, categories orlabels and norms (Hinings et al. 2017 ). These establish
the boundaries of each community of organizations,
defining its membership, the appropriate ways of
behaving and the appropriate relationships betweenorganizational communities.
Whereas institutions and institutional field both
describe how social structures are reproduced, theconcept of institutional work focuses on understand-ing how actions affect institutions (Hampel et al.
2017 ). Extending work on institutional entrepreneur-
ship, institutional change and innovation, the study ofinstitutional work is concerned with the analysis and
categorization of practical actions through which insti-
tutions are created, maintained and disrupted andhow they may transform the organizational field(Lawrence et al. 2009 , Leca et al. 2009 ). The concept
enables us to study how actors rather than merelyaccepting and reproducing the existing CDWM institu-tional field, can contribute to its development.Accordingly, we can “explore the practices and proc-
esses associated with actors ’endeavours to build up,
tear down, elaborate, and contain institutions, as wellas amplify or suppress their effects ”(Hampel et al.
2017 , p. 3).

__data__.text:
2009 ). The concept
enables us to study how actors rather than merelyaccepting and reproducing the existing CDWM institu-tional field, can contribute to its development.Accordingly, we can “explore the practices and proc-
esses associated with actors ’endeavours to build up,
tear down, elaborate, and contain institutions, as wellas amplify or suppress their effects ”(Hampel et al.
2017 , p. 3). The concept also sheds light on the
dynamics of the institutionalization process where
individuals and groups of individuals both contribute
to reproducing the established institution whilst at thesame time enact change by challenging, modifyingand disrupting it through their everyday practices.Though these actions may be intended to either pre-serve or change the established practices withinorganizations, their outcomes may be more or lesssuccessful and lead to unintended adaptations andinstitutional consequences (Lawrence 2011 ). So, the
concept of institutional work contributes to define therole of agency in relation to institutions and to illus-trate the notion of embedded agency which describe
how actors whose thoughts and actions are con-
strained by institutions are nevertheless able towork to influence those institutions (Greenwoodet al. 2006 ).
In its original definition, institutional work is defined
as“the purposive action of individuals and organiza-
tions aimed at creating, maintaining and disruptinginstitutions ”(Lawrence and Suddaby 2006 , p. 215) and
highlights the how, why and when of this action tak-ing place (Lawrence et al. 2011 ). Individuals areCONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT AND ECONOMICS 479

__data__.text:
described as capable beings that both intentionally or
unintentionally influence their institutional settingthrough their behaviour, thoughts and feelings. Focus
is on the actors ’roles in the tension between continu-
ity and change in institutional work (Hampel et al.
2017 ). These actions may be very dramatic and highly
visible or just mundane and hardly noticeable acts
integrated in daily routines (Lawrence et al. 2009 ).
Individuals engaged in institutional work are either
absorbed in consciously and strategically reshaping
social situation or focussed on managing the exigen-cies of immediate situations to cope with institutional
change (Lawrence et al. 2011 ). Institutional work,
therefore, addresses the different types of actionswhich actors engage in to construct meaning, beliefs,
rules or standards and thereby shape the course of
institutional change. In their literature review,
Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 ) listed these actions
and, by building on similarities and differences, pro-duced three categories: maintaining, creating and dis-
rupting institutions. They divided institutional work
according to its intended outcomes rather than themeans used to achieve particular institutional objec-
tives (Hampel et al. 2017 ). Whereas many authors
have developed and extended the original list of insti-tutional work by defining their own reference frame
(Dahlmann and Grosvold 2017 , Hampel et al. 2017 ,
Lehmann et al. 2019 ), adding new dimensions such as
emotional and unconscious processes (Voronov and
Vince 2012 ) or the role of space (Siebert et al. 2017 ),
our purpose is rather to build on the existing concept
as a tool to identify and organize actors ’positions and
actions towards the changes initiated by the new reg-ulations (Beunen and Patterson 2019 ).
Maintaining institutions
To subsist, institutions need to be maintained. Actors
need to constantly preserve existing institutions intheir daily actions, either routinely and unintentionally,or by actively counteracting ongoing change or by
destabilization. Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 ) identi-
fied six distinct practices. Other scholars have addednew forms such as repair work (Heaphy 2013 ) and re-
enactment (Lok and De Rond 2013 ).
These practices involve the support, repair or re-
creation of mechanisms that ensure compliance
(Fuenfschilling and Truffer 2016 ).Table 1 presents a
list and definitions of the maintenance work identifiedby Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 ). In the context of cli-
mate change, the concept of maintenance has beenmobilized as a mechanism to explain the inertia ofinstitutions to address these challenges (Munck afRosensch €oldet al. 2014 ).
Creating institutions
Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 ) identified three types
of institutional work aimed at creating institutions:practices involving political work to bring about newregulations and policies or access to material; thereconfiguration of existing beliefs and meanings inorder to modify normative institutions and a change
of cognitive environment in accordance with the new
institution. The authors characterized these three typesin nine forms of institutional work aiming at creatinginstitutions (see Table 2 ). The commonality between
these forms is that they have the ability to create rulesas well as rewards and sanctions to enforce the newrules (Lawrence and Suddaby 2006 ). This implies that
specific actors hold positions in a given field which
legitimates their exercising this authority and actively
engaging in institutional work. Several new forms ofcreating work have been added to the nine originalones (Hampel et al. 2017 ). For example, specific to the
construction industry, see Lieftink et al. (2019 ) identi-
fied in a Dutch case three new types of what theycalled relational institutional work: awareness creation,selective networking and coalition building.Table 1. Maintenance work adapted from Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 ).

__data__.text:
Disrupting institutions
Institutions may be disrupted when actors find the
existing institutional setting not supportive of theiractivities and they tend to “redefine, recategorize,
reconfigure abstract, problematize and, generally,manipulate the social and symbolic boundaries thatconstitute institutions ”(Lawrence and Suddaby 2006 ,
see Table 3 ). Disrupting institutions consists of three
practices (Lawrence and Suddaby 2006 , p. 235): dis-
connecting sanctions by working through the stateapparatus to disconnect rewards and sanctions forsome sets of practices, technologies or rules; disassoci-ating moral foundations by disassociating the practice,rule or technology from its moral foundation as appro-priate within a specific cultural context and undermin-
ing assumptions and beliefs which means decreasing
the perceived risks of innovation and differentiationby undermining core assumptions. Disrupting an insti-tution is the less documented form of institutionalwork (Fuenfschilling and Truffer 2016 ), and for some
authors is sharing similar features with the creation ofinstitutions (Zvolska et al. 2019 )
Critics of the concept of institutional work have
underlined the broadness of the concept which risksbecoming meaningless as it includes all kind ofactions intentional or not. Alvesson and Spicer ( 2019 ,
p. 207) proposed a differentiation between what theycall plain old work, work inherent to the fulfilment ofdaily tasks, and the work of creating sets of rules,promoting a new model for an industry or criticizing
dominant ideas about a particular type of organization
which might count as “institutional work ”. In the pre-
sent paper, we try to follow their advice and focus on
institutional work related to maintenance, creation of
disruption of the actual CDW in relation to theexpected adaptations required by the transformation
of the legislative frame.
In many fields over the last 20 years, institutional
work has been largely mobilized, but it has made a
late entry in Construction Management (Bresnen 2017 ,
Chan 2018 ). Studies have focussed on, among other:
individuals developing environmental expertise in the
AEC industry, showing that even though the role ofenvironmental managers has been well established,
these struggle to transform the existing institution.
Their role is characterized by a short-time focus, whilstthe work of influencing institutions would necessitate
a long-term approach and the commitment of the line
managers to support their work (Gluch and Bosch-Sijtsema 2016 ). Others examine individuals organizing
strategic sustainable facilities Management and reno-
vation in their everyday work life (Gluch and Svensson
2018 ) and the role of materiality in this process
(Svensson and Gluch 2022 ); how BIM managers work
to increase digitalization in the construction sector
(Bosch-Sijtsema and Gluch 2021 ), how municipalities
contribute to driving sustainability focussing on woodconstruction (Salmi et al. 2022 ); the role of coordin-
ation contributing to project performance inTable 2. Creating work adapted from Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 ).

Advocacy The mobilization of political and regulatory support
through direct and deliberate techniques of
social persuasionBuilding on CE principles and forthcoming legislation to
advocate for changes
Lobbying for the application of CE principles at local and
national levels
Defining The construction of rule systems that confer status or
identity, define boundaries of membership or create
status hierarchies within a fieldEstablishing new rules and goals related to waste within
the organization
Creating prizes and rewards
New certification systems
Constructing identities Defining the relationship between an actor and the field
in which that actor operatesDefining new set of competences, roles and functions in
the organization
New actors entering the CDW field
Changing normative
associationsRe-making the connections between sets of practices and
the moral and cultural foundations for those practicesCreating thematic groups related to CE within the
organization
Investing in electric machines and vehicles.

__data__.text:
design-build management (Urup 2016 ) drawing on
partnership (Gottlieb et al. 2020 ) or demonstrate how
actors use relational institutional work in interorgani-zational projects aiming at institutionalizing a newproject delivery method (Lieftink et al. 2019 ). The
articles collected for the literature review building oninstitutional work and the construction sector focus onsingle individual, organization or type of project, weidentify a gap to examine how different forms of insti-
tutional work are mobilized when a specific field is
under regulative transformation can contribute tomodify this existing field and possibly instore a newregime. In doing so we can identify what these actionsare and how they contribute or not to transform theexisting norms and practices into a sustainableCDW field.
Method
Research setting and data collection
To identify the ongoing activities related to the newregulatory framework in the field of CDW, we haveadopted an abductive strategy, drawing on the frameof institutional work by Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 )
(Dahlmann and Grosvold 2017 , Berghout et al. 2018 ,
Graf and Jacobsen 2021 ). The study builds on aninterpretative approach and a combination of qualita-
tive research methods and data sources addressingdifferent levels (Meyer and Rowan 1977 , Scott 2010)
highlighting the degree to which organizational struc-
ture and behaviour are driven by sets of socially con-
structed beliefs, norms and rules negotiated andenforced in communities of organizations (DiMaggioand Powell 1983 )
Combining the analysis of data drawn from mul-
tiple levels enables the study of singular professionalactivities embedded in the environment of institu-
tional complexity and create a link between these
activities and the potential transformation at the levelof the field (Shadnam and Lawrence 2011 ). We
focussed on the interplay among actors ’intentions
regarding CDW, their activities, actions taken and
expected outcomes. A synthesis of available literatureand document analysis have been undertaken to tracemajor developments of new legislation.
The empirical material has been gathered between
2017 and 2020 in three successive phases. A flowchartspecifying the different phases of collecting empirical
material is presented in Table 4 .
Phase one consisted of an exploratory study aiming
at mapping the field of CDW in the region of WestSweden. During our participation to a researchTable 3. Disrupting work, adapted from Lawrence and Suddaby ( 2006 ).

__data__.text:
network (Constructivate Mistra closing the loop
2017 –2019) gathering 28 practitioners and researchers
concerned with the future of waste in construction,we identified 6 actors actively engaged in CDW and
advocating for changes in the sector with whom we
conducted semi-structured interview.
In addition to these data, we started to collect
information from reports, documents and mediacoverage, including professional guidelines, norms andcertifications, company websites, renovation projects
and quality control protocols, waste material descrip-
tions, price lists and price calculations, as well asnational and European governmental reports andlegislations. The synthesis of this literature and docu-ment analysis has enabled us to gain a broader under-standing of the development of the institutional field,
the different actors ’roles in the process and to trace
the major developments of the regulative frame. Italso provided information about some of the inter-viewees ’ongoing projects (Bryman 2016 ).
To follow the institutional work agenda, we
focussed on the micro-level actions and interactions of
individuals as the phenomena of interest. Therefore,the next two steps of data collection focussed oninterviews and observations as primary data sources,enabling us to capture practitioners ’everyday activ-
ities as well as the meanings they ascribe to them(Zilber 2008 , Smets and Jarzabkowski 2013 ). So, to do
so we have focussed on two specific actors, namely
the demolition companies and the three largest con-tractors operating in West Sweden as they are bothbeing directly engaged with the production of CDWon site and the handling afterwards. The demolitioncompanies were identified through snowball sampling
and sourcing the web from a map search engine
using specific trade words and concepts (Bryman2016 ). Out of 21 companies contacted, seven compa-
nies took part in the study gathering 11 participants.The interviewees position in the organization was alsopart of the selection. Either manager or owner theirsocial position reflects their formal authority and
thereby ability to impose change in the organization
(Battilana et al. 2009 ).
For the third phase, we chose to contact the three
largest contractors in Sweden as they play a leadingrole in shaping the CDW institutional field. Choosing
main actors within a field is consistent with an explor-
ation of what is still an emerging phenomenon (Yin2009 ). We initially interviewed the environmental man-
ager at the regional level. Though their formallyassigned role may vary, they share the common taskto develop and implement CDWM processes withintheir organization. They introduced us to site manag-
ers enabling us to collect information on practices andattitudes towards CDW at the level of the project. A
total of 13 project-, site- and production managers dis-
tributed between four sites were part of the project.
Data were primarily collected through semi-
structured interviews with practitioners of the CDW
institution field. Interviews are commonly used as
data-collection method when studying institutionalwork to identify actors ’roles in shaping the institu-
tional context they are part of (Lawrence et al.
2011 , Granqvist and Gustafsson 2016 , Dahlmann and
Grosvold 2017 ). They allow us to understand how
individuals interpret their surroundings, explain theiractions and elaborate on description of practices.
We are therefore better able to understand the
underlying reasons as to why individuals performparticular actions, what they do to shape the institu-tional context and under what circumstances
(Hampel et al. 2017 ). Though the semi-structured
interviews were shaped according to the function ofthe respondents, they mainly consisted of three setsof open questions focussing on: (1) the function,
task and responsibility of the interviewees; (2) their
current practices of CDWM and the opportunities,challenges and barriers they identify related to thenew regulative frame and (3) their perceptions,actions or/and reactions towards meeting these chal-
lenges and overcoming the barriers.
The interviews took place either at the interview-
ees’offices or on the construction site. The duration
of the interviews ranged from one to one and a half
hours. On eight occasions, they were performed asgroup interviews with more than one representativeof the organization. All participants were informedabout the aim of the study and that their contribution
would be anonymized (Bryman 2016 ).

ees’offices or on the construction site. The duration
of the interviews ranged from one to one and a half
hours. On eight occasions, they were performed asgroup interviews with more than one representativeof the organization. All participants were informedabout the aim of the study and that their contribution
